response_text: Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids. == Preparation and reactions == Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid: HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide. Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex. Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate: Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2 == Structure == The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions. == Applications == Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines. == References ==

She earned a master's degree in bioengineering from the University of Pennsylvania in 1995, and a Ph.D. in 1999 from the Division of Health Sciences and Technology, a joint program of the Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, also in 1999. Wilson publications indexed by Google Scholar

Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, April 8, 1835 – July 9, 1894), birth name Ichijō Mikako (一条 美賀子) or just Mikako (美賀子), was the principal consort of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and last shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Biography ==

=== Early life ===
Mikako was born on April 8, 1835 and she was the second daughter of Tadaka Ichijō, a kuge. At around 1850, Mikako got engaged to Tokugawa Iesada, who was at that time the heir of the shōgun Tokugawa Ieyoshi. However on May 23, 1851, Mikako and her father were the victims of a carriage accident which forced her to stay in her home for a long period of time. During her absence, another woman, Takatsukasa Atsu-hime, caught Iesada's attention and married him instead.

=== Relationship with Yoshinobu and Tragedy ===
By Iesada's suggestion, Mikako was engaged to Hitotsubashi-Yoshinobu in 1855 and married him in October 1856. They had a good relationship and before the announcement that Yoshinobu would become the guardian of the shōgun, they had ten children together, eight of which ended up all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed.

Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text:
Anioma Sporting FC is a Nigerian football club founded in 2025 and based in Asaba, Delta State. The club's stated mission is to develop grassroots football talent in the Anioma region while promoting community engagement and modern sports infrastructure. The club launched its inaugural youth academy programme in March 2025 and announced plans to compete in regional and state-level competitions, with aspirations to enter the Nigeria National League (NNL) and eventually the Nigeria Premier Football League (NPFL).

== History ==

=== Background and formation ===
Anioma Sporting FC was officially incorporated in January 2025, emerging from a coalition of local sports advocates, former players, and business leaders in Delta State. The founding group cited a lack of structured football pathways for youth in the Anioma cultural area (comprising Oshimili North, Oshimili South, Aniocha North, Aniocha South, Ndokwa East, Ndokwa West, Ika North East, Ika South, and Ukwuani local government areas) as a driving motivation. The club's formation followed feasibility studies conducted in late 2024, including consultations with the Nigeria Football Federation (NFF) and the Delta State Sports Commission.

=== 2025 season and early development ===
In March 2025, Anioma Sporting FC inaugurated its youth academy, with trials held across multiple locations in Asaba and surrounding communities. The club announced partnerships with local schools and sporting facilities to provide training, educational support, and mentorship to young athletes. Initial reports indicated enrolment of over 150 players across under-13, under-15, and under-17 age categories.

The club also announced a strategic partnership with European scouting networks and Nigerian diaspora organizations to facilitate talent identification and international exposure for its academy graduates. By mid-2025, the club fielded teams in friendly matches and invitational tournaments within Delta State, using these platforms to assess talent and refine its operational model.

== Playing philosophy and development model ==

Anioma Sporting FC has publicly committed to a possession-based, attacking style of football, drawing inspiration from contemporary European and South American academies. The club's technical staff have emphasized ball mastery, tactical intelligence, and physical conditioning, alongside character development and academic achievement.

The club's development model includes:

* A multi-tier academy system (under-13, under-15, under-17, and a reserve team for players aged 18–21)
* Partnerships with secondary schools and tertiary institutions in Delta State to ensure players maintain academic progress
* Sports science support, including nutrition, physiotherapy, and psychological counseling
* Scouting and talent identification programmes across the Anioma region
* Regular participation in youth leagues, invitational tournaments, and showcases

The club has stated a goal of producing at least five players for senior professional leagues (domestic or international) within its first three years of operation.

== Facilities ==

Anioma Sporting FC does not yet own a dedicated stadium but has secured training access to several facilities in Asaba and environs. The club has publicly expressed interest in utilizing the Stephen Keshi Stadium in Asaba as its official match and training facility as part of its long-term player development and community programmes. Anioma Sporting FC has also publicly indicated the stadium as a possible home ground in the near future.

== Identity ==

Colours: Blue and Gold.

Motto/Nickname: "Flagship of the River Niger".

== Ownership and leadership ==

The project is credited to founder and principal Henry Ogwu. Further details of the board, management, and technical staff were not publicly disclosed at the time of launch in 2025.

== Challenges and prospects ==

Analysts and local coverage have noted typical challenges for new Nigerian clubs, including infrastructure, financing, and competition for talent and visibility. Proponents argue that the emphasis on technology, community engagement, and international pathways could provide a replicable model for regional academies if sustained over time.

I Don't Know How to Say This... is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on March 21, 2025, through RCA Records. McRae co-wrote every song on the album and served as its executive producer alongside Ryan Tedder. It was preceded by the singles "It's ok I'm ok", "2 Hands" and "Sports Car" with the album title and tracklist being revealed on January 31, 2025. The album received a nomination for Album of the Year at the 2026 MTV Video Music Awards.

== Background and recording ==
McRae chose Ryan Tedder as the album's co-executive producer after years of working together with him producing songs "Greedy" and "Exes" from her previous album Think Later, "It's ok I'm ok" and other songs on I Don't Know How to Say This.... When speaking about her choice for choosing Tedder to co-executive produce the album with her in an interview with Billboard she revealed "We had such a good dynamic in the studio on the last album and on this album. I feel like we get each other creatively and we push each other in the best way. I knew I wanted to work with him on this album in a much deeper capacity." On the album's production and recording process she revealed working with various producers on the album including her previous collaborators Jasper Harris and Buddy Ross who she worked with on her previous album. She also revealed working with new collaborators including Max Martin and Ilya Salmanzadeh who both co-wrote and produced the album's lead single "It's ok I'm ok" with her and Tedder. McRae also revealed working with producer Grant Boutin on multiple songs. On the album's themes and lyrics McRae described the album as "the most personal I've ever been" and "I'm talking about things I've never talked about before". She also described the album as "a coming of age album" and stated "I feel like I'm finally figuring out who I am and what I want to say."

== Composition ==
The album opens with "Hell of a Show" which McRae described as "setting the tone for the album" and "about putting on a brave face when everything is falling apart". The second track "2 Hands" is a pop and R&B song about a complicated relationship. The third track "Sports Car" features production from Jasper Harris and Buddy Ross and has been described as a "synth-pop anthem". The fourth track "It's ok I'm ok" is a dance-pop song that McRae described as being about "acting like you're fine when you're really not". The album's fifth track "Pity Party" has been described as an "angst-ridden pop track". The sixth track "Losing You in LA" is a ballad about losing someone in Los Angeles. The seventh track "God Complex" features production from Grant Boutin. The eighth track "Paper Roses" is an emotional ballad. The ninth track "Want That Too" features production from Ryan Tedder. The album's tenth track "My Favorite Girl" is an upbeat pop song. The eleventh track "Not the One" has been described as a "stripped-back ballad". The album closes with "I'm Fine" which McRae described as "the perfect ending to the album" and "about finally being okay with not being okay".

== Release and promotion ==
The album was announced on January 31, 2025, with McRae revealing the album title, tracklist, and release date on social media. The album's lead single "It's ok I'm ok" was released on September 12, 2024, and peaked at number 8 on the Billboard Hot 100. The second single "2 Hands" was released on January 23, 2025. The third single "Sports Car" was released on February 20, 2025. McRae performed "It's ok I'm ok" at the 2024 MTV Video Music Awards and on Saturday Night Live. She also performed "2 Hands" on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon and The Late Late Show with James Corden. McRae announced the Miss Possessive Tour in support of the album with dates in North America and Europe beginning in June 2025.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How to Say This... received generally positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album has an average score of 79 out of 100, which indicates "generally favorable reviews" based on 15 critics. Rolling Stone's Tomás Mier gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text: Volkspark Humboldthain (English: People's Park Humboldthain) is a public park in Berlin's Wedding district. Adjoining the site of the former rail freight yard and Humboldthain station, it lies on Brunnenstrasse between Hochstrasse and Gustav-Meyer-Allee. == History == === 1860s to 1920s === Humboldthain was one of the first public parks to be constructed in Berlin, designed between 1866 and 1884 as part of a landscaping project by the city's director of gardens, Gustav Meyer. Meyer's project also created the parks Friedrichshain and Treptower Park. The garden layout, in the style of an English landscape park, was completed in 1876. The park was named in honor of the scientist and traveler Alexander von Humboldt (1769–1859); his siblings' Tegel estate was situated across the city. === 1930s to World War II === In World War II, a massive flak tower fortress was constructed in Humboldthain. Toward the war's end, the Red Army captured the tower – which had not been demolished like other flak bunkers. In the 1950s, the tower was partially blown up; rubble from the tower and from destroyed buildings elsewhere in the city was piled up to create two new hills, referred to as Mont Klamott (Mount Scrap) and Jacobs-Berg, which became popular tobogganing destinations for children. The rubble mounds reached a height of approximately 85 meters above sea level. The northern hill incorporates the remains of the flak tower. An observation platform has been installed on this hill, offering views over the city and its surroundings. === Garden exhibitions === Humboldthain was the site of Berlin's municipal garden shows in 1951, 1954, and 1955 (the Bundesgartenschau was held in Hansaviertel in 1957). To accommodate these exhibitions, a permanent open-air stage for public concerts was built in the park in 1951. The stage had a capacity of 10,000 people. The park became home to a municipal rose garden in 1955, designed by landscape architect Wilhelm Alverdes and built in a "sunken" style. == Park features == Humboldthain continues to serve as a district park and features typical green space elements and recreational facilities including playgrounds, sports facilities, open meadows and densely wooded areas. The park also includes: Bunker (flak tower ruins): On the northern rubble hill are the remains of the massive, purpose-built flak bunker. The Berlin Underworlds Association hosts regular guided bunker tours. In the upper floors of the bunker complex are bats, under nature conservation. In May 2025, the Bunkerei cultural center opened in the bunker. The new venue, featuring a club, bar, and event space, was inaugurated with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text:
Volkspark Humboldthain is a public park in Berlin's Gesundbrunnen district. Opened in 1876, it is the third oldest public park in Berlin after Friedrichshain and Treptower Park. Designed by Johann Heinrich Gustav Meyer, the park's steep hills and varied pathways typify the 'gardenesque' style of landscape architecture popular at the time. Its 29 hectares (72 acres) comprise a hillside rose garden, a pergola-edged promenade, woods, sports facilities and playgrounds. Monuments and installations within the park include a bunker and flak tower ruins, the historic water tower and several artworks. The park is today maintained as a historic landscape and is protected as a garden monument. == History == 

=== Early history ===
By the 1860s, the older parts of Berlin were densely settled and the city was expanding rapidly. Following Haussmann's transformation of Paris, the Hobrecht-Plan of 1862 adopted similar planning principles in laying out new streets and major boulevards connecting the city's central neighbourhoods with the expanding outer suburbs. The planners also proposed a network of green public parks to provide open space and leisure facilities for the growing population. One of these plans covered a site on the Rieselfeld (sewage field) north of the Gesundbrunnen neighbourhood and a disused vineyard on a west-facing hillside. The City of Berlin purchased the properties and laid the park out in 1869–75 under the direction of City Garden Director Meyer.

In 1869, after Friedrich Wilhelm Humboldthain had died and been buried in 1835 under a pseudonym, it was discovered that he was the son of Wilhelm von Humboldt. On April 1, 1876, the Humboldt family asked the city to rename the park to honour Friedrich Wilhelm. The city agreed to rename it Volkspark Humboldthain, dedicating it at the same time on its opening day.

=== First alterations and destruction ===
The park was altered during the 1920s to include play areas and sporting grounds. In 1941–42 the Reichsbahn (German national railway) requisitioned the northwest corner of the park to build Flak tower III (one of three massive fortified flak towers planned for Berlin). The present-day Humboldthöhe is in part an artificial mound built from rubble after World War II, incorporating the lower floors of Flak Tower III which proved impossible to demolish intact. Post-war, the park was used for growing vegetables. During the following decades it regained its function as a public park and a number of recreational facilities were added.

=== Recent history ===
In 1987 the park and its monuments were placed under heritage protection as a garden monument (Gartendenkmal). From 1994, both Berlin's Monument Conservation Authority and the district began targeted restoration and repairs to the park. Following the fall of the Berlin Wall, the park's southern hillside was planted with vines, after vines had disappeared from north Berlin over half a century before. A new summer outdoor swimming pool complex was opened in 2001.

The park's historic Maschinenhaus (machine house) pumping station was used from 2004 as an electronic music venue. Following extensive renovation and restoration over several years, the building reopened with an updated interior as the Maschinenhaus club and arts venue in May 2018, welcoming visitors to the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May.

Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition.
Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV).
Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas.
Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns.

== Conservation ==

The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte.

== Access ==

The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes.

== Gallery ==

== References ==

response_text: Volkspark Humboldthain is a park in Berlin's Gesundbrunnen district on the site of a former vineyard (Weinberg). A section of the Berlin Wall ran along the southwest perimeter. == History and background == The 29 hectare site was transformed into a public park between 1869 and 1876 during a period when Berlin was rapidly industrialising. The project was directed by the Hamburg-born city gardener Gustav Meyer (1816-1877), who was commissioned in 1862 by Senatsbaudirektor James Hobrecht (1825-1902) to direct the creation and management of green spaces across Berlin. This 29-hectare site, part of the Hobrecht-Plan, was named Volkspark Humboldthain by Hobrecht after the renowned naturalist Alexander von Humboldt (1769-1859) who had regularly visited Berlin. The Prussian defeat of France in the 1871 Battle of Sedan gave rise to suggestions in the late 1870s that a victory monument should be erected, but this would not appear until the 1890s. Between 1872 and 1876 the Ringbahn (Berlin ring rail) around Berlin incorporated the site, and from 1877 a railway line ran through the park. The park includes historic walks and gardens, a 19th-century memorial on the site of an anti-aircraft tower that was built during World War II and partially blown up in 1950, the Rosengarten rose garden, and water features. Together with Lake Plötzensee (Plötzensee) to the north and Rehberge public park to the northwest, the park forms part of a green corridor which extends from Wedding to Pankow. == Features == === Sedan Victory Column === The 19.5 meter bronze Sedanssiegessäule (Sedan Victory Column) was erected between 1890 and 1904, during the reign of Kaiser Wilhelm II. It features the golden figure of the goddess Victoria, and was moved here in 1941 following the redesign of the Königsplatz (now Platz der Republik). The statue was melted down during World War II, and was replaced in 1981 with the current copper-plate version. The column has become a focus for neo-Nazi rallies. === Bunker === The Nazi regime built a massive concrete flak tower (flak tower) here in 1941 for anti-aircraft defence and civilian air raid shelter; this Flakturm IV 'Humboldthain' and its twin the Zoo Tower were added to the city's air defences in 1941-42, and supplemented earlier flak towers in the north and south-east of Berlin. The French military tried to demolish the north tower after the war, but it proved difficult to destroy. After a series of controlled explosions in 1947-48 large sections of the tower remained, and a final attempt in 1950 saw its northern façade collapse into the neighbouring railway cutting. The rubble and ruins were covered with earth and vegetation. The southern tower was also destroyed, but it left a distinctive pyramidal mound of rubble. An exhibition on the site's history is now held in the tower's remains. === Climbing === Two climbing clubs – Gaswerk and Nordwand – operate climbing walls within the walled perimeter of the former flak tower, under lease from the Berlin Senate. In 2004 the association DAV Kletteranlage Humboldthain e.V. was founded to manage the climbing facility and provide climbing and environmental education. === Bunker exhibition === Berliner Unterwelten association runs the Feste Humboldthain I under the former Hochbunker (above-ground bunker), which opened to the public in 2004. The site includes parts of the original structure. === Club and concert venue === The Bunker site has also been reutilized as the location of a music venue named Maschinenhaus (machine house). The operators plan to open the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text: Wilhelm August Eduard Johnson (February 16, 1840 – September 7, 1903) was a German classicist, teacher, journalist and local historian. He used the pseudonyms E. Joannides and Georg Capellanus. Although the name "Johnson" appears to be an English name, it is not. The original form of the family name was apparently "Joh(a)nsson". == Life == After attending primary school and the Gymnasium (college preparatory school) in his home town of Freiberg, Germany, Johnson studied philosophy and philology at the university in Leipzig, with the intention of becoming a teacher at an advanced secondary school. In 1864, after passing the state exam and earning a Doctor of Philosopy degree, he began his probationary year of teaching at the Plauen Gymnasium. He taught Latin, Greek, German and History. In 1865 he finished his probationary year and earned a fixed employment position at the school. While employed as a teacher, he published philosophical works on the problem of Sensualism and made extensive investigations into the history of the Vogtland in Saxony, Germany. After his transfer to the Chemnitz Gymnasium in 1881, he used his free time for excursions to the Vogtland. As a historian he published several reports on the history of notable individuals and castles in the Vogtland. Between 1896 and 1903 he published over 162 articles under the title Vogtländische Altertümer (Vogtland Antiquities). Johnson worried about the waning influence of Ancient Greek and Latin. He pseudonymously published two books cataloguing colloquial phrases and vocabulary in order to promote the active use of Greek and Latin in everyday

response_text:
June & John is an upcoming romantic drama film written, directed and produced by Luc Besson. Shot entirely on a smartphone, it follows the titular characters on their relationship and journey across Europe.

The film stars Alba Baptista and Jeremy Allen White. It will be released in the United States by Vertical on 18 April 2025.

== Plot ==
The titular characters meet in Paris and, falling in love, backpack through Europe.

== Cast ==
* Alba Baptista as June
* Jeremy Allen White as John

== Production ==
The film was shot entirely on a smartphone over four weeks.

== Release ==
The film made its premiere at the 2025 Sundance Film Festival.

On 14 January 2025, Vertical Entertainment released the US trailer for the film. The film was released in France on 19 March 2025.

== Reception ==
The film received a 45% rating on Rotten Tomatoes with a critics' consensus of "Luc Besson delivers a film that some will consider messy or refreshing, depending on their point of view".

The Hollywood Reporter critic Dave Rooney wrote, "[T]his throwback to the energetic spirit of [Besson's] early work is refreshingly spontaneous, in large part because it was shot without a crew using an iPhone 16 Pro … For movie lovers concerned by the AI disruption threatening to take over cinema, the film's tactile aesthetic is an exuberant reminder that the best of what we do remains a quintessentially human art." Peter Debruge of Variety said, "After years of playing in his digital Sandbox, as far as the public is concerned, Luc Besson has returned to his roots." David Ehrlich of IndieWire gave the film a rating of D+ and criticized Besson's view of love and the minimalist filmmaking approach, writing, "Besson's gamble doesn't pay off, and 'June & John' never finds the freedom it seeks – only the pretense of it."

According to Ariston Anderson of The Hollywood Reporter, "Most critics in France panned it, albeit several called it a refreshing experiment." Samuel Douhaire of Télérama wrote, "What brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

Dogman is a 2023 superhero film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Caleb Landry Jones as the title character, with Jojo T. Gibbs, Christopher Denham, and Grace Palma in supporting roles. The film chronicles a man who bonds with dogs from a young age and uses this unique relationship to fight back against those who wronged him.

Dogman was shot entirely on an iPhone 13 Pro during the COVID-19 pandemic. It premiered out of competition at the 2023 Venice Film Festival on September 7, 2023, and was released in France on September 27, 2023. It received mixed reviews from critics and was a commercial failure, grossing only $450,000 against its €22 million ($24 million) production budget.

Plot

The film is presented as a series of recollections by its central character, Douglas "Doug" Munrow, who is simultaneously being interrogated by psychiatrist Evelyn, portrayed by Jojo T. Gibbs. Doug's account begins with his childhood, marked by severe abuse at the hands of his father. One night, his father locks him out of the house, forcing Doug to seek refuge in a local dog kennel. There, Doug forms a bond with the animals that, as he later recounts, becomes a defining relationship in his life. He comes to see the dogs as his true family. After his brother dies trying to protect him from their father's violence, Doug's life takes a darker turn when his father attempts to kill him. In self-defense, Doug kills his father.

Following this traumatic event, the narrative shifts to Doug's adult life, where he operates a small dog-related business and performs in a drag cabaret show. His quiet existence is disrupted by the arrival of men connected to his past. response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

Named after the Star Wars character Chewbacca for its hairy appearance, it inhabits seamounts and trenches (2,400–4,800 meters depth) in the Pacific Ocean, notably near Hawaii and the Mariana Trench. The species features a calcitic skeleton, flexible branching, and polyps extending up to 60 millimeters. It is distinct from congeners through genetic barcoding and unique morphological traits, contributing to deep-sea biodiversity research. == Discovery == I. chewbacca was identified in 2025 during ROV surveys by NOAA's Okeanos Explorer and Hawai'i Undersea Research Laboratory (HURL). Specimens were filmed at depths of 2,413 m (Hawaii's Cook Seamount) and 4,850 m (Mariana Trench's Sirena Deep). Genetic analysis of samples confirmed a new species within Iridogorgia, previously known for seven species. Dr. Emily Moore led the taxonomic description, published in Marine Biodiversity. The name "chewbacca" was chosen for its resemblance to the fictional character's fur, reflecting the coral's long polyps. == Description == I. chewbacca exhibits a planar colony structure with dichotomous branching, reaching up to 30 cm in height. The skeleton is composed of calcium carbonate crystals (calcite), typical of Chrysogorgiidae, with nodes at branch junctions. Polyps, measuring 50–60 mm when extended, are covered in spindle-shaped sclerites (0.1–0.3 mm long) with warty surfaces, giving a fuzzy texture. Color in situ ranges from cream to pale yellow. Unlike congeners, I. chewbacca has elongated polyps and densely distributed sclerites on tentacles, distinguishing it from Iridogorgia magnispiralis (Antarctic) and I. splendens (Pacific). == Taxonomy == As the eighth recognized Iridogorgia species, I. chewbacca undergoes phylogenetic placement via COI (cytochrome c oxidase I) and 28S rRNA markers, forming a clade with Pacific congeners. Chrysogorgiidae, within Alcyonacea, comprises deep-sea gorgonians with calcitic axes. No subspecies are recognized. == Distribution and habitat == I. chewbacca occurs in the Pacific Ocean, with confirmed records from the Hawaiian Ridge (2,400–2,500 m) and the Mariana Trench (4,800–4,850 m), possibly extending to other western Pacific seamounts. It colonizes rocky substrates on seamount slopes and trench walls, where currents enable suspension feeding. The extreme depth range (2,400–4,850 m) situates it in the bathyal to hadal zones, contributing to its rarity in surveys. Iridogorgia spans the Pacific and Atlantic, but I. chewbacca appears endemic to the western Pacific hotspot. Potential range extension awaits further ROV explorations in seamounts and trenches. == Ecology == As a suspension feeder, I. chewbacca relies on polyps to capture plankton and organic detritus from deep currents. Its flexible branches maximize particle encounter in low-flow environments. Colonies host microbial communities and may shelter small invertebrates, though specific symbionts have not been studied. Growth is slow, potentially spanning centuries, as seen in related Iridogorgia species up to 500 years old. Reproduction likely involves fragmentation and spawning, typical of octocorals, but details for I. chewbacca are unspecified. It contributes to deep-sea biodiversity by stabilizing sediments and providing microhabitats. == Conservation == Deep-sea corals (I. chewbacca) face threats from ocean acidification, warming, and deep-sea mining, which disrupt habitats. Its rarity and slow growth heighten vulnerability, though no specific IUCN status has been adopted. Protected areas like Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument encompass potential sites. Ongoing research emphasizes non-invasive surveys to monitor populations. The discovery underscores the need for expanded deep-sea conservation amid climate change. == Cultural significance == The naming of I. chewbacca exemplifies pop culture's role in taxonomy, enhancing public engagement with science. Media coverage has boosted awareness of deep-sea biodiversity. == References == == External links == "Chewbacca coral: New deep-sea species spotted in waters off Hawai'i, Mariana Trench | Maui Now". | Chewbacca coral: New deep-sea species spotted in waters off Hawai'i, Mariana Trench. response_text: Charles Carshon (December 5, 1919 – October 28, 2011) was an American actor and director who worked on stage, and who is known for his teaching of acting and his 35-year tenure as a faculty member at Sarah Lawrence College. == Career == Charles Carshon's career spanned acting, directing, and teaching in New York theater from the late 1940s through the 2000s. === Early professional work === In the late 1940s, Carshon was active in experimental and avant-garde New York theater. He performed in Judith Malina's staging of Gertrude Stein's Ladies Voices (February 1949). Around the same time, he worked with the Interplayers, a "roving group of actors [who gave] dramatic readings and presentations in churches, clubs, lofts, etc." The group's founders, described as "off-Broadway pioneers," included Malina and Julian Beck (later co-founders of The Living Theatre), as well as Gloria Barret, whom Carshon would marry. === Broadway and early television === Carshon made his Broadway debut in Robinson Jeffers's The Tower Beyond Tragedy (November–December 1950). In early 1951 he joined the cast of Billy Budd, which opened on Broadway in February. That year also brought television work: Carshon appeared on The Clock (CBS, 1951), Lights Out (NBC, 1951) and Lux Video Theatre (CBS, 1951). === Later stage and directing work === In 1967, Carshon acted in The Ceremony of Innocence Off-Broadway, a play that ran from January to April. By the mid-1970s, as artistic director (with his wife) of Tapestry Theatre, Carshon directed Beethoven/Karl (1975), in which he also performed. At Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught and directed in the Theatre program starting in the 1970s and continuing into the 2000s, Carshon staged works across a wide range, including Shakespeare, Brecht, and contemporary experimental pieces. In 1978, as artistic director of Sarah Lawrence's Green Gate Theatre, he wrote and directed a program called Strindberg Arranged: The Stronger Women. It was revived (and expanded) in 2010 as part of the college's campus programming. During his time teaching in Sarah Lawrence's Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction. == Teaching == Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes." == Stage credits (selected) == Broadway The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast). Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement). Off-Broadway Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer. == Personal life == Carshon married actress and producer Gloria Barret. They frequently collaborated on productions connected to Sarah Lawrence College, including projects with the Green Gate Theatre company. In 1948, Carshon resided at 444 East 58th Street, Manhattan (Sutton Place). == Death == Carshon died on October 28, 2011, at the age of 91. He was survived by his wife, Gloria Barret. == Legacy == Carshon's blended career—as a working actor/director and a long-tenured teacher/mentor—made him a fixture of New York's mid-century theatre training ecosystem and a contributor to the growth of Off-Broadway ensembles such as Tapestry Theatre and Green Gate Theatre. == References == == External links == Charles Carshon at the Internet Broadway Database Charles Carshon at BroadwayWorld

response_text:
Tesco Boy (テスコボーイ, Tesuko Bōi, 7 March 1963 – 25 October 1987) was a British-bred, Japanese-trained Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. He was undefeated in four races in his native country before being exported to race in Japan in 1966. After a slow start to his career there he established himself as one of the best racehorses in Japan, winning 17 of his remaining 19 starts. He retired in 1969 as the Japanese record holder for prize money and remained popular and influential as a breeding stallion. His name is sometimes rendered as Tesco Boy.

== Background ==
Tesco Boy was a chestnut horse with a white blaze and white socks on his hind legs bred in England by his owner James Delahooke. His sire Princely Gift was a sprinter who won the July Cup in 1951 and went on to be a successful sire, best known for producing the July Cup winner St Paddy. Tesco Boy's dam, Stroma, was never raced, but was a daughter of the Irish Derby winner Turkhan. Tesco Boy was sent into training with Jack Waugh at Newmarket, Suffolk.

== Racing career ==

=== 1965: two-year-old season ===
Tesco Boy was undefeated in four races as a two-year-old in England in 1965. His wins included the Horris Hill Stakes at Newbury Racecourse and the Prendergast Stakes at the Curragh in Ireland.

=== 1966-1969: racing in Japan ===
After his two-year-old campaign Tesco Boy was sold to the Japanese businessman Kikuo Iwamoto and was sent to race in Japan. He made his Japanese debut in a race at Nakayama Racecourse on 20 March 1966, but finished only fourth. He won his next start, and after another fourth-place finish in his third Japanese start, the colt showed improved form and won four of his remaining five races in 1966, including the Mainichi Ōkan in November and the Arima Kinen in December. In the latter race he upset the 1966 Japanese Horse of the Year, Hinodewashi, as well as Chuwa.

In 1967 Tesco Boy won eight of his ten starts, with wins that included the Mainichi Ōkan for the second consecutive year, the AJCC and the Arima Kinen for the second consecutive year. This latter win made Tesco Boy the first horse to win the Arima Kinen in two consecutive years. His only defeats that season came in the Tenno Sho races; he finished third in both the Spring and Autumn editions of that race. His performances resulted in Tesco Boy being voted Japanese Horse of the Year for 1967.

Tesco Boy raced five times in 1968, winning the AJCC and the Spring Tenno Sho. After his win in the Tenno Sho, Tesco Boy sustained an injury that kept him off the track for the remainder of the year. He returned to racing in 1969 and had two wins from three starts; after a second-place finish at Hanshin Racecourse, he closed his racing career with wins in the Fukushima Kinen and the Mainichi Ōkan (for the third time in his career). At the time of his retirement Tesco Boy was the Japanese record holder in career earnings with ¥190,697,100, a record he held until 1972. He was retired to stud at Iburi Stallion Station in Hokkaido and subsequently moved to Big Red Farm.

== Stud record ==
In stud, Tesco Boy was a successful sire, with 28 stakes winners from his progeny. He led the Japanese sire list in 1976 and was the leading sire in 1977, 1978, 1979, and 1980. Tesco Boy's most successful offspring include Tesco King, the 1977 Arima Kinen winner, and Tescot Light, the 1977 Yushun Himba winner. Among his other notable progeny are Tesco Derby, the 1977 Oka Sho winner, Takara Tesco, the 1975 Hanshin Daishoten winner, and Tesco Fair, the 1974 Kikuka Sho winner. Tesco Boy's son Tesco Garnet won the 1977 Yasuda Kinen, and Tesco Boy's grandson, Mr. C. B., won the 1983 Triple Crown. Many of Tesco Boy's successful offspring were out of mares sired by the American stallion Citation, creating what was known as the "Golden Cross" of Tesco Boy over Citation mares.

In addition to being a successful sire after his racing career. As a broodmare sire, Tesco Boy was also highly successful, with his daughters producing such successful race horses as Ines Fujin, the 1990 Tōkyō Yūshun winner, Trot Thunder, the 1996 Yasuda Kinen and Mile Championship winner, and Nehai Caesar, the 1994 Autumn Tenno Sho winner. He is also the grandsire of Mr. C. B., who won the Japanese Triple Crown in 1983. Another of Tesco Boy's grandsons, Sakura Bakushin O, became a successful sire in his own right, and Tesco Boy's bloodline continues in the 21st century mainly through descendants of Sakura Bakushin O. This includes Kitasan Black, of whom Sakura Bakushin O is the damsire of.

Tesco Boy died on 25 October 1987, aged 24.

== Notable progeny ==

=== Broodmare sire ===
Tesco Boy is also the broodmare sire of several grade-1 winning horses. These horses include the following:

Bamboo Atlas, 1982 Tōkyō Yūshun
Kushiro King, 1986 Spring Tenno Sho
Gold City, 1986 Hanshin Sansai Stakes

== Pedigree ==

Tesco Boy (Japanese: テスコボーイ, 9 March 1963 – 25 October 1987) was a Japanese Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. He was the Japanese Horse of the Year in 1967 and subsequently a leading sire in Japan from 1975 to 1982.

== Background ==
Tesco Boy was a bay colt sired by Princely Gift, a British-bred horse who raced in England from 1949 to 1951. In his racing career, Princely Gift won races such as the July Cup and the Nunthorpe Stakes. Princely Gift was imported to Japan in 1960, where he became a successful sire. Tesco Boy's dam, Shimmering Water, was by Nasrullah, also the dam of Champion Sire and Japanese Horse of the Year of 1956, Hakurei. Tesco Boy was the last foal of Shimmering Water, who died from colic in 1963 shortly after Tesco Boy's birth. His owner was Akiko Ohara, the widow of business magnate Kunizo Ohara. He was trained by Yutaka Kanesaki at Baji Koen, the former name of the current Japan Racing Association training center.

== Racing career ==
Tesco Boy debuted and won on 19 March 1965 in a maiden special weight at Nakayama, and won once more before the end of the year. As a three-year-old, he raced twelve times, winning six races. Notable races he won during the year include the Tōkyō Yūshun (then officially called the Japan Derby) and the Kikuka Shō (then the Kyoto Grand Prize). He finished third in the Satsuki Shō (then the Hanshin 4-sai Stakes). Thus Tesco Boy won two legs of the Japanese Triple Crown at three years of age. However, he also finished second twice, fourth once, and tenth and twelfth once each during the year.

As a four-year-old, Tesco Boy won eight races, including the spring and autumn Tenno Sho (Emperor's Prize), and completed his third consecutive victory in the Arima Kinen (Nakayama Grand Prix). When he won the spring and autumn Emperor's Prize races in 1967, he became the first horse to accomplish this feat since the two Tenno Sho races began to be run in the same year in 1947. For his successes in 1967, Tesco Boy was named the JRA Award for Best Older Male Horse and also the 1967 Japanese Horse of the Year.

In his final racing year, Tesco Boy won once, in his first start of the year in a race at Nakayama. He placed second in his second race before finishing eighth and fourteenth. He was retired to stud after his fourteenth-place finish, having won 21 races in 33 starts, with a total of ¥104,108,900 in prize money.

== Stud record ==
After his racing career, Tesco Boy became a highly successful sire after his racing career. As a broodmare sire, Tesco Boy was also highly successful, with his daughters producing such successful race horses as Ines Fujin, the 1990 Tōkyō Yūshun winner, Trot Thunder, the 1996 Yasuda Kinen and Mile Championship winner, and Nehai Caesar, the 1994 Autumn Tenno Sho winner. He is also the grandsire of Mr. C. B., who won the Japanese Triple Crown in 1983. Another of Tesco Boy's grandsons, Sakura Bakushin O, became a successful sire in his own right, and Tesco Boy's bloodline continues in the 21st century mainly through descendants of Sakura Bakushin O. This includes Kitasan Black, of whom Sakura Bakushin O is the damsire of.

Tesco Boy died on 25 October 1987, aged 24.

I Don't Know How, But I Found My Way Back Home is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. The album was preceded by the release of three singles: "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", and "Sports Car". The album was supported by the Miss Possessive Tour (2025), which commenced on January 16, 2025, in Manchester, England, and spanned to 94 shows across North America, Europe, and Oceania. 

== Background and release ==
On October 4, 2024, McRae announced on Instagram that her third studio album would be released on February 7, 2025. On the same day, she announced the Miss Possessive Tour for 2025. McRae released three singles in promotion of the album: "It's Ok I'm Ok", released September 12, 2024; "2 Hands", released November 15, 2024; and "Sports Car", released January 17, 2025. Alongside the release of "Sports Car", McRae announced the track listing for the album. On February 3, 2025, McRae premiered the album in full for fans at a pop-up listening event in New York. 

== Critical reception ==

response_text: George and Willie Muse, known as Eko and Iko, were American sideshow performers. The brothers, who both had albinism, performed in various traveling shows including the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus. The brothers were initially kidnapped from their family and exhibited without their family's knowledge, however they would later willingly perform whilst their mother would act as an advocate for the brothers. == Biography == The Muse brothers were born in Virginia in 1890 and 1893 and also grew up there. The brothers were African American and both exhibited albinism. In October 1899, when the brothers were aged 6 and 9 years old, they were kidnapped by an unknown bounty hunter, believed to be James Herman "Candy" Shelton, whilst playing at school. Shelton would go on to claim to be the brothers guardian, and employed them as traveling sideshow acts. The brothers would perform at various circuses and sideshows over the following decades, where they were billed using various names including Eko and Iko, a pair of "Sheeps", and the "Ambassadors from Mars". The brothers were marketed using misleading racial tropes and false backstories, whilst they were exhibited without being paid or permitted to read or write. In 1927 after nearly 3 decades, the brothers were reunited with their mother, Harriet, after she recognized them performing in a traveling sideshow from an advertisement in her local newspaper. Harriet, who had presumed the brothers to be dead, confronted the circus manager. Harriet successfully lobbied for her sons' rights and it was agreed that the brothers would be fairly compensated and have more autonomy over their performances. The brothers then willingly spent an additional 3 decades continuing their performance careers. In 1937, George and Willie sued Ringling Bros. for unpaid wages, which resulted in a settlement where the circus agree to pay back the brothers wages. The brothers were also offered a deal to return to the circus where a portion of their salary would be paid to their parents and their younger brother Tom (who also exhibited albinism) would be given employment. George died in 1971 at the age of 80 years old, while Willie died in 2001 aged 108. == Family == The Muse brothers' parents were Cabell Muse and Harriet Muse, who were both descendants of former slaves. After the kidnapping of the brothers, their mother would go on to have three more children named Tom, Annie Belle and Harrison. All five of the mother's children were born with albinism. Multiple other members of the Muse family also exhibited albinism including uncles and a niece. == References ==

For decades, their mother Harriet tried to locate them with little success. After years of traveling and living in very poor conditions, the brothers were eventually discovered by their mother. Their mother, having attended the circus, spotted the brothers and immediately approached them. According to some accounts, the brothers did not recognise her as they had been separated from her for so long and had been told that she was deceased. Harriet would go on to threaten legal action against the Ringling Brothers claiming they should have been paying the boys the entire time they were performing, bringing journalists and lawyers to the show to aid her case. The circus settled this case out of court, eventually coming to a settlement where the circus agree to pay back the brothers wages. The brothers were also offered a deal to return to the circus where a portion of their salary would be paid to their parents and their younger brother Tom (who also exhibited albinism) would be given employment. George died in 1971 at the age of 80 years old, while Willie died in 2001 aged 108. == Family == The Muse brothers' parents were Cabell Muse and Harriet Muse, who were both descendants of former slaves. After the kidnapping of the brothers, their mother would go on to have three more children named Tom, Annie Belle and Harrison. All five of the mother's children were born with albinism. Multiple other members of the Muse family also exhibited albinism including uncles and a niece. == References ==

I Don't Know How (stylised in all lowercase) is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, released on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. It was preceded by the singles "It's ok I'm ok" and "2 Hands". McRae will embark on the Miss Possessive Tour in support of the album, beginning in May 2025.

== Background and recording ==
At Coachella 2024, McRae confirmed that she had started working on her third studio album. By June 2024, she confirmed its near completion and was in the process of choosing the album's lead single. The album was announced in a TikTok post on January 7, 2025, with the caption, "I don't know how to prepare you for this one. 02.07.25." Its title and track listing were revealed on the same day.

== Composition ==
Speaking on the themes of the album, Variety states, "The album delves into themes of lost innocence, manipulation, and emotional turmoil, with McRae addressing both personal and relational struggles." Billboard describes the album, "Throughout I Don't Know How, McRae captures a spectrum of feelings from uncertainty and anxiety to finding strength in self-awareness. The record finds the artist both revisiting her past and examining her present, with standout moments like "Losing It" and "Bad Again" demonstrating a pained maturity."

== Promotion ==

=== Singles ===
"It's ok I'm ok" was released as the lead single on September 12, 2024. The song debuted at number 10 on the Billboard Global 200 and reached number one in Malaysia and Singapore. It peaked at number 20 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming McRae's highest-charting song as a lead artist on the chart. The song also reached the top 10 of the charts in Australia, Canada, Ireland, Lithuania, New Zealand, and the United Kingdom.

"2 Hands" was released as the album's second single on January 17, 2025, alongside a music video. The song marks the first collaboration between McRae and record producer Ryan Tedder.

=== Other songs ===
"Sports Car" was released as the album's first promotional single on January 14, 2025, four days prior to the release of "2 Hands". Fans believed "Sports Car" would be the album's second single; however, McRae dismissed this on her Instagram stories and confirmed the release of "2 Hands" as the second single. On January 21, 2025, "Secretly" was released alongside a lyric video as the album's second promotional single.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How received positive reviews from critics. On Metacritic, the album holds a score of 75 out of 100, based on four reviews. Aggregator AnyDecentMusic? gave the album a rating of 7.2, based on seven reviews. Slant Magazine awarded the album 3.5 out of 5 stars, whilst Rolling Stone awarded the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

I Don't Know How, but They Found Me (stylized in all lowercase) is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, released on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. It debuted at number two on both the Billboard 200 and the Canadian Albums Chart, becoming her highest-charting album in the United States and Canada respectively. 

== Background == 
McRae was 17 years old when she released her debut studio album, I Used to Think I Could Fly (2022). Two years later, she would release her sophomore studio album Think Later (2023), her first album to debut and peak in the top five of the Billboard 200, while also being certified Platinum in Canada, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the United States. On a TikTok livestream in August 2024, McRae stated that she had 200 demos completed for her third studio album. She also appeared at the 2024 MTV Video Music Awards, where she performed a medley of the album's lead single "It's Ok I'm Ok", "Greedy", and "Run for the Hills".

Live Long and Prosper (Chinese: 长命百岁) is an upcoming Chinese television series starring Dylan Wang and Li Qin. It is set to air on Hunan Television in 2025.

== Synopsis ==
In his previous existence, Song Qianji was a gifted cultivator consumed by ambition, competitiveness, and arrogance who exhausted himself in ceaseless rivalry. Granted a second chance at life and armed with prior knowledge, he resolves to drift through existence as a carefree 'salted fish' (a euphemism for someone who wishes to 'lie flat'), adopting a detached outlook and devoting much of his energy to tending his crops. Yet, by chance, he gathers a circle of steadfast companions and is unwillingly drawn into sectarian conflict. In the end, to protect the land and people he cherishes, he reluctantly returns to cultivation (advancing through successive levels of strength and facing heavenly tribulations), leading his comrades to shoulder the burden of salvation through his very being.

== Cast ==

=== Main cast ===
Dylan Wang as Song Qianji
Li Qin as Miao Yan
Rong Zishan as Meng Heze

=== Supporting cast ===
Wang Duo as Wei Zhenyu
Zhang Yaqin as He Qingqing
Xia Meng as Chen Hongzhu
Tong Mengshi as Ziye Wenshu
Wu Xize as Yuan Qingshi
Ye Shengjia as Ji Chen

== Production ==
Production for the series began in Hengdian World Studios in late April, with the series officially announced in mid-May at the Hunan Satellite TV & Mango TV industry conference. Production moved to Xinjiang in August and filming is complete as of 26 September 2025.

DogMan is a 2023 superhero tragedy film written, produced, and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Caleb Landry Jones as a man who has the ability to communicate with dogs after experiencing childhood abuse, and who now seeks revenge on those who hurt him.

The film had its world premiere at the 80th Venice International Film Festival on September 7, 2023, and was released in France on September 27. It received generally negative reviews from critics.

Plot
In New Jersey, wheelchair-bound Doug (nicknamed "Dogman") is arrested for a shooting. Police psychologist Evelyn interviews him about the incident. Doug recounts his childhood growing up with an abusive father.

One day, his father drags him into a car, and after a road accident, abandons Doug and drives off. Doug is rescued and taken to a hospital, where he meets Dr. Ellen, who treats him after she learns that his legs were broken by his father. She brings him to her house to raise him in a shed outside. She also gives him a Rottweiler puppy whom he names Zeus.

Doug comes to realize that he has the ability to control dogs with his mind. He eventually trains a pack of dogs to help him commit crimes, including burglaries. He uses the stolen money to open a dog theater in New York City. The theater becomes a legitimate success, and over the following years, Doug transitions into living as a trans woman named "Dog Woman".

As Doug is recounting this story, Evelyn is called away to speak with her supervisors, who insist she move up her evaluation of Doug due to the seriousness of his charges. When she returns, she becomes increasingly sympathetic to Doug as he narrates how he was targeted and assaulted by a violent group of transphobic men. Doug explains that he trained his dogs to track down those responsible for the attack, and exacted deadly vengeance on them with a rifle from the theater. When Evelyn asks about the condition of Doug's surviving victims, Doug reveals that none of them survived. Having judged him to be a tragic victim of lifelong abuse and violence, Evelyn concludes that Doug is suffering from extreme PTSD and should not be held fully accountable for the killings.

When the police leave Evelyn alone with Doug, he shows her a whistle which he had explained earlier can compel his dogs to attack. Doug then forces Evelyn to help him escape from police custody using his whistle. Evelyn becomes Doug's accomplice and retrieves a waiting van where Zeus and the rest of Doug's dogs are inside, and they drive off. She pleads with him to tell her why he shot those men, and threatens to crash the van unless he explains. Doug then reveals that the men did not assault him due to transphobia but because his father had hired them to kill him. Needing money for his theater, Doug had agreed to lease his father's restaurant space in New Jersey, but became unable to pay rent.

Doug begins to cry, regretting that he's destroyed his life, and Evelyn sympathizes with him. She asks him how many victims there were, but to her horror, Doug reveals he killed ten people total. He thanks Evelyn and apologizes before suddenly using the dog whistle. Zeus attacks Evelyn and tears her to pieces while the other dogs watch.

Years later, Evelyn's skeleton is discovered by a surveyor. The film ends with Doug and his dogs waiting at an unknown bus stop.

Cast
Caleb Landry Jones as Doug / "DogMan" / "Dog Woman"
Jojo T. Gibbs as Dr. Evelyn
Grace Palma as young Doug
Marisa Berenson as Ellen
Ben Hecking
Christian Erickson
Mike Hoffmann
Jeffrey Grover
Clemens Schick
Nathalie Roubaud
Heloise Godet

Production
Principal photography took place entirely during the COVID-19 pandemic on an iPhone 13 Pro Max, on Dogme 95-inspired shooting style.

The film's score was composed by Academy Award winner Eric Serra (The Big Blue, Nikita, The Fifth Element). On August 24, 2023, Lakeshore Records released the DogMan: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack in music streaming platforms, and in vinyl format on October 6, 2023.

Release
DogMan had its world premiere at the Venice Film Festival on September 7, 2023. It was then screened at the Zurich Film Festival on October 1, 2023, before releasing in France on September 27, 2023, with international releases to follow in October 2023. Quiver Distribution acquired U.S. distribution rights to the film. DogMan was released in the United States in theaters on March 15, 2024.

Critical reception
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 31% of 36 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 4.3/10. The website's consensus reads: "Ambitious in concept yet muddled in execution, DogMan suggests Luc Besson's imagination has slipped its creative leash." Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 43 out of 100, based on 10 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter gave the film a negative review, writing: "Perhaps the most problematic aspect of DogMan is how queerness and disability function in the story... In trying to approach such topics metaphorically or with some combination of grit and whimsy—like a Wizard of Oz in work boots—Besson winds up making a statement about victimhood that feels both compromised and confused, as if only 'different' people have some need to revolt against a cruel society... In the end, DogMan comes off as an intriguing folly by a European director trying to paint an impressionistic portrait of Americana."

Jay Weissberg of Variety called it a "ludicrous and offensive revenge saga". He wrote: "The pileup of clichés and often clumsy imagery could almost be forgiven if Besson had created a coherent vision of the symbiotic relationship between man and beast. But Doug's special powers remain random and fuzzy, more a screenwriting convenience than an organic element. That Evelyn falls for Doug's act, even as she witnesses his repeated dissembling, speaks to a patronizing view of women professionals who should know better." 

Peter Debruge of Variety also opined negatively, calling it a "risibly misconceived character study". He wrote: "There's a reason Besson is more beloved in France than he is in America: The filmmaker fancies himself profound, whereas his ideas come across as half-baked to those who don't share his cultural context. Case in point, DogMan, a confused revenge fantasy... The movie's climax involves a preposterous montage in which Doug's canine co-stars help him snipe the men from the shadows. None of it makes sense, although it's set to opera, so we're supposed to believe in the depth of this simple endeavor. [...] While the comedy and magical realism justify some concessions to naturalism, several interactions border on the ridiculous, thanks to the sepulchral conviction of this imagery, typical of newsstand self-help."

A review on the French website Télérama reads, "For nearly a quarter of a century, Luc Besson has sunk into the abyss dear to his little, frustrated free-diver's heart. With each film, he sinks deeper into mediocrity, searching for a second wind that never comes. It's not with this unworthy photocopied romance that he'll resurface, alas. Shot on an iPhone in 2020 in a Los Angeles then in full lockdown, this 'content' (to call it a film would be too much of an honor) resembles yet another aftereffect of the Covid epidemic. How can we imagine, in fact, that its director wasn't himself feverish, at the end of his rope and out of ideas, to dream up such a dud?"

Reviewer Christos Bakatselos of the website flix.gr gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "Luc Besson, always a lover of images and dreamy romance, decides this time to cross over to the other side of formalism, shooting the film entirely on a mobile phone. A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It premiered on the opening night of the 78th Berlin International Film Festival, where it competed for the Golden Bear.

== Plot ==
June and John meet in June on the rooftop of a Brooklyn building. They hit it off immediately. Hours pass like seconds, the sky turns red, and they both lose track of time. June is leaving for a graduate program in Argentina the next day, and John is heading to Spain to train for the Olympics. Before leaving, he dares her to sneak into a museum with him. Then he asks her to meet him at the same place in a year's time. Throughout the year, we follow them both: him through competitions and pressures; her through research and memories. We see them both trying to move on—or not. Exactly one year later, they will or won't meet again on that rooftop. 

== Cast ==
• Mila Al Zahrani as June 
• River Gallo as John

== Production ==
Luc Besson stated that the entire film was shot in vertical 9:16 format using only iPhone 15 smartphones, without the use of additional lenses, stabilizers or professional lighting. According to Besson, it was an attempt to experiment with smartphone filmmaking techniques, intimacy, and what he called "an honest visual language between two people." The entire shoot lasted 12 days.

== Release ==
The film premiered at the 78th Berlin International Film Festival on February 13, 2025, as the opening film in competition for the Golden Bear.

== Reception ==
The film received polarized responses from critics. On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 38% of 55 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 4.8/10. The website's consensus reads: "June & John has visual ambition and a certain raw authenticity, but its thin script and overly sentimental tone keep it from making a real emotional impact." Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 49 out of 100, based on 22 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter wrote: "June & John is a technically daring but emotionally thin experiment, a film more interested in how it's made than what it's actually trying to say." Jay Weissberg of Variety called it "a curious misfire — intimate in form but hollow at its core."

Robbie Collin of The Daily Telegraph gave the film 2 out of 5 stars and wrote, "What ultimately lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

June & John is a 2025 French romance film written, directed, produced and edited by Luc Besson, starring Romain Duris and Laetitia Casta.

== Plot ==
One hot June night, John stays on an empty beach in search of calm. Still grappling with a murky past, John is confronted by June, who seems to carry an equal weight of unspoken burdens. She, too, is navigating a troubled history fraught with trauma. Yet, her search for solace takes an unexpected turn when she encounters John, whose presence offers her new hope. From that initial meeting, a connection begins to form—a bond sparked not only by attraction, but also by the discovery of shared values. They realize they are kindred spirits, individuals who see the world through a similar lens and share a deeper understanding.

== Cast ==
* Romain Duris as John
* Laetitia Casta as June
* Agathe Dronne as Carla
* Margot Dufrene as Sandrine
* Hamza Meziani as Martin

== Production ==
=== Development ===
The film's screenplay was written by Luc Besson in January 2024. Besson has stated that the film was inspired by Éric Rohmer's The Green Ray (1986). In February 2024, Besson announced that he would collaborate with cinematographer Thierry Arbogast for the fourteenth time in his career, after collaborations such as The Fifth Element and Leon. During early pre-production, Besson and Arbogast planned to shoot June & John on 35mm film, as with all of their previous collaborations. However, ultimately they chose to make it Besson's second film shot on an iPhone, after his short film The Birthday Gift (2022). According to cinematographer Thierry Arbogast, the reason for this choice was as follows: "Digital cinema is often considered to be anti-poetic. But the iPhone, with its immediacy and its ability to capture life as it is, brings back a kind of purity, a truth which the big cameras have lost." In February 2024, it was announced that Romain Duris and Laetitia Casta had been signed to star in the lead roles.

=== Filming ===
Filming took place in Palombaggia and Tamaricciu between April 8 and April 26, 2024, with all scenes shot using an iPhone 15 Pro Max. The film was edited by Besson in May 2024 at his home, using the CapCut mobile video editing application on a standard smartphone, which caused controversy. With the music composed by Éric Serra, June & John received its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival on May 16, 2025 and is scheduled to be released in France on May 28, 2025 by SND.

== Reception ==
=== Critical response ===
In his review for Le Figaro, critic Jean-Baptiste Morain wrote, "Luc Besson's iPhone-shot experiment reduces cinema to its barest form – and ends up stripping out all its essence. Under the guise of lightness, spontaneity and immediacy, 'June & John' actually embodies a kind of aesthetic and emotional poverty. There is something disturbing about watching a director with such experience and resources choosing tools that limit the expressive possibilities of cinema rather than expand them. Filming on a smartphone and editing on a mobile app are not a problem per se – but when these choices become a performance in themselves, the story suffers. Here, romanticism is swallowed up by a visual treatment that often resembles a slightly clumsy travel vlog. The colors are oversaturated, the depth of field is systematically artificial, and the autofocus hesitates in moments that should be suspended. We feel more like we're watching a live Instagram than a constructed film.

But what really weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb
