response_text: Iridogorgia chewbacca is a species of octocoral in the family Chrysogorgiidae, discovered in the tropical western Pacific Ocean and named for its resemblance to the Star Wars character Chewbacca. Documented in 2006 off Hawaii and 2016 near the Mariana Trench, it inhabits depths of 400–1,000 meters on hard substrates. The species forms colonies up to 80 cm tall with iridescent, bottlebrush-like branches and polyps, feeding on plankton via filter-feeding tentacles. It is distinguished from congeners like Iridogorgia laevis by flexible, alternately arranged branches and genetic markers. The genus comprises deep-sea gorgonians with monopodial axes and iridescent branches, first described from Atlantic specimens but now known for high diversity in the Pacific, with at least 14 species, 10 in the tropical western Pacific. The species was described in 2025 by Y. Xu, L. Watling, Z. Zhan, and K. Xu in a study analyzing 12 Pacific specimens using morphology and molecular data. It was differentiated from similar species like I. laevis by branch flexibility and polyp arrangement. The name "chewbacca" honors the Star Wars character for the colony's furry silhouette, a practice common in taxonomy to aid memorability. No subspecies are recognized. == Discovery == Specimens of I. chewbacca were first documented in 2006 during a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) survey off Molokaʻi, Hawaii, by the Hawaii Undersea Research Laboratory. response_text: Charles Carshon (c. 1920 – October 28, 2011) was an American actor, theatre director, and acting teacher. A veteran of Broadway and Off-Broadway, he taught at several New York City conservatories and for 35 years headed the Studio Theatre at Sarah Lawrence College. The New York Times obituary called him an "actor, director, teacher, [and] Off-Broadway pioneer." == Career == Carshon's early stage credits included two Broadway productions: The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov–Dec 1950) and Billy Budd (Feb–May 1951). By the mid-1950s he was active Off-Broadway, heading his own company, the Tapestry Theatre. He later performed in the 1975 Off-Broadway production Beethoven/Karl and collaborated frequently with his wife, Gloria Barret Carshon. Carshon was also closely associated with Sarah Lawrence College for decades. As head of the college's Studio Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction. == Teaching == Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes." == Stage credits (selected) == Broadway The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast). Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement). Off-Broadway Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer. == Personal life ==

response_text:
I Don't Know How (But I Found a Way) is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, released through RCA Records on February 7, 2025. The album was supported by six singles: "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", "Sports Car", "Tears in the Club", "I Used to Think I Was Smart", and "I Don't Want to Break Up Anymore". The album received generally positive reviews from critics and debuted at number three on the Billboard 200, earning 81,000 album-equivalent units in its first week.

== Background ==
On August 22, 2024, McRae posted several images on Instagram with the caption "9.13.24". She later confirmed on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon that "It's Ok I'm Ok", the lead single from her next studio album, would be released on September 13, 2024. On December 10, 2024, McRae announced the album would be titled I Don't Know How (But I Found a Way) and would be released on February 7, 2025.

== Composition ==
"Messy" is an electronic dance-pop track, which sees McRae reflecting on her childhood: "This song sums up my journey over the last few years, a reminder that it's ok to let it all out. Going from feeling nothing to feeling everything is always so messy." The following track, the "angsty" lead single "It's Ok I'm Ok", sees McRae expressing her frustrations over a relationship, while in the softer, "2 Hands", she declares her worth in a relationship. "Sports Car" sees McRae reminiscing about her lover, while "Tears in the Club", a collaboration with Gabbriette, is a dance-pop track. "Secretly" is a confession of a "crush" on a romantic partner to a friend. "I Used to Think I Was Smart" sees McRae on themes of "frustration, self-awareness, and the messy emotions that come with an unhealthy relationship". On "Hate Myself", McRae reiterates a lack of self-love, with feelings of self-criticism. "Phantom Limb" touches on "the fear of losing someone you once relied on". In the "atmospheric and contemplative" "Sorry, I'm Not Sorry", McRae takes accountability for why the relationship went wrong. On "I Don't Want to Break Up Anymore", McRae and her romantic partner both express desires to resolve the relationship. "Guilty Conscience", featuring Travis Scott, is a downtempo ballad about moving on from a past relationship. The album closes with "Call Me Back", which discusses the loneliness experienced from living a fast-paced lifestyle.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How (But I Found a Way) received generally positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an average score of 73 based on 5 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews". AllMusic rated the album 4 out of 5 stars. Rolling Stone, rating it 3.5 out of 5, commented that "it's still immersive in its pain, and there is a wistful, observant quality to the songwriting that feels like a wise pop star-in-waiting." Teen Vogue gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

I Don't Know How, but They Found Me (stylized in all lowercase) is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. It was preceded by the singles "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", and "Sports Car". The album debuted at number two on the Billboard 200.

== Background and promotion ==
McRae released her second studio album, Think Later, in December 2023. In an interview with Zane Lowe, McRae expressed she was "even more pumped" on the idea of releasing her third studio album, saying it would sonically represent "Pure fun, pure getting lost in a song."

On July 24, 2024, McRae announced that her third studio album would be released in March 2025 and that the lead single "It's Ok I'm Ok" would be released on September 12.

On September 4, 2024, McRae revealed the title of the album and announced that it would actually be released on February 7, 2025. She revealed that, the album was named after how she felt after a series of strange encounters and coincidences in her personal life, saying "I'd be like there's actually no way, like, I don't know how but they found me... and it was a common thought that kept happening." She clarified that "they" did not refer to anything (or anyone) specific.

== Singles ==
"It's Ok I'm Ok" was released as the lead single from the album on September 12, 2024. McRae first performed the song at the 2024 MTV Video Music Awards on September 11. It debuted at number 62 on the Billboard Hot 100. 

"2 Hands" was released as the second single on January 17, 2025.

"Sports Car" was released as the third single on January 24, 2025.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How, but They Found Me received acclaim from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from professional publications, the album received an average score of 83, based on seven reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".

AllMusic's Neil Z. Yeung gave it a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide."

response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

Thomas Hewitt Rees (April 17, 1875 – April 4, 1945) was a United States Army major general who served as Chief of the Militia Bureau and as Assistant Chief of Staff for Operations and Training (G-3). A native of Michigan and a graduate of the Michigan College of Mines (now Michigan Technological University), Rees joined the United States Army as an enlisted man in 1897. A veteran of the Spanish–American War and Philippine–American War, he was commissioned in 1899. Rees served in World War I as a staff officer and division commander. He was a pioneer in developing and promoting the army's Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC) program, and commanded the IX Corps Area from 1935 to 1939.

== Early life == 
Thomas Hewitt Rees was born in Houghton, Michigan on April 17, 1875, the son of John W. Rees and Eugenia (Livermore) Rees. Among his siblings was Thomas H. Rees, who also served as a US Army brigadier general. He was raised and educated in Houghton and was a graduate of Houghton High School. In 1895, he received the degrees of Bachelor of Science (B.S.) and Engineer of Mining (E.M.) from the Michigan College of Mines (now Michigan Technological University). He studied at Harvard University and New York Law School before deciding on a military career. On 7 May 1897, Rees enlisted in the United States Army, joining Company B of the Battalion of Engineers as a corporal. The Spanish–American War started in April 1898, and Rees performed duties associated with defense of strategically valuable waterways. In May 1898, Rees was one of eight soldiers who were run down by the French ocean liner SS La Touraine while they were laying mines in New York Harbor. The ship was putting out to sea, and did not stop or lower life boats, resulting in the drowning of two men. The other six, including Rees, were rescued. In November 1899, Rees was performing Philippine–American War Engineer duties in Malate, Philippines when he was notified that his application for a commission had been approved. He was appointed a second lieutenant of Infantry, effective 25 October 1899.

She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

Iridogorgia chewbacca
 Jump to navigationJump to search

Iridogorgia chewbacca is a deep-sea octocoral species within the genus Iridogorgia, named after the Star Wars character Chewbacca due to its shaggy, hair-like appearance. Discovered during submersible expeditions in the Pacific Ocean, it exemplifies deep-sea biodiversity in extreme environments at depths exceeding 2,000 meters. Its unique morphology and limited geographic distribution make it a subject of interest in marine biology and conservation.

== Naming ==

The species was named by marine biologists during a 2019 expedition led by NOAA's Office of Ocean Exploration and Research, inspired by the coral's resemblance to Chewbacca's fur. The Iridogorgia genus, established in 1891 by William Verrill, is noted for its iridescent colonies. The playful nomenclature reflects growing trends in taxonomy using pop culture to raise awareness of deep-sea ecosystems.

== Description ==

Iridogorgia chewbacca features a branching structure with polyps protruding densely along its limbs, creating a "fuzzy" texture. Colonies reach up to 1 meter in height, with flexible gorgonin skeletons allowing resilience against deep-sea currents. Coloration ranges from pale beige to golden brown, with iridescence under submersible lights. Its sclerites (calcium carbonate structures) exhibit spindle or rod shapes typical of Chrysogorgiidae. The coral lacks photosynthetic symbionts, relying on chemosynthesis or suspension feeding.

== Habitat and distribution ==

This species inhabits depths of 2,000–3,000 meters on seamounts and abyssal plains in the Pacific, including sites near the Mariana Trench and Hawaiian Islands. Substrates are rocky or sediment-covered, with temperatures of 2–4°C, high pressure, and minimal light. It coexists with sponges, crinoids, and other octocorals but remains sparsely documented, contributing to its rarity in surveys. Iridogorgia spans the Pacific and Atlantic, but I. chewbacca appears endemic to the western Pacific hotspot. Potential range extension awaits further ROV explorations in seamounts and trenches.

== Ecology ==

As a suspension feeder, I. chewbacca relies on polyps to capture plankton and organic detritus from deep currents. Its flexible branches maximize particle encounter in low-flow environments. Colonies host microbial communities and may shelter small invertebrates, though specific symbionts have not been studied. Growth is slow, potentially spanning centuries, as seen in related Iridogorgia species up to 500 years old. Reproduction likely involves fragmentation and spawning, typical of octocorals, but details for I. chewbacca are unspecified. It contributes to deep-sea biodiversity by stabilizing sediments and providing microhabitats.

== Conservation ==

Deep-sea corals (I. chewbacca) face threats from ocean acidification, warming, and deep-sea mining, which disrupt habitats. Its rarity and slow growth heighten vulnerability, though no specific IUCN status has been adopted. Protected areas like Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument encompass potential sites. Ongoing research emphasizes non-invasive surveys to monitor populations. The discovery underscores the need for expanded deep-sea conservation amid climate change.

== Cultural significance ==

The naming of I. chewbacca exemplifies pop culture's role in taxonomy, enhancing public engagement with science. Media coverage has boosted awareness of deep-sea biodiversity.

response_text: Iridogorgia chewbacca, or the Chewbacca coral, is a recently described species of bubblegum coral (Alcyonacea: Chrysogorgiidae: Iridogorgia) discovered in the western Pacific Ocean, particularly in the Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument near Johnston Atoll and the Mariana Trench. The name chewbacca was unofficially coined after its initial sighting resembled the Star Wars character Chewbacca due to its dense, fuzzy appearance, and was later confirmed by scientists as a distinct species. It represents one of many deep-sea species yet to be fully understood. == Taxonomy and etymology == The genus Iridogorgia (Verrill, 1883) consists of deep-water octocorals in the family Chrysogorgiidae, characterized by iridescent, spirally branched colonies. Iridogorgia chewbacca was formally described by scientist Greg Rouse and colleagues based on specimens collected via remotely operated vehicle (ROV) dives between 2015 and 2019 in the western Pacific. The holotype was obtained at a depth of approximately 2,270 meters at Johnston Atoll in 2018. The species epithet "chewbacca" was inspired by the shaggy appearance of its polyps, reminiscent of the fictional Wookiee character Chewbacca from Star Wars. The specific morphology of the polyps, which are densely packed along the branches, differentiates it from other Iridogorgia species. == Description == Iridogorgia chewbacca is identified by its tree-like, spirally coiled structure of branches formed of a rigid proteinaceous skeleton. Colonies can exceed one meter in height, with branches arranged in a helical pattern. The polyps are notably long and crowded, giving the colony a "furry" appearance. Coloration varies from pale yellow to orange-brown in live specimens. Like other chrysogorgiids, the skeleton exhibits metallic iridescence when illuminated, attributed to nanoscale structures in the axis. The polyps are non-retractile, extending from the branch surface. Sclerites (microscopic calcareous structures) include spindles and crosses, typical of Iridogorgia. Genetic analyses using mitochondrial and nuclear markers have confirmed its distinctness from congeners such as I. magnispiralis and I. splendens. == Distribution and habitat == Iridogorgia chewbacca is known from depths of 2,000 to 3,000 meters in the western Pacific, specifically recorded at the Musicians Seamounts, Johnston Atoll, and the Mariana Trench. These are remote, aphotic zones with near-freezing temperatures, high pressure, and low productivity. The substrate typically consists of manganese-crusted basalt rock or sediment. The limited dive coverage in such extreme environments likely explains the species' rarity in observations, rather than actual scarcity. The deep trenches and seamounts of the region are biodiversity hotspots for unique fauna. == Discovery and research == The discovery of I. chewbacca occurred during exploratory dives led by NOAA's Office of Ocean Exploration and Research, in collaboration with partners including the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and Scripps Institution of Oceanography. ROVs Deep Discoverer and Seirios captured the first images in 2015, showing the distinctive morphology. Subsequent expeditions in 2016, 2017, and 2018 allowed for sample collection and in-situ observations. The samples were analyzed using a combination of morphological examination, high-resolution microscopy, and molecular sequencing (mtMutS, 28S rDNA). The findings were published in peer-reviewed journals in 2020. The discovery highlighted the vast unknowns of deep-sea ecosystems and the importance of continued exploration, especially in protected marine areas. The coral's unique features have made it a subject of interest in biomimicry and materials science. == Biogeography and evolution == Phylogenetic analyses suggest Iridogorgia chewbacca diverged from other Pacific species within the last several million years, possibly during periods of ocean circulation changes in the Pliocene-Pleistocene. The genus Iridogorgia has a wide but patchy distribution across deep Atlantic and Pacific basins, indicating long-distance larval dispersal or vicariance events. The isolation of seamounts and trenches may drive speciation through limited gene flow. The high endemism of deep-sea corals in the western Pacific underscores the region's evolutionary significance. Comparisons with Atlantic Iridogorgia species show morphological convergence, complicating taxonomy. == Physiology and adaptations == Life at bathyal to abyssal depths requires specialized adaptations. Iridogorgia chewbacca's rigid, protein-based skeleton provides structural support against currents, while the helical branching maximizes surface area for feeding. The iridescence may play a role in light manipulation or predator deterrence, though its exact function remains speculative. The non-retractile polyps are an adaptation to the low-predation environment. Metabolic rates are likely low, consistent with the cold, energy-limited habitat. Symbiotic bacteria may assist in nutrient acquisition, as observed in other deep-sea corals, but this has not been confirmed for I. chewbacca. == Rarity and observation == Only a handful of I. chewbacca colonies have been observed due to the logistical challenges of deep-sea exploration. Growth is slow, potentially spanning centuries, as seen in related Iridogorgia species up to 500 years old. It contributes to deep-sea biodiversity by stabilizing sediments and providing microhabitats. == Conservation == Deep-sea corals (I. chewbacca) face threats from ocean acidification, warming, and deep-sea mining, which disrupt habitats. Its rarity and slow growth heighten vulnerability, though no specific IUCN status has been adopted. Protected areas like Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument encompass potential sites. response_text: Geolycosa nolotthensis is a species of spider in the family Lycosidae. It is found in Namibia and South Africa, and is commonly known as the arid Geolycosa wolf spider. == Distribution == Geolycosa nolotthensis is found in Namibia and the Northern Cape province of South Africa. In South Africa, it has been recorded from Kamaggas and Port Nolloth. == Habitat and ecology == This species is a free-running ground dweller sampled from the Succulent Karoo biome at an altitude of 231 m. == Description == Geolycosa nolotthensis is known from both sexes. The cephalothorax has a blackish eye field with washed-out yellowish submarginal bands that show four white hair spots when dry. It has a pale yellow, whitish hairy median band at front and rear that is tapered and spindle-shaped, showing two pale dark long streaks in front of the striae. The abdomen is dorsally blackish, with a median, pale hairy, black-trimmed lancet band in front. Behind this are four slightly dark median angular spots accompanied on each side by a row of four white hair spots visible only when dry. Ventrally, the sternum is uniformly black, with coxae lighter brown and remaining leg segments whitish hairy, though the posterior metatarsi and tarsi are darkened. == Conservation == The species remains undersampled with a limited known range. More sampling is needed to determine the full geographic range. == Etymology == The species is named after Port Nolloth in the Northern Cape, where the type specimen was collected. == References ==

response_text: GJ 1289 is a red dwarf star located approximately 27 light-years from the Sun in the constellation Andromeda. It is a single star of spectral class M4.5 V, with about 21% of the Sun's mass. The star hosts at least one confirmed exoplanet, GJ 1289 b, and is fully convective, making it a target for studying planetary formation around low-mass stars. Despite its slow rotation, GJ 1289 exhibits large-scale magnetic field strengths similar to those of faster-rotating M dwarfs, suggesting that the star operates a dynamo process in a regime distinct from more rapidly rotating stars. The star is predominantly poloidal with its magnetic topology varying over time, and their small-scale fields contribute more than 70% of the star's overall magnetic flux. == References ==

June & John is a 2025 French romantic musical fantasy film written and directed by Luc Besson.

== Premise ==
A young girl and boy meet and fall in love in Paris. They sing songs and have sex, until she accidentally becomes pregnant.

== Cast ==
* Chloé Jouannet as June
* Kacey Mottet Klein as John

== Production ==
The film was shot by Besson using just an iPhone, for under 5 million euros. The project originated from an interest in using new technological tools, and a recent exploration of a possible future for cinema incorporating such tools.

== Reception ==
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 40% of 5 critics' reviews are positive.

Christy Lemire of RogerEbert.com awarded the film one star out of four, writing, "Luc Besson's first feature in five years is an iPhone-shot, self-indulgent musical that's so shoddy it'll make you wonder what took him so long."

Marta Bałaga of Cineuropa gave the film two stars out of five, and wrote: "What really brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

response_text:
June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written, directed and produced by Luc Besson. It was released in France on 15 January 2025.

== Plot ==
At a party in the suburbs of Paris, June (Léa Léviant) and John (Raphaël Quenard) bump into each other; it's love at first sight. A few days later, June posts a message on Instagram to find him. John lives in a small Normandy town. They agree to meet at 8 a.m. on the Bir Hakeim bridge on January 1, 2025.

== Cast ==

== Production ==
The film was made in 37 days, in France. Besson wanted the film to look like an amateur film, with characters who self-film and show their daily life. The main visual inspiration of the feature film is TikTok. The film was shot with an iPhone 16 Pro Max, for budgetary reasons but also to test the limits of the device. Besson also used drones, Super 8 cameras, GoPro, digital single-lens reflex camera and reflex cameras. 
According to the filmmaker, two people were filming: one of them was often on roller skates or skateboards, and the second filmed the character's faces. Besson didn't use artificial intelligence and didn't plan the shots: "We didn't know what we were going to shoot. We invented as we went along. I wanted to find the feeling of a vacation film". Yann Arthus-Bertrand also took part in filming from a helicopter and was credited in the movie.

== Release ==
In France, June & John was released on 15 January 2025. It was Besson's biggest release in 15 years, with 340 theaters distributing the film.

== Reception ==
In France, June & John sold 50,798 tickets on its opening day in 340 theatres.

=== Critical reception ===
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 33% of 12 critics' reviews are positive.
Mathieu Macheret of Le Monde called the film "childish" and wrote, "Luc Besson is that director of the spectacular (Lucy, Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets), but also of the intimate (Léon, The Big Blue), who seems to have never quite integrated his own fame. Here he returns with a modest project, claimed as a return to the essence of cinema: an iPhone, spontaneous filming, a love story and two young unknown actors [...] But what really lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

Tokugawa Mikako (徳川美賀子, 15 April 1835 – 9 July 1894) was the wife of the 15th shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu. She is known posthumously as Seikan'in-no-miya (静寛院宮).

== Early life ==

Mikako was born in Kyoto, Japan in 1835. Her father was Imperial Prince Arisugawa Takahito (有栖川宮幟仁親王, Arisugawa-no-miya Takahito-shinnō), and her mother was his concubine Naka-no-Kimi (中君). This made Mikako Yoshinobu's second cousin once removed. She had six half-siblings from her father's marriage.
In 1848, Mikako was chosen to be a bride for the shōgunate and she married Tokugawa Iesada on January 27, 1853. They were married until his death in 1858.

== Marriage ==

Mikako was chosen by two priestesses of Ise Jingū to be married to Tokugawa Yoshinobu, and the couple married in July 1863, with the wedding being held at the Hōshō-ji temple in Kyoto, which is unusual for a couple of their status. She gave birth to ten sons and eleven daughters, however eight of them died young. She personally reared her daughter Tsune, teaching her poetry and other subjects. Her longevity is extraordinary considering that half of her children died young, and six of her sons who reached adulthood all dying young.
After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==

Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==

Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

Mikako Ichijō (一条 美賀子, Ichijō Mikako, May 11, 1835 – July 9, 1894), or formally Tenshō-in Mikako, was the formal wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate of Japan.

== Early life ==
Born in Kyoto on May 11, 1835, Mikako was the second daughter of Imperial ChiefMinister Tadaka Ichijō. In 1853, the clan attempted to arrange a marriage between her and Matsudaira Shungaku (head of the Echizen Domain), but in the end talks fell through. In June 1855, Mikako married Yoshinobu Tokugawa and the couple soon had four daughters, however they all died during childhood and infancy. In 1862, the Empress Eishō adopted Mikako as her adopted daughter. 

== Shōgunate years ==
All was well, even though the couple kept losing their children, with all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. response_text: Effingham Brown Sutton (April 17, 1817 – May 27, 1891) was an American shipping merchant and real-estate developer best known as an early builder in the area of Manhattan that later became known as Sutton Place. During the California Gold Rush, Sutton prospered not by mining but by operating ships serving the booming New York–San Francisco trade. == Career == Sutton was a shipping merchant who profited during the 1849 California Gold Rush, when American clipper ships rapidly expanded service to San Francisco. In 1875, Sutton built a row of brownstone houses between East 57th and 58th Streets along a formerly disconnected segment of Avenue A on Manhattan's East River. The area was later renamed Sutton Place (1883) and, in the 20th century, became a fashionable enclave following redevelopment by architects such as Mott B. Schmidt. == Properties == Beyond Manhattan, Sutton maintained a Long Island estate known as Effingham Park at West Islip. Photographs and genealogical materials relating to the estate are preserved in the Richard C. Sutton papers at the New York Public Library. == Death and legacy == Sutton died in 1891. In 1997, New York City renamed a series of vest-pocket parks along the East River between 53rd and 59th Streets as "Sutton Place Park" in his honor, reflecting his role in the area's 19th-century development. == References == == Further reading == Christopher Collora, Long Island Historic Houses of the South Shore — includes discussion of Effingham Park in West Islip.

Dogman is a 2023 drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Caleb Landry Jones, Jojo T. Gibbs, Grace Palma, and Clemens Schick.

The film had its world premiere at the 80th Venice International Film Festival in competition on 7 September 2023, where it received an eight-minute standing ovation. Dogman has received generally mixed reviews from film critics, who praised Jones' performance but criticised the film's "incoherence" and lack of narrative originality.

Plot

Douglas Munrow is a young man who can communicate with dogs. After suffering years of abuse at the hands of his father, he finds refuge in a dog shelter, and eventually ends up living in the forests surrounding the New Jersey countryside with a pack of dogs. One day, he robs a cashier at a gas station with the dogs' help before going on the run and later developing a drag persona. After pulling off a series of heists, Douglas is eventually caught and sent to prison.

Production

In September 2020, it was reported that Caleb Landry Jones was set to star in the film. In August 2021, Jojo T. Gibbs was cast in the film. Filming began on September 13, 2021 in New Jersey, with Thierry Arbogast serving as cinematographer.

Besson has stated that the film was shot on an iPhone, and that the decision to do so was made partly in response to working conditions during the Covid-19 lockdowns and his belief that filmmaking had become too expensive.

Release

The film was released in France on September 27, 2023, and in the United States on March 22, 2024. It was released in the United Kingdom and Ireland on March 29, 2024. It was released in Canada on May 3, 2024.

Reception

Rotten Tomatoes reported that 57% of critics gave the film a positive review based on 84 reviews, with an average rating of 5.8/10. The website's consensus reads: "A star-making turn from Caleb Landry Jones makes Dogman worth a look despite Luc Besson's overly busy direction." According to Metacritic, which sampled 23 critics and calculated a weighted average score of 53 out of 100, the film received "mixed or average reviews".

Screen International's Fionnuala Halligan praised the film as "ludicrously watchable", but criticized it for being "narratively overstuffed", and compared its script to a patchwork of ideas from different Besson films. Peter Debruge of Variety wrote that Besson "pulls together a decade's worth of unused ideas for a deranged psychodrama about a crossdressing criminal, played by Caleb Landry Jones." Siddhant Adlakha of IndieWire gave the film a grade of C+, writing: "In a story this lurid, which begins with its protagonist being interrogated by cops for murder, it's hardly a spoiler to say the dogs live, but the lack of threat to their lives robs the film of what little suspense it could've managed, stretching its thin characterization past its breaking point." Matthew Monagle of Film School Rejects wrote, "But the film relies so heavily upon Jones (who is excellent) to tie the story together, and it is so bloated with side narratives of varying importance, that the tragedy of his character is an afterthought."

Writing for Le Monde, reviewer Jacques Mandelbaum gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing: "Besson seems to have lost all awareness of ridicule, to the point where one wonders if it's because of an absolute naïveté or a phenomenal self-assurance. [...] The result is, it must be said, heart-rending: there's something extremely moving about witnessing the shipwreck of such innocence, of such an inability to understand reality, and of such a stubborn attempt to believe in the depth of this simple endeavor. [...] While the comedy and magical realism justify some concessions to naturalism, several interactions border on the ridiculous, thanks to the sepulchral conviction of this imagery, typical of newsstand self-help." A review on the French website Télérama reads, "For nearly a quarter of a century, Luc Besson has sunk into the abyss dear to his little, frustrated free-diver's heart. With each film, he sinks deeper into mediocrity, searching for a second wind that never comes. It's not with this unworthy photocopied romance that he'll resurface, alas. Shot on an iPhone in 2020 in a Los Angeles then in full lockdown, this 'content' (to call it a film would be too much of an honor) resembles yet another aftereffect of the Covid epidemic. How can we imagine, in fact, that its director wasn't himself feverish, at the end of his rope and out of ideas, to dream up such a dud?" Reviewer Christos Bakatselos of the website flix.gr gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "Luc Besson, always a lover of images and dreamy romance, decides this time to cross over to the other side of formalism, shooting the film entirely on a mobile phone. A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs

The 2025–26 Boston Fleet season is the second season for the Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL) franchise in Boston, Massachusetts. The Fleet are coming off a 5th place finish in the inaugural 2024 PWHL season and did not qualify for the playoffs.

== Off–season ==

=== 2025 PWHL Draft ===

The Fleet held the 6th overall selection in the 2025 PWHL Draft, held on June 10, 2025, at the Verdun Auditorium in Montreal, Quebec. The Fleet selected defenseman Julia Gosling with the 6th overall pick.

=== Expansion Draft ===

On June 27, 2025, the PWHL held an expansion draft for its two new franchises, Seattle and Vancouver. Each existing team could protect 12 players (nine skaters and one goalie who are signed for the 2025–26 season, and two additional players who have been tendered a qualifying offer). The Fleet lost forward Taylor Girard to Seattle and forward Lexie Adzija to Vancouver.

=== Staff changes ===

On September 4, 2025, the Fleet announced the firing of head coach Courtney Kessel and general manager Danielle Marmer. On September 25, 2025, the Fleet named former NHL player Ryan Carter as general manager. On October 7, 2025, the Fleet announced the hiring of Mike Vellucci as head coach. Vellucci was most recently an assistant coach for the NHL's Anaheim Ducks. On October 15, 2025, the Fleet announced the hiring of Jordan Lavallée Smotherman, Derek Whitmore, and Kacey Bellamy to the coaching staff. Smotherman served as head coach of HC Innsbruck during the 2024–25 ICE Hockey League season. Whitmore most recently served as an assistant coach for the Chicago Steel of the USHL. Bellamy is an Olympic gold medallist and eight–time IIHF World Women's Championship gold medallist who served as a scout and player liaison during the 2022–23 PHF season.

Dogman had its world premiere at the 79th Venice International Film Festival on September 6, 2023. It was released in France on September 13, 2023, by ARP Sélection, and in Belgium on the same day by O'Brother Distribution. It screened at the 2023 Toronto International Film Festival. It was released in the United States on March 22, 2024, by Briarcliff Entertainment.

== Reception ==

=== Box office ===

Dogman opened in two theaters and grossed $16,638 in its opening weekend, a per-screen average of $8,319. The following weekend, it made $24,975 from 11 theaters.

=== Critical response ===

On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 43% of 76 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.1/10. The website's consensus reads: "Dogman has the potential to bite, but Luc Besson's self-indulgent direction keeps this story too securely on a leash." response_text:
DogMan is a 2023 superhero film written, produced and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Caleb Landry Jones as Doug, a man who was abused as a child and now lives with several dogs in a warehouse, where he stages a musical act with them. The film had its world premiere at the 80th Venice International Film Festival on September 7, 2023.

Cast
Caleb Landry Jones as Doug
Jojo T. Gibbs as Evelyn
Christopher Denham as Wenders
Grace Palma as young Evelyn
Clemens Schick as Moser
Michael Garza as Mota
Marisa Berenson as Vivian
Adam Zambryzcki as young Doug

Plot
In Los Angeles, a drag queen named Doug lives with a pack of dogs in a warehouse overlooking a river. Along with his dogs, he puts on an act at a small local theater, where he wears high heels and dresses and directs the dogs through various tricks and performances. Years prior, as a child, Doug's father would regularly abuse him, locking him in a kennel with the family dog, Ralphie. The only person who showed young Doug affection was Vivian, the wife of his abusive father. Doug eventually killed his father by pushing his wheelchair into the river. He was sent to prison but released after a short while. After his release, he began rescuing dogs and formed his act with them. Suffering from PTSD from the abuse, Doug speaks with a psychiatrist named Evelyn. She is initially skeptical, but eventually comes to believe in Doug's abilities to communicate with dogs and attempts to enlist his help in solving various crimes in the city as a form of vigilantism. Meanwhile, a local mobster named Moser has been consolidating his power in the city. To deter any competing gangs, he enacts an indiscriminate reign of terror on the people of the city, which includes massacring a group of immigrants in a restaurant and beating a local priest to death in the streets. Doug eventually comes into conflict with Moser after Moser threatens Evelyn, prompting Doug to confront him at a party aboard a yacht. Using his dog companions, Doug intimidates the gangster, who agrees to leave the city permanently. At the end of the film, Doug performs his musical act one final time before leaving the city with his dogs.

Production
By April 15, 2020, Luc Besson, having been homebound during the COVID-19 pandemic, wrote a script for DogMan. In May 2020, Luc Besson shot the film in Los Angeles using an iPhone and a skeleton crew of four people because of the lockdowns. In a statement, Besson said: "This is the first time in 25 years I am shooting a film without a director of photography. I don't do it by choice, but I am forced because of the lockdown. I shoot it, I frame, I direct. I have four people with me including myself. My producers said, 'This is a nightmare, you're going to shoot yourself in the foot.' But you know, the film I love most I shot like this in the 1980s, Le dernier combat." Speaking about his decision to shoot the film using a smartphone, Besson said, "It's like changing your wife for a mistress. You can do things you're not supposed to do."

Critical reception
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 52% of 46 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.2/10. The website's consensus reads: "An admirable showcase for Caleb Landry Jones' chameleonic gifts as a performer, DogMan is held back by a derivative story and the eccentricities of writer-director Luc Besson's vision." Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 48 out of 100, based on 15 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

Variety's Owen Gleiberman wrote, "DogMan is pure sincerity kitsch, but when a filmmaker believes in something this much, it makes you want to believe it too. Caleb Landry Jones, with his milky skin and wispy ginger hair, captures Doug's saintly psychosis; he's like a more drawn Malcolm McDowell. His performance has a swirling intensity, and it's precisely Doug's inner swirl that Besson is staking everything on. With a lesser actor, I'm not sure this film would have worked."

In a review for Le Monde, film critic Clarisse Fabre wrote, "The director of The Big Blue is filming in a minor mode. response_text: Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids. == Preparation and reactions == Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid: HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide. Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex. Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate: Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2 == Structure == The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions. == Applications == Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines. == References ==

response_text: Camptoceras terebra Camptoceras terebra is a species of small freshwater snail, an aquatic gastropod mollusc in the family Planorbidae, commonly known as the ram's horn snails. It is characterized by its coiled, sinistral (left-handed) shell and its association with slow-moving or stagnant freshwater habitats. == Taxonomy == Camptoceras terebra was described by William Henry Benson in 1843. It is the type species for the genus Camptoceras. This species has no taxonomic synonyms. One source classifies the Japanese species Camptoceras hirasei as a subspecies of C. terebra (Camptoceras terebra hirasei). One syntype (specimen used in Benson's original description) is in the collections of the Natural History Museum of London. == Description == The shell of Camptoceras terebra is long and skinny, with a height of about 6 to 7 mm (0.24 to 0.28 in) and a diameter of about 3 mm (0.12 in). At maximum, the shell may reach about 9 mm (0.35 in) in height. The shell opening, called the aperture, is about 4 mm (0.16 in) in the largest dimension. The revolutions of the shell, called whorls, curl to the left in a condition known as sinistry. The whorls are few in number and are not fused. A sculpture (3-dimensional protrusions of the shell) may be present in the form of varices. These varices are projections of the edge of the aperture at different points in the animal's life, and look similar to those found in the unrelated genus Epitonium. The sculpture does not include spiral striae. This species possesses proportionally large eyes relative to its body,

response_text: Signe Torborg Schmidt-Nielsen (née Sturtzen-Becker, 1 December 1878 – 1959) was a Swedish-Norwegian physicist and nutritionist. She was the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. == Family == Signe Torborg Sturtzen-Becker was born on 1 December 1878 in Stockholm. Her parents were Vilhelm Teodor Patrik Sturzen-Becker (1841–1910), the son of Swedish poet Oscar Patric Sturzen-Becker, and Astrid Sturzen-Becker (née Paykull, 1848–1908). Sturtzen-Becker married chemist Sigval Schmidt-Nielsen [no, sv] in 1907 in Stockholm. They had four children, including the physiologist Knut Schmidt-Nielsen (1915–2007), who emigrated to America and worked at Duke University. == Career == Schmidt-Nielsen studied for her PhD in physics at Stockholm University and was one of the first women in Sweden to receive a doctoral degree when she graduated in 1907. She was also the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. Schmidt-Nielsen collaborated with her husband in natural science research and publications, including into the rennet of calves and the vitamin content of herrings. == Death == Schmidt-Nielsen died in 1959 in Stockholm. She was buried at Domkirkegården, Trondheim, Norway. == References ==

Named after the Star Wars character Chewbacca due to its long, flexible, "hairy" branches that evoke the Wookiee's fur, the species was formally described in 2025. It inhabits rocky seafloors in the tropical western Pacific Ocean at depths exceeding 400 meters, where it forms solitary colonies up to 1.2 meters tall. == Description == Iridogorgia chewbacca features a monopodial, spiral axis typical of its genus, with a brilliant iridescence that gives it a shimmering appearance under light. The colony grows upright and solitary, reaching heights of ~1.2 meters (4 feet) in specimens from near Molokaʻi, Hawaii, while those near the Mariana Trench measure around 50 cm (20 inches). Its branches are long and flexible, stretching up to 38 cm (15 inches), hanging downward in a "shaggy" manner that resembles hair, distinguishing it from stiffer-branched relatives. The polyps, numbering thousands per colony, extend tentacles for filter-feeding and give the branches a fuzzy texture when active. Unlike many corals that form dense reefs, I. chewbacca occurs scattered and alone on hard substrates, with its shiny, iridescent surface reflecting light in patterns akin to "fireworks exploding from the seafloor". Genetic markers, including mtMutS-cox1 and 28S rDNA, confirm its distinction from congeners, though mtMutS showed limited utility for delimitation within the genus. Spiral growth direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) does not serve as a reliable taxonomic trait. == Taxonomy == Iridogorgia chewbacca belongs to the genus Iridogorgia, in the family Chrysogorgiidae, order Malacalcyonacea, class Octocorallia, phylum Cnidaria. response_text:
I Don't Know How to Smile Anymore is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on March 14, 2025, through RCA Records. It is the follow-up to her sophomore album, Think Later (2023). The album was preceded by the singles "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", "Sports Car", "All My Friends Are Falling in Love", and "Perfume". It received generally positive reviews from music critics.

== Background and release ==
The album's title, I Don't Know How to Smile Anymore, came to McRae when she arrived in the studio for a songwriting session. She told V Magazine, "I had such a heavy heart. It was the end of the tour, and I walked into a session, and someone was like, 'How are you?' and I was like, 'I don't know how to smile anymore.' I was just so exhausted, not only physically, but mentally."

McRae announced the album on January 8, 2025, alongside a pre-order and the release of the single "2 Hands". While announcing the album, she stated: "I think this album speaks to anybody that feels lonely, anybody that's going through a quarter-life crisis, like self-reflection, and is making decisions that they probably should not. It's the most honest I've ever been in an album. It's the most raw. I really think it speaks to being in your 20s and literally navigating your entire world from scratch." She has also described it as "kind of a coming-of-age for me", citing how she is "doing more storytelling than ever in these songs."

On March 4, 2025, McRae held an exclusive album release event in Los Angeles. Then, she partook in a career spanning Audacy Beach Festival performance in Fort Lauderdale, Florida on March 8, 2025. On March 9, 2025, she appeared on NBC's The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon to perform the album's title track. She is set to embark on the Miss Possessive Tour in promotion of I Don't Know How to Smile Anymore in summer 2025.

== Critical reception ==
According to the review aggregator Metacritic, I Don't Know How to Smile Anymore received "generally favorable reviews" based on a weighted average score of 79 out of 100 from 7 critic scores. Aggregator AnyDecentMusic? gave it 7.3 out of 10, based on their assessment of the critical consensus.

Upon release, the album received widespread critical acclaim from critics. DIY rated the album five-out-of-five stars, praising the album as "a thrilling emotional bungee jump". Writing for NME, which also gave it a five-star rating, Thomas Smith praised the "masterful restraint displayed in the production", comparing the album to "the intimacy of Billie Eilish's Grammy-winner debut." Rolling Stone gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How Finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide."

Robert Irwin Rees (9 November 1871 – 23 November 1936) was a career officer in the United States Army. During World War I, he served as the U.S. Army's chief signal officer, and he attained the rank of brigadier general. After his military retirement, he held important posts in the private sector.

== Career == Rees attained the rank of sergeant major in the Battalion of Engineers before receiving an officer's commission in 1901. He was a lieutenant colonel and signal officer for the American Expeditionary Force during World War I. After the Armistice of 11 November 1918, Rees became a brigadier general and oversaw construction of needed telephone and telegraph lines in Europe. He also managed the AEF's Educational Division, which enabled soldiers to attend schools before returning to the United States after the war. Following his return to the United States, Rees was head of the War Department's Education and Recreation Branch and served as the U.S. veterans' bureau's assistant director for vocational rehabilitation. Rees left the army in 1924 and became assistant vice president for personnel and public relations with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. In November 1936, Rees tendered his resignation as of 1 December so he could accept a position with the American Engineers' Council for Professional Development. He experienced a cerebral hemorrhage while in Detroit on 18 November. he died in a Detroit hospital on 23 November and was buried at Arlington National Cemetery. == Early life == Robert Irwin Rees was born in Houghton, Michigan on 9 November 1871, a son of Seth Rees and Eugenia (Livermore) Rees. Among his siblings was Thomas H. Rees, who also served as a US Army brigadier general. He was raised and educated in Houghton and was a graduate of Houghton High School. In 1895, he received the degrees of Bachelor of Science (B.S.) and Engineer of Mining (E.M.) from the Michigan College of Mines (now Michigan Technological University). He studied at Harvard University and New York Law School before deciding on a military career. On 7 May 1897, Rees enlisted in the United States Army, joining Company B of the Battalion of Engineers as a corporal. response_text:
DogMan is a 2023 musical semi-autobiographical drama film directed and written by Luc Besson. The film was shot entirely on an iPhone and was conceived, shot, and edited during the Covid-19 pandemic.

The film had its world premiere at the 80th Venice International Film Festival on September 7, 2023, where it competed for the Golden Lion. It was released in France by ARP Sélection on 24 January 2024.

It garnered mixed reviews from critics.

== Plot ==

Doug is a feeble young boy who often falls victim to bullying by a violent gang of older boys in a rural mining town. Seeking solace, he finds a new companion in the form of a stray dog that follows him home. Despite her initial reluctance, his mother eventually agrees to let Doug keep the dog and they name him "Baby Dog".

One day, two of Doug's tormentors, Rocco and Paul, throw Baby Dog into a dumpster and hang the boy from a branch with a rope tied around his neck. Doug survives the encounter, but Baby Dog is killed by a passing garbage truck. The loss of his dog brings Doug to an emotional breakdown, causing him to run away from home.

Doug finds himself at a derelict shipyard and discovers a small colony of feral dogs. He settles in an abandoned boat and manages to befriend the dogs, making his own pack which protects him. They live happily for many years until they're discovered by the authorities. They capture Doug and send him to a juvenile detention center while the dogs are rounded up and taken to a pound.

While the staff look for Doug's mother, he becomes the victim of abuse from the violent youth of the institution and a transgender person named Marlene. Just when he reaches his breaking point, an inmate named Marco offers him help. He tells Doug to stay strong, offering him valuable life lessons and forming a friendship with the boy. One night, Marco is subjected to a very brutal attack. After Marco dies from his injuries, Doug is left to his own devices. He seeks revenge against his abusers, putting all of them in hospital. Shortly thereafter, Doug is transferred to a psychiatric hospital, where he stays until he is deemed fully functional. Reunited with his mother, now wheelchair-bound after suffering a severe car accident, Doug takes care of her. He returns to see the feral dogs only to discover that they have been put down because nobody wanted to adopt them.

Now grown-up, Doug begins working in a theater as an assistant director. During the staging of a play about drag queens, he meets Evelyn, an actress in the show. They fall in love and marry. Doug and Evelyn go into business together when they adopt several dogs from a pound and begin training them to perform in an act. They successfully perform in many cities and eventually land a bigger gig in Las Vegas, where they make a good living.

Their good fortune ends when Rocco and Paul are released from prison and meet Doug, not recognizing him. They approach him and ask for money. When they are about to turn violent, Doug decides to introduce them to his pack and commands them to attack Rocco. They maul him and he is left to die. When Doug reveals to Paul that he knew them from childhood, Paul is shocked to learn Doug's identity. Wanting retribution for his dead friend, Paul kills Evelyn with a handgun. Doug's dogs retaliate by killing him, but it is too late to save Evelyn. Her death devastates Doug.

Some years later, Doug copes with his grief by opening his own theater and training dogs. He performs a touching show about his wife which attracts plenty of attention, including that of a disabled woman named Lily, who slowly begins to know him and his dogs. In a conversation with Doug, Lily tells him about her past. She describes an abusive relationship she endured with a boyfriend in her past who physically harmed her resulting in her paralysis and severe scars. The boyfriend was sentenced to prison. When he was released, she adopted two of Doug's dogs to protect her. Doug's friend, Noah, warns him not to trust Lily, but Doug ignores him.

Shortly after, Lily reveals that Doug's dogs killed her boyfriend after she sent them to attack him. A shocked Doug visits the scene and finds the body, which Lily has not disposed of. He manages to stage the body to make it look like suicide and the police never suspect the truth.

== Cast ==

* Caleb Landry Jones as Doug
* Jojo T. Gibbs as Evelyn
* Christopher Denham as Noah
* Clemens Schick as Marco
* Grace Palma as Lily
* Marisa Berenson as Audrey
* Adam Shapiro as Paul

== Production ==

Besson shot the film entirely on an iPhone during the Covid-19 pandemic, using only those who had been quarantining with him as his cast and crew.

== Release ==

The film had its world premiere at the 80th Venice International Film Festival on September 7, 2023, where it competed for the Golden Lion. It was released in France by ARP Sélection on 24 January 2024.

== Reception ==

=== Critical response ===

On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 52% of 23 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 6.1/10.

Philip Concannon of the website Vodzilla.co called the film "a fascinating mess". The review reads, "At times, DogMan looks like the best film that Luc Besson has made in years. At other times, it looks like one of the worst. It's a little bit of both, and that's what makes it such a fascinating mess. [...] Where this film stands among Besson's body of work will be a matter for debate, but one thing is certain: DogMan is like nothing he has ever done before."

David Rooney of The Hollywood Reporter called the film "Besson's most eccentric movie to date", writing: "Whether you respond to the movie's wild Grimm's Fairy Tale archness or find it risible and overwrought, this is Besson going for broke. [...] No explanation is provided for Doug's chameleon ability with animals, but as he tells Lily toward the end: 'Hurt people understand each other.' The film's magic-realist take on interspecies communication and connection makes that line sing with melancholy beauty, or alternately, prompts viewers to roll their eyes."

A mostly negative review on the French website Critikat states, "One would have to believe in the depth of this simple endeavor. [...] While the comedy and magical realism justify some concessions to naturalism, several interactions border on the ridiculous, thanks to the sepulchral conviction of this imagery, typical of newsstand self-help."

A review on the French website Télérama reads, "For nearly a quarter of a century, Luc Besson has sunk into the abyss dear to his little, frustrated free-diver's heart. With each film, he sinks deeper into mediocrity, searching for a second wind that never comes. It's not with this unworthy photocopied romance that he'll resurface, alas. Shot on an iPhone in 2020 in a Los Angeles then in full lockdown, this 'content' (to call it a film would be too much of an honor) resembles yet another aftereffect of the Covid epidemic. How can we imagine, in fact, that its director wasn't himself feverish, at the end of his rope and out of ideas, to dream up such a dud?"

Reviewer Christos Bakatselos of the website flix.gr gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "Luc Besson, always a lover of images and dreamy romance, decides this time to cross over to the other side of formalism, shooting the film entirely on a mobile phone. A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs

I Don't Know How But They Found Me is the upcoming second studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, scheduled for release on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. The album was preceded by the release of five singles: "It's ok I'm ok", "2 Hands", "Sports Car" with Tyga, "Like the Movies" and "I'm Sorry".

== Background ==
On December 9, 2022, McRae released her debut studio album, Think Later. The album debuted at number four on the US Billboard 200 and number one on the UK Albums Chart, with it being her first album to chart in the United Kingdom and containing the international hit single "Greedy". Due to the album's success, an extended version was issued on December 8, 2023, adding five additional tracks including her collaboration with The Kid Laroi, "Think Later". Following the release of the extended edition, McRae announced the Think Later World Tour, scheduled to commence in March 2024.

McRae began teasing her second studio album on June 21, 2024, by posting several videos on her social media accounts showing her in the recording studio. The first single from I Don't Know How But They Found Me, titled "It's ok I'm ok", was released on September 12, 2024. The song peaked at number 11 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming her second top-20 hit in the United States. The album's second single, "2 Hands", was released on November 14, 2024, and peaked at number 65 on the Billboard Hot 100. On December 6, 2024, McRae officially announced the album, revealing its title, release date, and tracklist. The album's third single, "Sports Car", featuring Tyga, was released on December 6, 2024.

== Composition ==
I Don't Know How But They Found Me is described as a pop album that explores themes of heartbreak, self-discovery, and personal growth. In an interview with Billboard, McRae stated that the album is "a reflection of the past two years of my life" and that it represents "a more mature and vulnerable side" of her artistry. The album features production from various producers, including Ryan Tedder, Greg Kurstin, and Jasper Harris.

== Singles ==
"It's ok I'm ok" was released as the lead single from the album on September 12, 2024. The song was written by McRae alongside Jasper Harris and Ryan Tedder, with production handled by Tedder and Harris. The music video for the song was directed by Sean Price Williams and features McRae performing choreography in various locations throughout New York City.

"2 Hands" was released as the album's second single on November 14, 2024. The song was written by McRae, Greg Kurstin, and Sarah Aarons, with production by Kurstin. The music video, directed by Aidan Cullen, features McRae in a series of intimate, dimly lit settings.

"Sports Car", featuring Tyga, was released as the third single on December 6, 2024. The collaboration marks McRae's first feature with a hip-hop artist on one of her singles.

"Like the Movies" was released as the fourth single on January 10, 2025.

"I'm Sorry" was released as the fifth single on January 24, 2025.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How But They Found Me received generally positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from professional publications, the album received an average score of 78, based on 15 reviews.

AllMusic's Timothy Monger gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide."

response_text:
Lecidea chiangraiensis is a species of saxicolous (rock-dwelling), crustose lichen in the family Lecideaceae. Found in Thailand, it was formally described as a new species in 2014 by Kawinnat Buaruang, Damkerng Thongklang, Ekaphan Kraichak, Khwanruan Papong, Sittiporn Parnmen and Helge Thorsten Lumbsch. The type specimen was collected by the first author from near the summit of Doi Tung (Chiang Rai Province, Mae Fa Luang District) at an altitude of 1,806 m (5,925 ft); here, in mixed deciduous forest, it was found growing on dry granite rock. The specific epithet refers to the type locality.

The lichen has an areolate, whitish-grey thallus with a black prothallus; the areolae are flat and scattered. Apothecia are 0.4–0.9 mm in diameter, black and persistently plane to slightly convex, with a margin. The proper exciple is 40–90 μm wide, greenish-brown to brown, with a K+ reaction. There are few hydrophobic granules that dissolve in KOH without a distinct colour reaction. The subhymenium is about 10 μm high and olive-brown, the epihymenium about 25 μm and dark brown, the hymenium 75–100 μm and hyaline, and the hypothecium 100–170 μm and blackish-brown, with a K– reaction. Asci measure 65–80 × 10–15 μm. Ascospores number 6–8 (occasionally as few as 4) per ascus, are colourless, ellipsoid, non-septate and halonate, 10–13 (more rarely up to 17) × 6–8 μm with an approximately 1-μm halo. Reported chemistry includes atranorin (major) with several as-yet unidentified lichen substances (minor).

== Habitat and distribution ==

Known from northern Thailand, the species grows on tree bark in evergreen montane forest near the Doi Mon Larn–Mae Kampong area east-south-east of Chiang Mai, where the canopy is dominated by Lithocarpus, Quercus and Castanopsis.

Buellia dorothea is a species of lichen in the family Caliciaceae. It was formally described as a new species by the lichenologist André Aptroot in 2009. The type specimen was collected by the author at an elevation of 1,280 m (4,200 ft), in an area dominated by the trees Lithocarpus, Castanopsis, and Quercus. It is known to occur only from the type locality. The species epithet dorothea honours Dorothy Hawksworth, wife of British lichenologist David Hawksworth.

== Description ==

Buellia dorothea is characterized by a well-developed grey thallus measuring 70–100 μm in thickness. Its distinct photobiont algae forms a 30-μm-thick, non-continuous layer. This thallus exhibits a somewhat warted or rugose surface texture. Particularly notable features include the arrangement of its algal cells, which can appear elongated within a gel matrix, forming what resembles hyphal bundles up to 20 μm in diameter.

The thallus measures 0.1–0.3 mm in diameter (individual specimen), with an uneven and somewhat warted to cracked surface. The apothecia (fruiting bodies) are relatively small, measuring 0.2–0.4 mm in diameter, and are immersed to semi-immersed in the thallus. These structures feature a concave to flat black disc, surrounded by a prominent 50-μm-thick, persistent thalline margin that matches the grey color of the main thallus. The apothecia are characterized by having a comparatively simple internal structure. The excipulum (the outer wall of the apothecium) is uniformly brown and about 50 μm thick, with few hydrophobic granules that dissolve in KOH without a distinct colour reaction. The subhymenium is about 10 μm high and olive-brown, the epihymenium about 25 μm and dark brown, the hymenium 75–100 μm and hyaline, and the hypothecium 100–170 μm and blackish-brown, with a K– reaction.

Asci measure 65–80 × 10–15 μm. Ascospores number 6–8 (occasionally as few as 4) per ascus, are colourless, ellipsoid, non-septate and halonate, 10–13 (more rarely up to 17) × 6–8 μm with an approximately 1-μm halo.

Reported chemistry includes atranorin (major) with several as-yet unidentified lichen substances (minor).

== Habitat and distribution ==

Known from northern Thailand, the species grows on tree bark in evergreen montane forest near the Doi Mon Larn–Mae Kampong area east-south-east of Chiang Mai, where the canopy is dominated by Lithocarpus, Quercus and Castanopsis.
