June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson and shot entirely on a mobile phone. The film stars Sophie Wilde and Édouard Michelon as the titular characters and follows their romance during a two-month summer trip. It premiered at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on 13 February 2025.

Plot
On June 21, while traveling by train to Istanbul, John, a Frenchman, sees June, an American, and immediately falls in love with her. He approaches her at a Vienna train station, and they spend the rest of the day together exploring the city. They wander through various locations and develop a connection.

As June is set to fly back to the United States the following day and John to France, the couple is faced with the decision to continue their relationship.

Cast

Production
On 15 January 2025, it was announced Luc Besson wrote and directed a new romantic film titled June & John, shot entirely on a mobile phone. The film was produced by Besson's EuropaCorp in association with TF1 Films Production and it was financed by Netflix. The film stars Sophie Wilde and Édouard Michelon in the lead roles.

Sophie Wilde described it as "a really intimate love story", saying: "It really is their story, it's a two-hander, it's on their iPhone, so they're kind of capturing their own story, and it was a really special way of working." She also said "It was a really long schedule, it was two months of shooting, but we shot it in such a beautiful way. We were in Paris, in Vienna, Istanbul, Athens and Santorini and at the end we shot a little bit in New York City and so it was really special.".

Release
June & John had its world premiere at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on 13 February 2025. It was released in France on 19 February 2025 by SND, and will be released by Netflix worldwide on 28 March 2025.

Reception
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 17% of 6 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 3.6/10.

Aurélien Allin of Première gave the film a rating of 1 out of 5 stars, writing, "But very quickly, the evidence becomes painfully obvious: June & John is above all proof that the smartphone is unfortunately not for everyone. And that Luc Besson's fall continues inexorably. [...] The whole thing never stops looking like an unbearable Instagram story, despite its very long 105 minutes. And, what's more, from influencers who have just discovered life." Christophe Caron of CinemaTeaser gave the film a rating of 1 out of 5 stars, writing, "We can understand that the director, who fell from his pedestal with the Sand Van Roy affair, wanted to remake his image with a candid film, imbued with a contemporary romanticism nourished by social networks and their diktats. But this approach is unsuitable for cinema which, admittedly, has the right to be inspired by modern tools, but not to follow them when they are based only on marketing, demagogy and imposture." Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter wrote, "To watch June & John is to relive the pandemic-era sensation of being stuck on a seemingly endless Zoom call, the people on the other end of which you not only don't know but could also care less about." Mintzer concludes, "Whereas Before Sunrise had its characters falling for each other over the course of several engaging conversations about life, love and everything in between, June & John shows them bonding over TikTok-ready dance moves, zip-lining and para-sailing excursions, and lots of French kissing, while Wilde and Michelon are given barely anything to do other than play at being happy, sometimes documenting themselves as if they were influencers showing off to their social media followers (if only the film had actually gone in that direction, it might have had more to say)."

Mathieu Macheret of Le Monde wrote, "The man who made his debut in the cinema at the end of the 1970s with a short shot in 16 mm (L'Avant dernier, 1981) could, forty-five years later, have used the economic and narrative constraints of the means at his disposal to tell something else, a more constrained, more realistic story, drawing on the period that had just passed to attempt this realism. We would have forgiven him for the erraticism of a film that did not necessarily need to find its audience, since it is financially supported by Netflix. But June & John wants to be a major popular film, released first in cinemas and then on the platform, even though its subject and its treatment are those of a minor film, unworthy of such a release and more made to get lost in a catalog. Unless we see it as an involuntary allegory of the Covid epidemic. How can we imagine, in fact, that its director wasn't himself feverish, at the end of his rope and out of ideas, to dream up such a dud?" Reviewer Christos Bakatselos of the website flix.gr gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "Luc Besson, always a lover of images and dreamy romance, decides this time to cross over to the other side of formalism, shooting the film entirely on a mobile phone. A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. Thomas Wilberforce Rees (9 August 1871 – 6 July 1945) was a United States Army brigadier general who was a recipient of the Medal of Honor for valor in combat in 1899 during the Philippine–American War. A native of Michigan, Rees enlisted in the United States Army in 1897 and received a commission in 1899 after completing a competitive examination. He was a veteran of the Spanish–American War and Philippine–American War, took part in the United States occupation of Veracruz, and commanded the 28th Infantry Regiment on the Western Front during World War I. In September 1918, Rees received command of the 58th Infantry Brigade, which he led for the remainder of the war. After the war he commanded the 2nd Infantry Brigade in the Philippines and the Harbor Defenses of Baltimore. He retired in 1935, and was advanced to brigadier general on the retired list in 1942 in recognition of his Medal of Honor and combat service in World War I.

== Early life and start of military career ==

Rees was born in Houghton, Michigan, the son of mining engineer David D. Rees and Eugenia (Livermore) Rees. Among his siblings was Thomas H. Rees, who also served as a US Army brigadier general. He was raised and educated in Houghton and was a graduate of Houghton High School. In 1895, he received the degrees of Bachelor of Science (B.S.) and Engineer of Mining (E.M.) from the Michigan College of Mines (now Michigan Technological University). He studied at Harvard University and New York Law School before deciding on a military career. On 7 May 1897, Rees enlisted in the United States Army, joining Company B of the Battalion of Engineers as a corporal. The Spanish–American War started in April 1898, and Rees performed duties associated with defense of strategically valuable waterways. The Pearsall farm (also "Pearsall's farm" or "Pearsall homestead") was an 18th- and 19th-century family estate in the Turtle Bay area of what is now Midtown Manhattan, New York City. The farm's main parcel of about 19 acres occupied part of a 1688 patent granted to Francis Rumbouts and Jacobus Kip; it was bounded roughly by present-day Third Avenue, East 51st Street, and the East River, and centered near modern First Avenue and East 54th Street. Members of the Pearsall family held the land from the 1790s until at least the mid-19th century, and their homestead became a well-known landmark in early 19th-century Manhattan. As the city's grid plan advanced and new streets opened, the farm's rural character gave way to residential development, and the estate was eventually subdivided and sold off in parcels. == Property history == The Pearsall property formed part of a larger colonial tract. In 1688, New York's English governor, Thomas Dongan, granted a patent to merchants Francis Rumbouts (Rombout) and Jacobus Kip for about 150 acres northeast of "Deutel" (Turtle) Bay, bounded by the commons and lands of Jacobus Fabricius and David De Voor. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall. Pearsall's 1805 will gave his "country seat" to his wife for life, with remainder to his son Thomas C. Pearsall; the elder Pearsall died in 1807, and the devise took effect thereafter. In 1809, Thomas C. Pearsall purchased an additional parcel (about four acres) that had been part of the Fabricius patent, consolidating the holding along the river and Post Road. == Location and description == Nineteenth-century descriptions place the farmhouse near the later bed of Avenue A (now roughly First Avenue) between East 58th and 59th Streets, with frontage on the East River and the Post Road. Contemporary advertisements cited orchard and garden improvements, a wharf and landing, and access to rich fisheries in the adjacent cove at Turtle Bay. == Later development == By the 19th century the Pearsall lands—like neighboring estates at Turtle Bay—were surveyed into city lots as Manhattan's grid advanced. Subsequent owners subdivided and conveyed the tract, and the farm landscape disappeared beneath urban residential and commercial development. == Legacy and documentation

Pearsall Farm was a colonial-era estate on Manhattan's East Side, roughly bounded by present-day First Avenue, East 51st Street, the East River, and East 63rd Street. The property originated in part from a 1639 Dutch colonial land grant, and by the late 18th century was developed as the country seat of merchant Thomas Pearsall (died 1807), his wife, and their descendants. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall. Pearsall's 1805 will gave his "country seat" to his wife for life, with remainder to his son Thomas C. Pearsall; the elder Pearsall died in 1807, and the devise took effect thereafter. In 1809, Thomas C. Pearsall purchased an additional parcel (about four acres) that had been part of the Fabricius patent, consolidating the holding along the river and Post Road.

response_text: I Don't Know How but They Found Me! is the second studio album by American folk-pop singer-songwriter Jensen McRae. It was released on April 25, 2025, via Dead Oceans. == Background == Produced by Brad Cook, who recorded the album with McRae in North Carolina, the album centers on McRae's reflection on past relationships, deviating from its "coming of age"-themed predecessor, Are You Happy Now?. "Praying for Your Downfall" was released as the album's lead single on February 19, 2025. == Reception == Referring to several songs such as "I Can Change Him" and "Let Me Be Wrong", DIY's Sarah Jamieson remarked, "these are a set of songs that examine all the broken pieces of her love stories and point the finger in everyone's direction," giving the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5,

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Louane Emera and Théo Fernandez.

== Plot ==
John, a young actor in his twenties from the United States, is staying with his parents in Dinard. June, of Parisian origin, accompanies her parents for vacation at the campsite. One afternoon, during a beach outing, John and June meet. Their attraction is immediate and intense. However, this nascent love is complicated by their respective family backgrounds.

== Cast ==
Louane Emera as June Lalouette
Théo Fernandez as John Cooper
Jean Reno as François Lalouette
Sarah Lind as Mary Cooper
Caterina Murino as Nathalie Lalouette
James Purefoy as Rick Cooper

== Production ==
At the end of January 2023, Luc Besson announced on his Instagram account that he was starting a film project, without giving further details. In an interview with CinéSéries on 11 October 2023, Luc Besson stated that he was finishing editing what he described as his "most beautiful film", a highly personal romantic comedy inspired by his own adolescent experiences.

June & John is the fifth film to emerge from Besson's decision to shoot several projects back-to-back announced in 2022. The director stated his intention to create small-scale, personal films before potentially retiring. The film follows Dogman (2023), The Last Bath (2024), Dracula: A Love Tale (2024) and Enzo (2025).

Principal photography began on 29 March 2023 in Dinard, France and lasted about a month. According to the director, 80% of the footage was shot using an iPhone 14 Pro and edited on an iPad, with the remaining 20% filmed with traditional cinema cameras for specific visual effects sequences.

Luc Besson explained his technical choice: "I wanted total freedom of movement and an intimate approach to actors. The iPhone allowed me to film in narrow spaces, to follow the characters without constraint, a bit like a documentary." He added that the film was conceived as "a return to basics" after big-budget productions like Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017).

In February 2024, during post-production, the feature film received financial support from the CNC, enabling visual effects work and post-production finalization. This state support generated some controversy, given the director's mixed critical and commercial record in recent years.

== Release ==
June & John was selected for the 2025 Berlin Film Festival.

EuropaCorp announced the film's theatrical release in France for 9 April 2025, day-and-date with its debut on the Netflix platform in several international territories, including the United States.

== Reception ==
=== Critical response ===
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 42% of 31 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.1/10. The website's consensus reads: "June & John will appeal to Luc Besson enthusiasts looking for intimacy over spectacle, but this technically experimental romance lacks the narrative substance to justify its artistic ambitions." Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, assigned the film a score of 49 out of 100, based on 12 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

Charlotte Pavard of Télérama gave the film 2 out of 5 stars and wrote: "What lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written, directed and produced by Luc Besson. It stars Primetime Emmy Award winner Callum Turner and BAFTA Award winner Gaia Weiss. The film marks a reunion between Besson and the latter almost a decade after Weiss' breakout role in The Legend of Hercules (2014), which Besson co-produced. The film follows the volatile and passionate romance between John, a hopeless romantic, and June, a free-spirited drifter, as they navigate their tumultuous relationship marked by constant breakups and reconciliations. June & John premiered at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on February 13, 2025, and was released in France on February 19, 2025, by EuropaCorp Distribution.

Callum Turner as John
Gaia Weiss as June

June & John was set to be released in France on December 25, 2024, under the French title Juin et Jean. In November 2024, EuropaCorp Distribution announced that the film would instead be released in France on February 19, 2025. The film had its world premiere on February 13, 2025, at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival, screening out of competition in the Berlinale Special Gala section. In January 2025, Pathé Films acquired the distribution rights for June & John in Switzerland. In Brazil, Imagem Filmes acquired the distribution rights. The film was released in Switzerland by Pathé Films on February 19, 2025. In Brazil, it will be released on March 27, 2025, by Imagem Filmes. Black Bear Pictures was going to handle international sales for June & John when its previous title was Summer Nights, and on December 5, 2024, acquired the distribution rights for the U.S. and the U.K. Black Bear Pictures was in negotiations with several exhibitors about releasing the film in U.S. theaters, possibly in the spring or summer of 2025. The film was released digitally in the United States on February 18, 2025.

== Reception ==

On Metacritic, which uses a weighted average, the film has a score of 43 out of 100, based on 5 critics, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

=== Critical response ===
Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter gave the film a negative review, writing, "Conceived as the adaptation of a novel that doesn't exist (or at least not yet), the movie feels like a mishmash of a Terrence Malick-style voice-over poem with an aversion to traditional storylines and a penchant for magic-hour shooting and Steadicam nature walks. Yet unlike Malick, who tends to mine his narratives and visuals for a more cosmic and metaphysical experience (though he's not entirely above sentimentality and whimsy), Besson goes straight for the tear ducts while dishing out an old-fashioned love story that plays like an extended music video or a very long TV commercial."

Owen Gleiberman of Variety gave the film a negative review, writing, "At its worst, 'June & John' plays like a love story written in greeting-card sentiment and shot like something concocted in a laboratory of 21st-century film-geek aestheticism. Yet Besson, at times, salvages what he's doing by tapping his sincerity. He believes in this love story, and that keeps it, at moments, from turning into a glittering shell."

Dennis Lim of Reverse Shot gave the film a negative review, writing, "The result, dispiritingly, is something like an Anthropologie store come to life—romance as a tastefully rustic commodity, where every frame is a kind of visual ASMR designed to make you feel something without actually saying much of anything."

Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Dogman () is a 2023 drama thriller film written, directed, and produced by Luc Besson. It stars Caleb Landry Jones as Doug, a man who, scarred by an abusive childhood, finds solace and companionship in dogs. The film also stars Jojo T. Gibbs as Evelyn and Grace Palma as Velasquez.

The film premiered in competition at the 2023 Venice Film Festival on September 5, 2023, where it received mixed critical reviews with praise going towards Landry Jones' performance. The film had a wider release in France on September 27, 2023, and received a limited release in the United States on March 22, 2024.

== Plot ==

Evelyn, a psychiatrist, is called to a prison to evaluate Doug, a man found in drag and locked in a cage with his dogs. She finds him mute and unresponsive, but becomes intrigued by his case. As she delves deeper into his past through video recordings and sessions, she uncovers the harrowing story of his life.

Doug's childhood was marked by horrific abuse at the hands of his violent father. His only solace came from the dogs his father bred in their basement. After one particularly brutal beating, Doug was left with severe injuries. He survived and found refuge with his dogs, who became his only family.

Years later, Doug becomes a drag performer, using his theatrical persona as a form of escape and expression. He also trains dogs for theatrical performances. However, his past trauma continues to haunt him, and when he witnesses injustice, he takes matters into his own hands, using his unique relationship with his dogs to exact revenge on those he deems deserving.

As Evelyn pieces together Doug's story, she realizes that his actions, while violent, stem from a deep-seated need for justice and protection, forged by his traumatic past. The film explores themes of survival, trauma, and the complex bond between humans and animals.

== Cast ==

* Caleb Landry Jones as Doug
* Jojo T. Gibbs as Evelyn
* Grace Palma as Velasquez

== Production ==

In October 2021, it was announced that Luc Besson would write and direct Dogman, with Caleb Landry Jones attached to star in the film. Besson described the film as "an exploration of trauma and resilience, told through the unique lens of a man's relationship with his dogs."

Principal photography began in early 2022 in New Jersey and continued through various locations in the northeastern United States. Besson worked closely with animal trainers to ensure the safety and well-being of all dogs featured in the film.

== Release ==

Dogman premiered in competition at the 2023 Venice Film Festival on September 5, 2023. It was released in France on September 27, 2023, by Metropolitan Filmexport. The film received a limited theatrical release in the United States on March 22, 2024, distributed by Briarcliff Entertainment.

In August 2024, it was announced that the film would be broadcast by OCS.

== Reception ==

On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds an approval rating of 55% based on 96 reviews, with an average rating of 6.1/10. The website's critics consensus reads: "Dogman's ambitious exploration of trauma is elevated by Caleb Landry Jones' fearless performance, though Luc Besson's heavy-handed direction occasionally undermines the material." On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 58 out of 100, based on reviews from 23 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews."

Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian gave the film 3 out of 5 stars, writing: "Caleb Landry Jones delivers a committed performance in this unconventional drama, though Besson's storytelling can feel overwrought." David Rooney of The Hollywood Reporter praised Jones' performance but criticized the film's narrative structure, stating: "Jones is captivating, but the film's episodic structure and tonal shifts make for an uneven experience."

Jessica Kiang of Variety wrote: "Dogman is a bold, if flawed, examination of trauma and revenge, with Jones giving it his all in a role that demands both vulnerability and intensity." Owen Gleiberman of Variety noted: "The film's most powerful moments come from the wordless connection between Doug and his dogs, a testament to Besson's visual storytelling."

=== Accolades ===

Caleb Landry Jones received several nominations for his performance, including:

* Satellite Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture, Drama
* European Film Award for Best Actor

Mikako Ichijō (一条 美賀子, 24 July 1835 – 9 July 1894) was a Japanese princess and the legal wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu. She was also the daughter of Tadaka Ichijō. She is known by her childhood name, Mikako (also romanized as Mika).

== Early years ==
Mikako was born on 24 July 1835, the first daughter to the Chief Advisor (Kampaku) Tadaka Ichijō. As was the tradition she was raised away from her mother (Tadaka's concubine Matsuko Kushige). In 1842, she was taken under the care and tutelage of her step-mother, Tsumuko, whose father was Tadayuki Matsudaira, the lord of Matsue Domain.

== Marriage ==
In 1849, she was engaged to Yoshinobu Tokugawa, then known as Akimune Hitotsubashi, who was the son of Nariaki Tokugawa and a potential heir to the shōgun, Tokugawa Ieyoshi. She officially moved into Hitotsubashi mansion and the couple married in 1853. While being very supportive of Yoshinobu's political career, the pair did not have a child, as all their offspring died in infancy. She gave birth to five children: four daughters and a son, all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

Mikako Ichijō (一条 美賀子, Ichijō Mikako, January 16, 1835 – July 9, 1894) was a Japanese noble lady from the Ichijō family, a branch of the Fujiwara clan. She is also known as Princess Kazunomiya (一品親王妃 美賀子女王) or by the title Goshoroku. She married Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.


== Early life ==
She was born in Kyoto in 1835, the daughter of an aristocrat Tadayoshi Ichijō and a court lady Nozoe Hanako. As the daughter of a kuge, she received an education in classical poetry, literature, and painting. She was adopted by Emperor Ninkō in 1843, so she received the title of princess (nyoō).


== Marriage ==
In 1849, then a teenager, she married the future shogun Yoshinobu Tokugawa through the recommendation of Konoe Tadahiro. At that time Yoshinobu was the son of Tokugawa Nariaki and was named Kikuchiyo. She received the nickname "Mika-gimi." As Yoshinobu's lawful wife, her position was superior to that of his concubines. She gave birth to four children, but they all died young. The couple's first son, Iesada, was born in 1850, but died three days after birth. A daughter, Kamenosuke, lived from 1851-1852. Their second son, Ippei, lived from 1853-1855, and a third son, Shichimaro, lived from 1855-1859, with all dying young.

After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.


== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.


== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside


== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".


== References ==

In Ingham County, it serves parts of the townships of Aurelius, Delhi, and Onondaga. == History == The first commencement at Eaton Rapids High School was in 1875. A brick school was built in 1886 on the north side of King Street near the end of West Street. It was ultimately known as the West Building. An elementary school was built to the east of it, and the high school was built to the north of the elementary on the west side of Hall Street in 1923. The West Building was condemned by the state fire marshal in 1939, but the high school continued to hold classes in it due to overcrowding. It was torn down when the new high school opened. As of 1962, high school classes were held in three other buildings, including the 1923 high school, which was converted to a junior high when the current high school opened. Northwestern Elementary was built in 1959 and closed in 2011. Union Street Elementary was built in 1962. The architect was Guido A. Binda. Currently it is known as Union Street Center and houses the Early Learning Center and other programs for the community. The current high school opened in fall 1963. Warren Holmes Co. was the architect. The opening of the high school was marred by vandalism. A few days

She was also the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. Schmidt-Nielsen collaborated with her husband in natural science research and publications, including into the rennet of calves and the vitamin content of herrings. == Death == Schmidt-Nielsen died in 1959 in Stockholm. She was buried at Domkirkegården, Trondheim, Norway. == References ==

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It was released on Amazon Prime Video on March 27, 2025. The film is Besson's first movie to be entirely shot on a smartphone using an iPhone 16 Pro.

== Plot ==
June, an American student, falls in love with John, a Parisian photographer, during a brief encounter in Paris. They spend four days together, experiencing passion and romance before life pulls them apart. Their relationship is told through memories, stolen moments, and unfulfilled promises.

== Cast ==
* Marina Hands as June
* Raphaël Quenard as John

== Production ==
The film was shot entirely on an iPhone 16 Pro. Besson described the process as "liberating," saying that using a smartphone allowed the crew to be more mobile and spontaneous. He also stated that modern smartphones now have enough cinematic quality to tell emotionally rich stories. The film was shot in Paris and New York over the course of three weeks with a minimal crew.

== Release ==
June & John was released directly on Amazon Prime Video on March 27, 2025, without a theatrical release. This marked Besson's first direct-to-streaming film.

== Reception ==
The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics. On Rotten Tomatoes, it holds a 38% approval rating based on 21 reviews, with an average rating of 4.8/10. The consensus reads: "Despite Luc Besson's technical experiment, June & John struggles to connect emotionally, relying on surface-level romance and underdeveloped characters."

Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter wrote: "Besson's iPhone experiment feels more like a gimmick than a breakthrough. The visuals, while occasionally striking, don't compensate for the film's hollow emotional core."

Clarisse Fabre of Le Monde gave the film a negative review, writing: "What lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

response_text: I Don't Know How is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, released on January 24, 2025, through RCA Records. Described by McRae as "chaotic in the best possible way" and "like a therapy session" for her, the album delves into darker and more introspective themes following McRae's breakup with fellow singer The Kid Laroi in late 2023, who was reportedly the lyrical inspiration for her previous, more upbeat album Think Later. Sonically, the album blends upbeat, 1990s-inspired drum and bass and melodic pop with introspective ballads. It was met with widespread acclaim upon release. It was preceded by the release of four singles: "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", "Sports Car", and "Numb", the first of which was McRae's highest-charting song on the Billboard Hot 100 at the time, charting at number eight. The album was supported by her fourth headlining concert tour, So Close to What. == Background == Following the success of McRae's second studio album Think Later (2023), which was supported by the lead single "Greedy", she continued to tour extensively in 2024, including on the legs of Think Later World Tour in February to April and July to August, as well as on Taylor Swift's Eras Tour across several dates in July to August and October. Regarding her next record, McRae hinted that the project would be more mature and reflective, particularly referencing her 2023 breakup with fellow musician The Kid Laroi, in contrast to the upbeat nature of Think Later. During an interview with Variety in April 2024, she stated, "I'm never going to hate on [Think Later], because it was my feelings in the moment and it led me here, but it's definitely not the record I'm working on right now." She told ELLE UK in June 2024: == Composition == I Don't Know How runs for approximately 39 minutes. Sonically, it combines upbeat, '90s-inspired drum and bass and melodic pop with ballads and leans into indie pop and trip hop. The album alternates songs that deal with feelings like dejection and loneliness ("Numb", "Worst Wife Ever", "Sports Car") with the pain of others ("My Prom Dress", "Slow Hands"), self-discovery post-relationship ("Never, Ever"), and others that are introspective ("What Happened to Love", "It's Ok I'm Ok", "Ghost Me", "My Own Melody"). == Promotion == On October 16, 2024, McRae posted a video on her social media featuring a snippet of the song "What Happened to Love" and later announced that the song would be performed at her YouTube Theater show two days later. She also hinted at new music by stating: "YouTube Theater show is gonna be special for a reason ;)" On October 17, McRae shared another snippet of another song from the album, "Ghost Me", and revealed that both songs would be played at the show. In an interview with Z100, she teased a January release for her album and described it as "so fucking good" and "worth it". She hinted that the songs "What Happened to Love" and "Ghost Me" would not be singles of the album, explaining the reasoning behind her decision to debut them: "I don't want to be one of those artists that puts out every song before the album. That's the biggest risk, because it's maybe not the catchiest thing, but it creates a world." On November 4, Billboard confirmed that McRae was scheduled to release new music in 2025. McRae also announced the international leg of her world tour, titled Miss Possessive Tour, which runs from March to May 2025 and will tour parts of Canada, Europe, and the United Kingdom. On December 23, 2024, McRae announced a new tour, So Close to What, of select cities in North America from February to April 2025. On January 6, 2025, McRae announced the album's title, release date, and the album cover. Alongside the announcement, she stated, "creating this album was the most confusing, liberating, and necessary experience for me." The album cover debuted at midnight in Times Square in New York City and took on a 1970s-inspired art; McRae stated that the cover represents "emotional complexity beyond sadness, fear, or vulnerability" with "the confident yet contemplative facial expression and vibrant graphic design." McRae made an appearance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert on January 17. On January 21, following the track list reveal, she hosted a listening party for the album and performed at a surprise show in Brooklyn. The album will be supported by a headlining tour, titled So Close to What, which started on February 5, 2025. == Singles == On September 12, 2024, McRae released "It's Ok I'm Ok", a power pop track. It became her highest charting song to date on the US Billboard Hot 100, debuting and peaking at number eight. The song was certified gold by the RIAA and silver by BPI. A music video was released on the same day, featuring McRae dancing alone and with a backup group outside and in front of a green screen. On November 8, McRae released a drum and bass and trip hop song, "2 Hands". A music video released the same day, directed by Christian Breslauer, follows McRae singing at her office desk and meeting with two bosses for office talks interspersed with footage of them being killed by her. As of January 2025, the track had accumulated over 80 million streams on Spotify. The third single, "Sports Car", described as mid-tempo, was released on December 6. It was followed by a music video directed by Breslauer, following McRae singing in a sports car during multiple car shows. The music video received over 1.5 million views in 12 hours. The song was also performed on Saturday Night Live two days after its release. A fourth single, "Numb", was released on January 17, 2025, featuring introspective lyrics and indie pop sound. It was followed by a music video, showing McRae at an event walking through a crowd and signing autographs before leaving in a car with her lover. == Critical reception == I Don't Know How received widespread acclaim, with particular praise pointed towards its direction and sonic palette. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from professional publications, the album received an average score of 85, based on eight reviews, indicating "universal acclaim". Reviewing the album for The Independent, critic Roisin O'Connor opined: "[...] McRae leans into her strengths on this third album and goes darker with a diaristic set that captures the breathlessness of her youth [...] I Don't Know How turns out to be an existential album of the sort that surely secures an audience for a lifetime." Rolling Stone's Daniel Kreps praised the album, writing, "I Don't Know How [...] feels like a bit of a reset for the pop star as she gets personal with her listeners, with McRae wading through nostalgia, loss, heartbreak, regret, resentment and longing with songs that skew more ballad than banger." He gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text:
Olde Tyme Hardcore is the third studio album by Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on May 20, 1996 through Century Media Records. The album follows a similar formula to their debut album, Back on the Map (1989). The album features guest appearances from Dropkick Murphys singer Al Barr and Biohazard singer Evan Seinfeld.

== Background ==
Shortly after Slapshot finished touring in support of their second album 16 Valve Hate in 1995. Lead singer Jack "Choke" Kelly had been working to reform the bands original lineup. He wanted to bring back drummer Mark McKay and bassist Chris Lauria. In an interview with Ox-fanzine Jack "Choke" Kelly stated "I wanted to do a Back On The Map sounding album with the old line up" guitarist Mike Bowser was added and the band began recording the album.

== Critical reception ==
Christian Ritter of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

response_text: Mikako Ichijō (一条美賀子, Ichijō Mikako, May 21, 1835 – July 20, 1894), born Tsune-hime, was a Japanese noblewoman and the formal wife of the last shōgun, Tokugawa Yoshinobu. == Early life == Born as Tsune-hime, daughter to Tadayuki Ichijō, a high ranking court noble. She had one older brother and two older sisters, and was raised with lots of love. == Marriage == In December of 1853, after complex negotiations between the imperial court and the government, it was decided that she would marry Yoshinobu Tokugawa, who was a potential successor to the shōgunate. She first met Yoshinobu in 1854, and the formal wedding ceremony was held in Kyoto during November. The marriage produced two daughters, both of whom ended up all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

response_text:
Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, 15 May 1835 – 9 July 1894) was the official wife of the 15th shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu.

== Early life ==

Born in Kyoto, she was the daughter of Konoe Tadahiro, who was a relative of Empress Eishō. She had been called Princess Tsune (恒姫).

== Marriage ==

In 1850, she was a chosen to be the wife of Yoshinobu, the son of former shōgun Tokugawa Nariaki. The two officially married on October 25, 1856. After marriage, she was given the title of midaidokoro, however sources indicate that Yoshinobu was not particularly interested in Mikako, leaving her rooms on their wedding night. The only woman who he gave proper attention to was a concubine named Ichijo Mikako, even going so far as to name her 'Mikako' after his wife's name, to humiliate her. She also had several children with him, with most of them all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==

Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==

Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text: Humberto Álvarez Suárez (La Serena, 22 April 1898 – 16 April 1988) was a Chilean lawyer, professor and politician. He served as Chile's Minister of Justice and Minister of the Interior under different presidents. == Biography == Born in La Serena, he was the son of Humberto Álvarez Quiroga and Leopoldina Suárez Vargas. He completed his secondary education at the Liceo of La Serena, then studied law at the University of Chile, graduating in 1924 with a thesis on Prelación de Créditos (Precedence of Credits) that was partly incorporated into the Código de Procesamiento Civil. He married Marta Johannsen Bonchert; they had two children, Humberto and Marta. == Professional career == He worked as secretary-lawyer of the Municipality of Coquimbo (1921–1922), served as relator of the Court of Appeals of La Serena, was secretary to the Civil Code reform commission, and legal secretary of the Association of Electric and Mining Companies. He later practiced law with Gabriel González Videla and Pedro Enrique Alfonso. In business, he presided over the Compañía Olivarera Nacional, the Compañía de Conservas e Industrias Pesqueras S.A., and the Sociedad Pesquera of Iquique. From 1947 he taught procedural law at the University of Chile. == Political career == A member of the Radical Party, Álvarez was elected Deputy for the 4th Departmental Group (La Serena, Elqui, Coquimbo) for the 1933–1937 term. He resigned his seat upon being appointed Minister of Justice by President Arturo Alessandri Palma (12 September–22 October 1936). He was reelected Deputy for 1937–1941 (now covering La Serena, Elqui, Coquimbo, Ovalle, Illapel and Combarbalá), serving on the Committees of Social Legislation and Justice; Government; Constitution, Legislation and Justice; Finance; and the Joint Committee on the Organic Law of Courts. He again left the Chamber when appointed Minister of the Interior by President Pedro Aguirre Cerda (8 February–30 July 1940); his seat was filled by Rodolfo Masson Villarroel after a by-election. Álvarez was then elected Senator for Atacama and Coquimbo in 1941 and reelected in 1949 and 1957, serving until 1965. He sat on the Committees of Constitution, Legislation and Justice; Finance; Education;

He resigned his seat upon being appointed Minister of Justice by President Arturo Alessandri Palma (12 September–22 October 1936). response_text: Geolycosa subvittata is a species of spider in the family Lycosidae. It is endemic to South Africa and is commonly known as the Cape Geolycosa wolf spider. == Distribution == Geolycosa subvittata is found in the Eastern Cape and Western Cape provinces of South Africa. Notable locations include Grahamstown (now Makhanda), Port Elizabeth, Table Mountain National Park, Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden, and several other sites in the Cape region. == Habitat and ecology == This species is a ground dweller known to live in burrows. It has been sampled from the Fynbos and Thicket biomes at altitudes ranging from 5 to 552 m. == Description == Known from both sexes, Geolycosa subvittata is smaller than the related G. hectoria but has a similar dorsal color pattern. It has two yellow stripes on the abdomen. Ventrally, it bears a median longitudinal black stripe. The tibiae are not distinctly banded. Males measure 11 mm in total length, while females measure 14 mm. == Conservation == The species has a large range and is protected in Table Mountain National Park and Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden. However, most specimens were sampled around 1900, and the species is threatened by loss of habitat. == Taxonomy == The species was originally described by Pocock in 1900 as Lycosa subvittata from Port Elizabeth. It was later revised by Roewer in 1959. == References ==

response_text: Laura Toenjes is the superintendent of the Kyrene School District serving the Ahwatukee, south Tempe, and west Chandler communities in the state of Arizona. She is responsible for the education of approximately 12,000 students located at 25 elementary and middle schools, and employs over 2,000 staff, teachers, and administrators. Toenjes has a three year contract until June 30, 2027 with a base annual salary of $220,000. She has been with the Kyrene school district since 2016 joining when Dr. Jan Vesely became superintendent. After Vesely announced retirement in October 2020, the school board immediately promoted Toenjes to the superintendent role. Her career has also included positions at Sunnyside Unified School District and Arizona Department of Education. == Notable decisions == In February 2025, the Kyrene Governing Board created the Long Range Planning Committee. Toenjes was involved, and vetted 58 members of the committee. As of October 1, 2025, the planning committee is recommending closing 9 out of 25 schools, with final school board decision scheduled for December 2025. In April 2025, Toenjes re-affirmed that the school district's "policies around equity, inclusion and social-emotional wellness—are fully compliant with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964." Arizona Superintendent of Public Instruction Tom Horne threatened to withhold $1.5 million of federal funding per guidance from the United States Department of Education. The guidance was subsequently revoked, and district was properly funded. == References ==

response_text:
Lutz van Dijk (born 3 June 1955 in Berlin) is a Dutch-German writer and historian who also holds South African citizenship. Since 2001, he has been living and working in Cape Town, South Africa, and in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. Van Dijk is the author of the novel Verdammt starke Liebe (Damned Strong Love), which recounts a love story between a Polish and a German boy in Nazi Germany. The novel, which targets teenagers, was published in 1991 and drew the attention of audiences as well as scholars. Van Dijk received the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis for the book and, so far, the novel has been translated into 15 languages. In 2010, Van Dijk translated the book into Afrikaans. Alongside his literary career, Van Dijk is an activist for the rights of HIV-positive children and LGBTQ+ rights in South Africa. 

== Early life and education ==
Van Dijk was born in West Berlin, which, following the Second World War, was politically a city enclave in the east of Germany and surrounded by the Berlin Wall. He is the son of a Dutch father and a German mother. He attended Freie Universität Berlin, where he graduated with a Master of Arts degree. He specialised in European history, psychology, and educational science. He then spent time in Israel working on a Kibbutz and with a peace organisation and returned to Europe to continue studying, writing a dissertation on the history of homosexuality. He taught at the Free University of Berlin and at the University of Hamburg and served as a Scientific Counselor for the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam from 1989 to 1996.  In 1996, Van Dijk completed his PhD degree at the University of Oldenburg.

In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18.

In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002.

== Awards and nominations ==
Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize.

== References ==

A brick school was built in 1886 on the north side of King Street near the end of West Street. It was ultimately known as the West Building. An elementary school was built to the east of it, and the high school was built to the north of the elementary on the west side of Hall Street in 1923. Northwestern Elementary was built in 1959 and closed in 2011. Union Street Elementary was built in 1962. The architect was Guido A. Binda. Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5,

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the seventh studio album by Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on February 1, 2008 through I Scream Records and was produced by Slapshot. Arthur Johnston, (of Massachusetts hardcore punk bands S.F.A. and No Mistake), composed the four instrumental interludes, that are each named after and make homage to historically relevant hardcore punk record labels, following the track listing.

== Background and recording ==
After the band had many issues in their lineup for the previous album back in the early 2000s, frontman Jack Kelly stated the band was done. After some time had passed, Kelly re-united the band with longtime members, bassist Chris Lauria and drummer Mark Mckay, in addition to recruiting guitarist Mike Bowser (former The Pist, Death & Taxes).

== Critical reception ==
Frank Engelhardt of Rock Hard Germany praised the album, calling it a "crisp and raw slap-across-the-ear-drum disc" and stating "the Boston hardcore veterans on Olde Tyme Hardcore still display a lot of momentum after all these years."Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the eighth studio album by the Boston, Massachusetts hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on February 5, 2008 through I Scream Records. 

== Background ==
"Olde Tyme Hardcore" is the eighth studio album by the band, and was released on February 5, 2008 through I Scream Records. "Olde Tyme Hardcore" was recorded in less than three days at Q Division Studios in Somerville, Massachusetts. Singer Jack Kelly told Punknews.org that "We're more interested in making sure it sounds raw and live, than we are in making it sound perfectly produced." On January 10, 2008, Slapshot released an advanced internet stream of the album on their official Myspace page.

== Reception ==
Markus Endres of Ox-fanzine gave the album a rating of 6.5 out of 10 and stated "At the top they deliver old-school hardcore that is really fun." Adding "But where did the energy of a "16 Valve Hate" from the terrific debut go? I miss more of that and that's why I'm being stingy with my points." Erik Chosen of Trust fanzine wrote "Slapshot are back with nine new songs and these should please their fans. Jack's throat and the guitars still sound as raw as they did in the old days, only the drums sound a bit rounder than in the past. The guys take absolutely no prisoners and the boys don't reinvent the wheel either, but that's not their ambition anyway." Karsten Schmahl of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

response_text:
Olde Tyme Hardcore is the eighth studio album by the hardcore punk band Slapshot, released on June 8, 2009 through Bridge 9 Records. It was recorded in 2008 during three sessions at Damage Studios with producer Steve "Weasel" Risteen. It is the second album by the band to feature Weasel producing following 1997's Greatest Hits, Etc, Etc. The album was released six years after the bands previous studio album Tear It Down (2003).

== Background and recording ==

Slapshot disbanded following the release of Tear It Down and its release tour with the final concert taking place in 2004. Frontman Choke performed regularly with other bands and during this time Slapshot reunited a number of times for one off concerts, before regrouping in 2007. In an April 10, 2009, interview with Punk Core. Org, Choke explained: "After some lineup changes and a few break-ins rehearsal studios and vans and some various other crappy incidents we're back!" 
Due to the bands sporadic reunion since 2003, Choke reflected "I figured it was time, or at the very least, time to go in and figure it out." He continued, stating: "We went in and did the songs that were ready." With the sessions being recorded at Damage Studios in Southbridge, Massachusetts. Recording took place over three separate occasions, with Choke explaining "this record was actually recorded on three different occasions spanning something like 18 months. Choke notes that "I had a lot to say and a lot I wanted to say that had built up over the past 5 or 6 years." 

== Release ==

The album title and first track Olde Tyme Hardcore was meant to take aim at those who Choke refers to as "internet crybaby's" who complain that the bands best days were gone and not to reform. A video for the track "Thrasher" was created and posted on Bridge 9 Records Youtube page. The song Choke notes was written about his friend and drummer of Blood For Blood who Rob Lind "Thrasher" who died in 2004.

== Critical reception ==

Erik Lande of Ox-fanzine described the album as "Hardcore in its original 80's meaning that is, raw, fast and aggressive, uncomplicated, stripped-down punk in the truest sense." And goes on to conclude "No big differences between old and new songs. Really, guys: This is once again, SLAPSHOT! Get fucking clear!" While Heiko Gerken of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==

Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==
