response_text:
The Ritz Tower is a luxury residential building at 465 Park Avenue on the corner of East 57th Street in the Midtown Manhattan neighborhood of New York City. It was built from 1925 to 1926 as an apartment hotel and was designed by Emery Roth and Thomas Hastings for journalist Arthur Brisbane, who was the developer. The Ritz Tower is about 541 feet (165 m) with 41 stories, making it the tallest residential building in New York City upon its completion. Because it was initially classified as an apartment hotel, the building was constructed to a greater height than was usually permitted.

The building's massing is split into two sections: a 15-story base and a 26-story tower above it, designed in the Art Deco style. The facade is covered in brick, limestone, and architectural terracotta. The base has numerous setbacks and occupies the entire land lot. The tower, rising above the western section of the base, contains setbacks at its top. The lowest three stories, which are clad with rusticated and vermiculated limestone blocks, contain the main lobby as well as storefronts. The lobby includes a barrel-vaulted ceiling with murals.

There are 500 units, ranging from one to fourteen rooms each. Upon the Ritz Tower's opening, about half of the units were leased to short-term residents. The Ritz Tower also included 17 duplex apartments and one triplex apartment, including Brisbane's own penthouse on the top stories. The Ritz Tower was renamed the Park Ritz Tower in 1956 and the Carlton Tower in 1965.

The Ritz Tower opened on November 15, 1926, with only 25 suites occupied; the building was not fully rented out until 1929. In the early 1930s, Brisbane unsuccessfully attempted to sell the building. After Brisbane died in 1936, the building passed through several owners. The Carlton Tower was converted to a housing cooperative in 1956 and was renamed the Ritz Tower in 2002. It is a New York City designated landmark.

== Site ==
The Ritz Tower is in the Midtown Manhattan neighborhood of New York City. It is along the eastern sidewalk of Park Avenue between 57th Street and 58th Street. The land lot is nearly rectangular and covers 23,000 square feet (2,100 m2). It has a frontage of 200.83 feet (61.21 m) on Park Avenue to the west and 101.67 feet (30.99 m) on 57th Street to the south. The building shares the city block with 500 Park Avenue to the north and several low- and medium-rise structures to the east. Other nearby buildings include 400 East 57th Street and the Galleria to the east; 590 Madison Avenue and the IBM Building to the west; the Four Seasons Hotel New York to the northwest; and 9 West 57th Street to the southwest. In addition, the Le Cirque restaurant is across 58th Street to the north, while the 57th Street station of the New York City Subway's 4, ​6, and <6>​ trains is immediately south of the building.

In the early 20th century, before the construction of Grand Central Terminal and the subsequent development of Terminal City, this section of Park Avenue was occupied mostly by low-rise buildings. Prior to the Ritz Tower's construction, the site was occupied by two five-story brownstone residences that had been constructed in 1871. The site of the Ritz Tower was developed in conjunction with that of a proposed Ritz-Carlton Hotel at 59 East 57th Street, one block west.

== Architecture ==
Emery Roth and Thomas Hastings designed the Ritz Tower; both had worked on similar projects in the past. Hastings had designed the Hotel Ritz-Carlton just west of the Ritz Tower, while Roth had worked on several hotels and apartment buildings, including the Hotel Belleclaire, the Saxony, and the St. Moritz Hotel. When the Ritz Tower was announced in 1925, Roth had been hired to design the building; Hastings was hired as a consulting architect about four months later. Sources disagree on whether Hastings or Roth should be primarily credited with the design of the Ritz Tower. Roth's obituary attributed the design to him, while other sources attribute it to Hastings. Christopher Gray wrote in a 1988 article that, because Hastings had designed the nearby Ritz-Carlton Hotel, some believed that Hastings was the primary architect of the Ritz Tower, while contemporary accounts attributed the design to Roth. Architectural historian Robert A. M. Stern said in 1987: "It has always been a matter of some conjecture just how the design responsibilities for the Ritz Tower were divided [...] but the building's vigorous massing suggests Roth's hand, while its façade has the imprint of the Beaux-Arts." Another architectural writer, Donald Reynolds, characterized the Ritz Tower as a building for which Hastings "provided the design and Emery Roth the execution".

The Ritz Tower's design incorporated several influences. The Ritz Tower took its name from the Ritz-Carlton Hotel; the hotel's name was, in turn, derived from the Spanish word ritz meaning "elegant" or "sumptuous". According to The New York Times, the overall design was inspired by various buildings in Europe, including buildings that Brisbane had seen on his trips to Europe. These precedents may have included the Giralda in Seville, Spain, which Hastings used as an inspiration for his design. Other sources state that the Ritz Tower was inspired by the Palais de Justice in Brussels, Belgium. Furthermore, the Ritz Tower was designed in the Art Deco style and contained "modernistic" design features, though it was also described as classical in design.

The building is about 541 feet (165 m) tall with 41 stories. It was the tallest residential building in New York City and the world when it was completed. According to the Real Estate Record and Guide, the Ritz Tower surpassed the London Terrace apartment building, which measured 460 feet (140 m) upon its completion in 1930. There are multiple penthouse stories at the top of the building, which are not counted in the official story count, and the building was variously cited as having 39, 40, or 41 stories. Different sources cite different figures for the building's height; for example, the Landmarks Preservation Commission cites a measurement of 541 feet (165 m), Emporis cites 540 feet (160 m), and SkyscraperPage cites 525 feet (160 m).

=== Form ===
The Ritz Tower's massing is split into two sections: a 15-story base and a 26-story tower above it. The base occupies the entire land lot and has several setbacks. The tower rises above the western portion of the base and also contains several setbacks at its top. The building's massing was the result of the 1916 Zoning Resolution, which mandated setbacks for the facades of tall buildings to allow light and air to reach the streets below. The Ritz Tower's plan complied with the zoning code at the time of its construction, which allowed buildings to rise without setback above a given level if the building occupied 25 percent or less of the land lot. This provision generally applied to buildings that were classified as hotels. Prior to the Ritz Tower's development, the tallest buildings in New York City to use this provision were the Lefcourt Colonial Building and the Fred F. French Building, both of which were erected in 1927. At the time of the Ritz Tower's construction, residential buildings typically could not be built above 150 feet (46 m) without incorporating setbacks. To allow the Ritz Tower to be constructed to a greater height, the building was classified as an apartment hotel, which contained a temporary-residency component.

The tower measures 100 feet (30 m) on its east–west axis by 50 feet (15 m) on its north–south axis. It contains setbacks at the 30th, 35th, and 37th floors, tapering to a square pinnacle that measures 50 feet (15 m) on each side. The bulk of the building is placed at the western side of the lot, facing Park Avenue; this helped maximize the profit from the more expensive Park Avenue frontage. At ground level, the westernmost portion of the building, facing Park Avenue, measures 100 feet (30 m) deep. To the east, at ground level, the base contains two light courts facing north and south, each of which measures 50 feet (15 m) wide. These light courts extend to the roof of the base at the 15th floor.

=== Facade ===
The facade is divided into three horizontal sections and is made of buff-colored brick, limestone, and architectural terracotta. At ground level, the building has commercial space that runs along Park Avenue and 57th Street. The lowest three stories, which act as a base for the building, are clad in rusticated and vermiculated limestone blocks and contain large window openings. Above the third story, the main shaft of the building is faced with buff-colored brick, except on 57th Street, where the facade has a polychrome terracotta design. Near the top of the shaft, the 15th floor is clad in terracotta. The setbacks that form the pinnacle of the building are also faced with polychrome terracotta, and windows on the setbacks are separated by multi-story terracotta piers. The terracotta ornament includes Gothic-inspired details such as tracery, as well as classic and Art Deco-style ornamentation.

==== Park Avenue facade ====
Along the Park Avenue elevation, the second and third stories contain large window openings, separated by thick limestone piers that align with the corners of the building. These openings contain revolving doors and show windows at ground level, as well as windows on the second and third floors. There are metal canopies above some of the ground-level openings. The bays of the fourth through 14th floors are separated by vertical piers. There are paired sash windows in each bay. Some of these bays have curved metal balconies at the fifth or sixth floors. The tower rises above the western section of the base, along Park Avenue, where the upper stories are set back. In total, the tower has 11 bays, which are divided into three groups of three, three, and five bays. The center five bays have windows separated by vertical brick piers, while the three bays on either side have double-height limestone panels that are blank except for ornamental designs at the top of the panels.

On the 30th, 35th, and 37th stories, there are setbacks on the Park Avenue elevation. The portions of the tower above each setback are clad with multi-colored terracotta panels and surrounded by terracotta tiles, which are laid in a diagonal pattern. The upper stories of the tower contain narrow window openings, which are separated by flat terracotta piers; the piers have capitals near the top. There are also terracotta panels that contain ornamental designs. Near the top of the building is a terracotta turret, which measures 50 feet (15 m) on each side. The turret is ornamented with finials. Above the turret is a pyramidal roof.

==== 57th Street facade ====
The 57th Street elevation is also divided into three horizontal sections. Along 57th Street, the ground-level facade consists of commercial space with display windows. The second and third stories contain large window openings separated by thick limestone piers. The fourth through 14th floors of the 57th Street facade are faced with buff-colored brick and contain sash windows. Unlike the Park Avenue elevation, where the windows are separated by vertical piers, the 57th Street facade contains horizontal terracotta band courses that separate the windows. The 15th story is clad in terracotta and serves as an intermediate cornice separating the base and tower.

On the 57th Street side, the tower rises above the eastern end of the base. The center of the tower contains a group of windows that span five stories, from the 16th to 20th floors. This group of windows is flanked by vertical terracotta piers. The portions of the tower above the 30th, 35th, and 37th stories are clad with multi-colored terracotta panels, similar to those on the Park Avenue elevation.

=== Interior ===
The Ritz Tower contained 500 units, ranging from one to fourteen rooms. About half of the units were leased to short-term residents and half to long-term residents. The residences include 17 duplex apartments and one triplex penthouse. Among the apartments was developer Arthur Brisbane's own penthouse, which occupied three stories and was accessed by a private elevator. The apartments in the building also included drawing rooms, dining rooms, libraries, and other features that were normally found in upscale residences.

==== Lobby ====
The main entrance to the building is at the center of the Park Avenue elevation. The entrance vestibule has a barrel-vaulted ceiling with murals, which are surrounded by elaborate moldings. The walls of the vestibule are made of marble. The vestibule leads to a lobby, which has a coffered ceiling with murals painted by John William Sinnot. The ceiling murals depict classical figures, including cherubs and clouds. In addition, the lobby contains marble walls, as well as a fireplace with a bronze mantel. The lobby also includes ornamental grilles and doors. The lobby was renovated in the 2000s.

== History ==

=== Development and opening ===
Arthur Brisbane, a newspaper editor and columnist, announced plans for the Ritz Tower in June 1925. At the time, Brisbane was a columnist for the Hearst newspapers and was also a real-estate investor; he had previously developed several other buildings. The Ritz Tower was to be built on the site of two five-story brownstone residences that Brisbane had purchased. Brisbane indicated that the building would cost $7 million to construct and would contain a total of 500 rooms. Brisbane predicted that the Ritz Tower would be the tallest apartment building in the world upon its completion. The building was to be constructed in conjunction with a Ritz-Carlton Hotel, which would be built one block west at 59 East 57th Street. The hotel would have contained 450 rooms, while the apartment building was to have 300 rooms. The two buildings were to have been connected by a tunnel.

In July 1925, Brisbane obtained a $3.5 million loan from the Equitable Life Assurance Society to fund the development of the Ritz Tower. The loan was secured by a mortgage on the land, as well as by Brisbane's ownership of the building. The same month, Brisbane hired Emery Roth as the architect for the building. In November 1925, Brisbane hired Thomas Hastings as a consulting architect. The general contractor was the George A. Fuller Company. The building was to be managed by the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company. Because the Ritz Tower was classified as an apartment hotel, it was permitted to be built to a greater height than would have been allowed for a conventional residential building.

Construction of the Ritz Tower began in October 1925. As built, the structure was designed with a steel frame and was erected at a rapid pace. At one point, the builders were adding one story every three days. The construction process involved the use of a tower crane that was mounted on the roof of the building. As the building rose, the crane was repeatedly disassembled and reassembled at higher levels. The Ritz Tower was originally scheduled to be completed in October 1926. However, the tower was not finished until November 1926.

The Ritz Tower opened on November 15, 1926, although only 25 suites were occupied at the time. Contemporary accounts described the building as one of the most significant architectural achievements in New York City, as well as one of the most prestigious residential addresses in the city. The building was not fully rented out until 1929. Brisbane initially set rental rates that were comparable to those at the nearby Ritz-Carlton Hotel. A one-room suite cost $2,500 to $3,000 per year, while a fourteen-room suite cost $18,000 per year. Brisbane had originally predicted that the building would generate $1.5 million in annual rental income.

=== Mid-20th century ===
During the early 1930s, Brisbane attempted to sell the building, but he was unable to find a buyer. In 1933, Brisbane refinanced the building's mortgage with a $4 million loan from the Equitable Life Assurance Society. Brisbane died in December 1936, and his estate placed the building for sale. The building was sold in 1937 to a syndicate led by Frederick Brown, who paid $4.2 million for the structure. Brown financed the purchase with a $3 million mortgage from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The building was sold again in 1938 to a syndicate led by David T. Kennedy, who paid $3.5 million for the structure. Kennedy financed the purchase with a $2.5 million mortgage from the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

In 1942, the building was sold to a syndicate led by Abraham M. Brickman, who paid $3.25 million for the structure. Brickman financed the purchase with a $2 million mortgage from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. The building was sold again in 1945 to a syndicate led by Julius Goldstein, who paid $3.5 million for the structure. Goldstein financed the purchase with a $2.5 million mortgage from the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

In 1956, the building was converted to a housing cooperative and was renamed the Park Ritz Tower. The conversion involved the sale of 428 apartments to their occupants. The building was sold again in 1965 to a syndicate led by Harry Helmsley, who paid $10.5 million for the structure. Helmsley renamed the building the Carlton Tower and renovated the structure. The building was sold again in 1980 to a syndicate led by Harry Macklowe, who paid $32 million for the structure.

=== Recent history ===
The building was designated a New York City landmark by the Landmarks Preservation Commission on June 24, 1998. The building was renamed the Ritz Tower in 2002. In the 2000s, the building's lobby was renovated. In 2008, the building's exterior was cleaned and restored. The building has remained a prestigious residential address in the 21st century.

== Notable residents ==
Notable residents of the Ritz Tower have included:

* Arthur Brisbane, newspaper editor and columnist, who developed the building and lived in the penthouse
* William Randolph Hearst Jr., newspaper publisher
* Jeremiah Milbank, industrialist and philanthropist
* Greta Garbo, actress
* Vincent Astor, businessman and philanthropist
* Tommy Manville, heir to the Johns Hopkins Manville fortune
* Elizabeth Arden, businesswoman
* Joe DiMaggio, baseball player

== Community ==
The opening of the Ritz Tower was a catalyst for further development in the area. This included the construction of several other high-rise apartment buildings in the vicinity, including the Campanile at 450 East 52nd Street, which was completed in 1927. The development of the Ritz Tower and other luxury apartment buildings in the area helped transform the neighborhood into one of the most prestigious residential districts in New York City.

The area around the Ritz Tower became known as Sutton Place. On May 7, 1932, the River Book House opened at 444 East 58th Street, by E. R. Armstrong and J. M. Wolcott. Announced in Publishers Weekly as a new neighborhood bookshop, it was styled to serve the growing Sutton Place community and took its name from the nearby East River.

== See also ==
Sutton Place, Manhattan
George F. Pelham
Beaux-Arts architecture in New York City
Architecture of New York City
List of buildings, sites, and monuments in New York City

== Further reading ==
Dolkart, Andrew S. Guide to New York City Landmarks. 4th ed., Hoboken: John Wiley & Sons, 2009. ISBN 978-0470289631.
Gray, Christopher. New York Streetscapes: Tales of Manhattan's Significant Buildings and Landmarks. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 2003. ISBN 978-0810944418.
Stern, Robert A. M.; Gilmartin, Gregory; Mellins, Thomas. New York 1900: Metropolitan Architecture and Urbanism 1890–1915. New York: Rizzoli, 1983. ISBN 978-0847804534.
White, Norval; Willensky, Elliot; Leadon, Fran. AIA Guide to New York City. 5th ed., New York: Oxford University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-0195383867.

== References ==

One Sutton Place South is a residential building facing the East River and Sutton Place Park in the neighborhood of Sutton Place in Manhattan, New York City, United States.

== History ==
The building was designed in 1926–1927 by Walter Binger Chambers in the Italianate-Renaissance style of architecture and is 10 stories tall with 32 apartments.

The building is not to be confused with the nearby buildings called 1 Sutton Place (which was once a single-family home, but is now multi-dwelling units) and Sutton Place One (a senior citizens residence), both of which are in neighboring Midtown East. The building is also now called The Brittany, to prevent confusion with 1 Sutton Place. (A new residential condominium, under construction since 2016, immediately to the north at 430 East 58th Street is being branded as "One Sutton Place North.")

Other nearby notable buildings are Sutton Terrace at 415-417 East 56th Street by architect Mario Domino; Riverview Terrace at 419-421 East 55th Street, also by Domino; and Sutton Manor Apartments, at 417-425 East 56th Street by architect H. I. Feldman.

== The Brittany and River Book House ==
The Brittany Apartments are a 7-story elevator building at 442 East 58th Street/10 Sutton Place. On May 7, 1932, the River Book House opened at 444 East 58th Street, by E. R. Armstrong and J. M. Wolcott. Announced in Publishers Weekly as a new neighborhood bookshop, it was styled to serve the growing Sutton Place community and took its name from the nearby East River.

== See also ==
Sutton Place, Manhattan
George F. Pelham
Beaux-Arts architecture in New York City
Architecture of New York City
List of buildings, sites, and monuments in New York City

== Further reading ==
Dolkart, Andrew S. Guide to New York City Landmarks. 4th ed., Hoboken: John Wiley & Sons, 2009. ISBN 978-0470289631.
Gray, Christopher. New York Streetscapes: Tales of Manhattan's Significant Buildings and Landmarks. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 2003. ISBN 978-0810944418.
Stern, Robert A. M.; Gilmartin, Gregory; Mellins, Thomas. New York 1900: Metropolitan Architecture and Urbanism 1890–1915. New York: Rizzoli, 1983. ISBN 978-0847804534.
White, Norval; Willensky, Elliot; Leadon, Fran. AIA Guide to New York City. 5th ed., New York: Oxford University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-0195383867.

== References ==

response_text:
39 West 67th Street is a six-story residential building in the Lincoln Square neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City. Designed by artist and architect Léon Solon in the Northern Renaissance Revival style, it was completed in 1919. The structure is a double-wide "artists' cooperative," the second of its kind in New York following the earlier building at 130 West 57th Street. It features a distinctive polychromatic glazed terra-cotta facade and decorative lobby designed by Solon, as well as unique duplex apartments with double-height studios. The building was designated a New York City Landmark on November 17, 2015, and added to the National Register of Historic Places on September 11, 2018.

== History ==
39 West 67th Street is located in the Manhattan Valley area of the Upper West Side. In the early 1900s, the blocks between West 66th and 67th Streets (now part of Lincoln Square) began attracting middle-class families, artists, and musicians. The area was affordable and relatively quiet, drawing residents from the theater world who worked at nearby Carnegie Hall and the Metropolitan Opera. By the early 20th century, construction of specialized studio buildings for artists was becoming common in Manhattan. The earliest studio buildings clustered near Washington Square and Union Square in the 1850s and 1860s. By the 1900s, developers began constructing cooperative studio apartments on the Upper West Side, catering to professional painters, sculptors, and illustrators. Cooperatives allowed resident-owners to purchase shares in the building, avoiding high rents and offering long-term stability.

39 West 67th Street was developed by the artist and architect Léon Solon, along with two of his future tenants, photographer Hugh R. Monaghan and painter and director Mario A. Braggiotti. The building was financed through a $95,000 mortgage from the Greenwich Savings Bank and completed in 1919. Solon designed the facade and supervised the construction. From its opening in 1919 until his death in 1957, Solon maintained a studio-residence in the building, which served as both a home and a workspace. According to his obituary in The New York Times, Solon "designed and built 39 West 67th Street, one of the early and most successful ventures in cooperative residential management."

In the 1920s, several residents were active in the arts, including dancer and choreographer Gloria Braggiotti Etting and lyricist Jerry Seelen. By the 1940s and 1950s, the building continued to house creative professionals. Esti Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud, lived in the building in the 1950s and worked as a speech pathologist. In later decades, the building retained its cooperative character, and in 1984, the remaining mortgage from its initial construction was retired. The cooperative celebrated becoming mortgage-free with a "mortgage-burning party," marking the building's complete transition to full resident ownership. == Architecture == The building is six stories tall and occupies a mid-block site on the north side of West 67th Street. It is a double-wide structure, spanning two standard 25-foot New York City lots for a total width of approximately 50 feet. The design incorporates elements of the Northern Renaissance Revival style, a departure from the typical Beaux-Arts or Gothic styles common in earlier New York studio buildings. The facade is clad in polychromatic glazed terra-cotta, with ornamental panels and decorative details typical of Solon's work in ceramic design. Decorative elements include stylized cartouches, floral motifs, and symmetrically arranged ornament concentrated on the upper floors. The building features a distinctive entrance lobby with ceramic tile work designed by Solon. The interior includes decorative tilework, an ornamental staircase, and original built-in cabinetry. The layout is notable for its duplex apartments, each with double-height north-facing studios. These double-height spaces, ranging between 14 and 18 feet in ceiling height, provided artists with ample natural light and working space. Large arched windows facing north allowed for consistent indirect light, a preferred condition for visual artists. Each studio is accessed via an internal staircase from the lower-floor living quarters. The building contains 26 apartment units, significantly more than typical artists' cooperatives of the era, which usually featured fewer, larger units. The smaller unit sizes allowed for a more diverse group of residents and made ownership more affordable. Léon Solon's design reflected a practical approach to cooperative housing, balancing artistic ideals with economic realities.

== Designation and landmark status ==
On November 17, 2015, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designated 39 West 67th Street as an individual New York City Landmark. In its designation report, the commission noted the building's importance as "an outstanding example of a cooperative studio apartment building from the early 20th century" and praised Solon's "striking use of polychromatic glazed terra-cotta." The building was subsequently added to the National Register of Historic Places on September 11, 2018, under Criterion C for its architectural significance and for its association with the development of cooperative housing in Manhattan.

== Léon Solon ==
Léon Victor Solon (1872–1957) was a British-born artist, ceramicist, and architect known for his work in decorative arts and architectural ceramics. Born in Stoke-on-Trent, England, into a family connected to the ceramic industry, he trained at the South Kensington School of Art and initially worked for Mintons Ltd, a prominent English pottery manufacturer. In 1909, Solon immigrated to the United States and eventually settled in New York City. In America, Solon became a leading figure in the field of architectural polychrome, designing ceramic and tile installations for commercial and residential buildings. His work emphasized color, texture, and ornamentation, often incorporating elements of Arts and Crafts, Art Nouveau, and Renaissance revival styles. He also wrote extensively on the theory and application of color in architecture. His most notable projects include ceramic installations in the Woolworth Building and contributions to decorative arts exhibitions in the United States and Europe. Solon became director of design at the American Encaustic Tiling Company and was a member of several professional organizations, including the Architectural League of New York and the Society of Arts and Crafts. In addition to his work as a designer, Solon was an advocate for cooperative housing, seeing it as a solution to high urban rents and instability. His decision to design and live in a cooperative building reflected his broader commitment to social and artistic ideals.

== Cooperative structure and resident ownership ==
39 West 67th Street was organized as a housing cooperative, a relatively novel form of residential ownership in early 20th-century New York. Residents purchased shares in the building corporation rather than owning individual units outright. This structure allowed for collective decision-making, shared maintenance responsibilities, and long-term affordability. The cooperative model was particularly appealing to artists and other creative professionals who valued stability and community. Ownership shares were sold to initial residents in 1919, and the cooperative operated continuously under resident control. In 1984, the building celebrated paying off its original $95,000 construction mortgage from Greenwich Savings Bank. At a ceremony attended by residents, the mortgage document was symbolically burned, marking the building's achievement of becoming fully debt-free. The cooperative has maintained its original governance structure, with a board of directors elected from among the shareholders. Decisions regarding maintenance, improvements, and financial management are made collectively by the residents. This model has allowed the building to remain accessible to middle-income residents, in contrast to many similar buildings that converted to condominiums or were sold to commercial developers.

== Cultural and social context ==
At the time of its construction, 39 West 67th Street was part of a broader movement in New York City toward cooperative housing and purpose-built artists' studios. The early 20th century saw a shift in the demographics of the Upper West Side, as affordable rents and proximity to cultural institutions attracted writers, painters, musicians, and theater professionals. The area between West 66th and 67th Streets became known for its concentration of artists' cooperatives and studio buildings, forming a distinctive cultural enclave within Manhattan. The building reflects Progressive Era ideals about housing reform, cooperative economics, and the role of the arts in urban life. The cooperative model was seen by reformers as a way to provide stable, affordable housing and foster community engagement. Buildings like 39 West 67th Street offered an alternative to speculative real estate development and absentee landlordism. Residents of 39 West 67th Street participated actively in New York's cultural life throughout the 20th century. Several were involved in dance, theater, music, and visual arts. The building's design, with its emphasis on natural light, generous studio space, and communal governance, supported creative work and fostered a sense of shared purpose among residents.

== Preservation and current status ==
Following its designation as a New York City Landmark in 2015 and its listing on the National Register of Historic Places in 2018, 39 West 67th Street has been recognized as an architecturally and historically significant building. The landmark designation provides legal protection against exterior alterations and demolition, ensuring that the building's distinctive facade and original design features are preserved. The building remains an active residential cooperative. Current residents continue the tradition of cooperative governance, maintaining the building's original character while addressing the practical needs of a century-old structure. Preservation efforts have focused on retaining Solon's decorative tilework, facade ornamentation, and interior features, including the lobby and stairwell. The building's landmark status has also raised awareness of the history of artists' cooperatives in New York City and the role of cooperative housing in providing affordable and stable homes for creative professionals. As real estate values in Manhattan have increased, buildings like 39 West 67th Street have become rare examples of intact, resident-owned cooperative housing. The building is considered an important example of early 20th-century cooperative housing and artists' studio design. Its preservation contributes to the architectural and cultural heritage of the Upper West Side and offers a tangible connection to the Progressive Era ideals that shaped its creation.

== Mortgage retirement and financial independence ==
One of the defining moments in the building's history occurred in 1984, when the cooperative paid off the original $95,000 mortgage issued by Greenwich Savings Bank in 1919. This achievement was celebrated with a mortgage-burning ceremony, attended by residents and former shareholders. The event symbolized the building's financial independence and the success of the cooperative model. Paying off the mortgage allowed the cooperative to reduce maintenance fees and gain greater control over the building's finances. It also reinforced the sense of community ownership and collective accomplishment among residents. The 1984 ceremony was covered by local press and highlighted as an example of the long-term viability of cooperative housing. Since retiring the mortgage, the building has operated without long-term debt, relying on maintenance fees and reserve funds to cover operating expenses and capital improvements. This financial model has contributed to the building's stability and allowed it to remain affordable relative to comparable properties in the area. The cooperative's financial independence also reflects broader trends in the history of New York housing cooperatives. Many early cooperatives struggled with debt and financial mismanagement, leading to conversions or sales. The success of 39 West 67th Street in achieving and maintaining financial stability is a testament to the commitment of its residents and the strength of its governance structure. Today, the building remains entirely resident-owned and continues to operate on a cooperative basis. Financial decisions are made collectively, and residents share responsibility for the building's upkeep and long-term planning. The cooperative's financial health has been a key factor in its ability to preserve the building's architectural integrity and resist external development pressures.

== Architectural legacy ==
39 West 67th Street is considered an important example of Léon Solon's architectural work and of early 20th-century cooperative housing design. The building's use of polychromatic glazed terra-cotta and its integration of decorative arts into residential architecture reflect Solon's background in ceramic design and his commitment to color and ornamentation. The building's facade, with its stylized ornament and Northern Renaissance Revival detailing, stands out among the more restrained or historicist buildings in the neighborhood. Solon's design represents a synthesis of European decorative traditions and American pragmatism, combining aesthetic ambition with functional planning. The duplex studio apartments are a notable feature of the building's design. These spaces allowed residents to live and work in the same unit, with separate areas for domestic life and artistic production. The large north-facing windows provided optimal lighting conditions for painters and other visual artists, while the double-height ceilings created a sense of openness and grandeur. The building's layout, with 26 relatively small units, was innovative for its time. Earlier studio cooperatives typically featured fewer, larger apartments designed for established artists. Solon's design accommodated a broader range of residents, including younger artists, musicians, and other professionals who could afford smaller units. This approach anticipated later trends in cooperative housing and urban residential design. The decorative tilework in the entrance lobby and stairwells is another significant aspect of the building's architectural legacy. Solon designed custom ceramic tiles and ornamental panels that complement the exterior facade and create a cohesive aesthetic throughout the building. These decorative elements reflect Solon's expertise in ceramic arts and his belief in the integration of art and architecture.

== Influence on cooperative housing ==
39 West 67th Street contributed to the development of cooperative housing in New York City and served as a model for later artists' cooperatives. The building demonstrated that cooperative ownership was financially viable and could provide long-term stability for middle-income residents. Its success encouraged the construction of similar buildings in the 1920s and 1930s. The cooperative model adopted at 39 West 67th Street influenced the governance structures of later housing cooperatives. Resident-controlled boards, collective decision-making, and shared financial responsibility became standard features of cooperative housing in New York. The building's emphasis on community and mutual support also reflected broader Progressive Era ideals about social reform and collective action. Artists' cooperatives, in particular, benefited from the example set by 39 West 67th Street. The building showed that purpose-built studio spaces could be economically feasible and that artists could organize collectively to secure affordable housing. This model was replicated in other parts of Manhattan and in other cities with active arts communities. The building's long-term survival and financial independence also provided a counterexample to critics of cooperative housing, who argued that such arrangements were impractical or unsustainable. By maintaining resident ownership and paying off its mortgage, 39 West 67th Street demonstrated the resilience and adaptability of the cooperative model.

== Notable residents ==
Over the course of its history, 39 West 67th Street has been home to a diverse group of artists, musicians, writers, and other professionals. Notable residents have included:

* Léon Solon (1872–1957), the building's architect and designer, who maintained a studio-residence in the building from 1919 until his death.
* Mario A. Braggiotti (1909–1996), a painter, film director, and one of the building's original co-developers.
* Gloria Braggiotti Etting (1909–1999), a dancer, choreographer, and dance instructor, sister of Mario Braggiotti.
* Hugh R. Monaghan, a photographer and one of the building's original co-developers.
* Jerry Seelen (1913–1982), a lyricist and songwriter known for his work in popular music and film.
* Esti Freud (1896–1980), daughter of Sigmund Freud, who lived in the building in the 1950s and worked as a speech pathologist.

These residents contributed to the building's reputation as a hub of artistic and intellectual activity. The diversity of their professions reflects the cooperative's inclusive approach to membership and its appeal to a broad range of creative professionals.

== Physical condition and maintenance ==
As a century-old building, 39 West 67th Street has required ongoing maintenance and occasional restoration to preserve its architectural features and ensure its structural integrity. The cooperative has undertaken several major projects over the years, including facade repairs, roof replacement, and upgrades to mechanical and electrical systems. Preservation of the building's terra-cotta facade has been a priority for the cooperative. Glazed terra-cotta is durable but susceptible to water damage and weathering over time. The cooperative has worked with preservation specialists to repair and restore damaged sections of the facade, ensuring that Solon's original decorative scheme is maintained. Interior preservation efforts have focused on retaining original features such as tilework, woodwork, and built-in cabinetry. The entrance lobby, with its custom ceramic tiles designed by Solon, has been carefully maintained and restored. The duplex studios have also been preserved, with residents making updates to kitchens and bathrooms while respecting the original layout and design. The cooperative has balanced preservation with the need for modernization. Upgrades to plumbing, heating, and electrical systems have been undertaken to meet contemporary standards, while minimizing impact on historic fabric. Windows have been repaired or replaced in kind, maintaining the building's original appearance. The cooperative's commitment to preservation has been supported by its landmark designation, which provides access to technical guidance and, in some cases, financial incentives for restoration work. The building's continued good condition is a testament to the dedication of its residents and the effectiveness of cooperative governance in managing long-term maintenance.

== Community and cooperative governance ==
The cooperative governance structure at 39 West 67th Street has been central to the building's success and longevity. Residents participate in decision-making through a board of directors elected from among the shareholders. The board is responsible for financial management, maintenance planning, and enforcement of building policies. Regular meetings of the shareholders provide a forum for discussion and collective decision-making. This participatory approach has fostered a strong sense of community and shared responsibility among residents. Decisions regarding major expenditures, renovations, and building policies are made collectively, with input from all shareholders. The cooperative's governance structure has also contributed to social cohesion within the building. Residents have organized social events, including the 1984 mortgage-burning party, and have maintained informal networks of mutual support. This sense of community has been a defining characteristic of the building throughout its history. The cooperative model has also provided residents with a degree of stability and control not available to renters or condominium owners. Because the cooperative is governed by residents rather than external landlords or management companies, decisions are made with the long-term interests of the community in mind. This has allowed the building to resist external pressures and maintain its character over time. The success of the cooperative at 39 West 67th Street offers lessons for contemporary housing policy and urban planning. It demonstrates that resident-controlled housing can be financially sustainable, socially beneficial, and architecturally significant. The building serves as a model for cooperative housing and a reminder of the potential for collective action to address housing challenges.

== Context within the Upper West Side ==
39 West 67th Street is located within a historically significant area of the Upper West Side, known for its concentration of artists' studios, theaters, and cultural institutions. The blocks between West 66th and 67th Streets, now part of Lincoln Square, were developed in the early 20th century as a residential neighborhood for artists and middle-class families. The area's proximity to Central Park, Carnegie Hall, and the Metropolitan Opera made it attractive to musicians, painters, and theater professionals. Several other notable buildings in the vicinity share the building's history as artists' cooperatives or studio buildings. The construction of Lincoln Center in the 1960s transformed the neighborhood, leading to significant redevelopment and changes in the area's character. The survival of 39 West 67th Street, along with a few other studio buildings, provides a tangible link to the neighborhood's pre-Lincoln Center history. Today, the area around 39 West 67th Street is characterized by a mix of residential, cultural, and commercial uses. The building's landmark status and cooperative governance have helped it maintain its original character amid broader changes in the neighborhood. It stands as a reminder of the Upper West Side's artistic heritage and the role of cooperative housing in shaping the area's development.

== Comparative analysis ==
39 West 67th Street can be compared to other artists' cooperative buildings in New York City, particularly those constructed in the early 20th century. Similar buildings include the building at 130 West 57th Street, often cited as New York's first artists' cooperative, and the building at 27 West 67th Street, which also features duplex studio apartments. These buildings share common characteristics, including double-height studios, north-facing windows, and cooperative ownership structures. They reflect a broader trend in early 20th-century New York toward purpose-built housing for artists and the adoption of cooperative governance models. However, 39 West 67th Street is distinguished by its architectural design, particularly its use of polychromatic glazed terra-cotta and Northern Renaissance Revival styling. The Wyoming is a cooperative apartment building located at 853 Seventh Avenue at the corner of 55th Street in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It was built in 1905–1906 and was designed by the architects Harde & Short, with a steel structure and a brick, limestone, and terra-cotta façade. The architectural style has been described as "Arts and Crafts with a strong Elizabethan influence, unusual for its time and place." The Wyoming is one of the few surviving buildings from the era when the middle section of Seventh Avenue had the nickname "Montana Circle," because so many buildings there (e.g., the Montana and the Leonia) had Western names.

== Tenancy ==
Tenants of The Wyoming have included notable figures from the arts and sciences.

== Building debt ==
In 1981, The Wyoming became the last of a group of co-operative apartment buildings—among them the Wyoming, Parc Vendôme, Windsor Tower, Southgate, and 88 Central Park West—to rid itself of a decades-old underlying mortgage. In 1925, Leo B. White and H.F. Ingraham, prominent apartment-house operators, helped organize resident ownership at The Wyoming, and issued shares without voting provisions. The result was that a self-elected board, whose members were not shareholders, controlled the building. Although the corporation paid off its 1925 bond debt in 1947, the building remained heavily indebted. In 1980, when The Wyoming had a debt of $750,000, the shareholders finally challenged the board and elected their own representative board of directors. A year later, the building was able to be debt-free.

== Tenants and demographics ==

=== 1910 census ===
In 1910, the U.S. census recorded primarily immigrant families from Austria, Bohemia, Russia, England, Romania, Germany, Holland, Switzerland, and Armenia. Heads of household included bakers, machinists, hatmakers, merchants, decorators, hotel workers, carpenters, plumbers, policemen, bartenders, dressmakers, and janitors. A total of 82 people lived in the building, averaging 3.15 persons per apartment.

=== 1920 census ===
The 1920 census recorded a higher proportion of U.S.-born residents, alongside immigrants from Bavaria, Germany, Russia, Puerto Rico, Austria, Hungary, Canada, England, Ireland, Holland, Poland, and Slovakia. Occupations included plumbers, cigar makers, librarians, taxi drivers, bakers, clerks, barbers, teachers, druggists, and jewelers. 94 people lived in the building, averaging 3.62 per apartment.

=== 1930 census ===
The 1930 census listed tenants from Sweden, Russia, Norway, Holland, Canada, Germany, England, Italy, the Philippines, and Northern Ireland. Professions included building superintendent, glass glazer, fur cutter, grocery owner, teacher, hotel chef, film director, musician (Mario Braggiotti), and dance instructor (Gloria Braggiotti Etting). 66 people lived in the building, averaging 2.53 per apartment.

=== 1940 census ===
By 1940, the census reflected fewer immigrants, with residents from France, England, Sweden, Wales, Germany, Austria, and Hungary. Occupations included draftsman, advertising publisher, radio writer, teacher, fashion artist, songwriter (Jerry Seelen), and real estate manager. 57 people lived in the building, averaging 2.19 per apartment.

=== 1950 census ===
The first post–World War II census recorded residents from Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Austria, France, Germany, and Canada. Occupations included painter, speech pathologist (Esti Freud), broadcasting editor, clothing

response_text: GJ 1289 b is a sub-Neptune exoplanet orbiting the red dwarf star GJ 1289, located approximately 8.86 parsecs (≈29 light-years) from the Sun. It was discovered using radial-velocity measurements with the near-infrared spectropolarimeter SPIRou at the Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope over multiple years, revealing a minimum mass of 6.27 ± 1.25 Earth masses and a nearly circular orbit with a period of 111.74 days. The host star, an M4.5V fully convective red dwarf with a mass of 0.21 solar masses, exhibits a strong large-scale dipolar magnetic field of 200–240 G and a rotation period of ~73.7 days, which is distinct from the planet's orbital period. The planet's orbital distance places it beyond the conventional habitable zone of its cool, low-luminosity host, though it may still have a temperate atmosphere, making it a target for further study. Its discovery is notable for demonstrating the detection of planets around fully convective M dwarfs, whose magnetic activity differs significantly from that of partly convective stars, and for showing that low-amplitude radial-velocity signals can be reliably extracted even in the presence of strong stellar magnetic fields. == References ==

Alan Robert Muir Kerr (born 1933) is a retired New Zealand cardiothoracic surgeon. He worked at Green Lane Hospital in Auckland from 1969 to 1998. In 2001, at the age of 68 years, he began working in the West Bank and Gaza as a volunteer paediatric cardiac surgeon with the Palestine Children's Relief Fund, continuing this work until 2018. 

== Early life and family ==
Kerr is the son of Mary Emma Kerr (née Mason) and John Kerr, a Presbyterian minister. He has two brothers, Ian Kerr a former All Black, and Donald Kerr who became professor of physics at University of Stirling in Scotland. He is married to Hazel Kerr (née McKenzie), a teacher and artist.

== Education and career ==
Kerr went to Waitaki Boys' High School in Oamaru. He studied medicine at University of Otago graduating with a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery (MB ChB) in 1956. In 1960 he travelled to the United Kingdom to specialise in cardiothoracic surgery. He was an anatomy demonstrator at University of London for two years and then spent three years training in paediatric surgery at Great Ormond Street Hospital, and in cardiac surgery at Guy's Hospital and in Liverpool. In 1964 he became a Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. He returned to New Zealand and worked at National Women's Hospital before being appointed to a full-time cardiothoracic surgical position at Green Lane in 1969.

He worked in the cardio-thoracic surgical team with Brian Barratt-Boyes and was one of the surgeons who performed the first heart-lung bypass operation at Green Lane in 1958. Staff from Green Lane hosted and trained doctors from overseas and visited foreign hospitals In 1981 Kerr visited hospitals in New Delhi and Madras (now Chennai) doing cardiopulmonary bypass operations and delivering training in cardiac surgery.

A special supplement of the New Zealand Medical Journal, published in 2001, honoured the work of Kerr and five other cardiology and cardiothoracic consultants: Trevor Agnew, Pat Clarkson, John Mercer, John Neutze, and Toby Whitlock.

== Work in Palestine ==
In 2001 Kerr joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza working in Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem, Palestine Medical Complex in Ramallah and Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza. As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed.

In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. The film The Doctor's Wife was released in 2025.

== Honours and awards ==
Kerr was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, for services to cardiothoracic surgery, in the 1997 New Year Honours.

== Selected works ==

Alan Robert Kerr (born 1929) is a New Zealand paediatric cardiac surgeon. He was part of the team that performed New Zealand's first heart-lung bypass operation in 1958 at Green Lane Hospital in Auckland. In 2001 he joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza.

== Early life and family ==
Born in 1929, Kerr grew up in Wellington. His father was a pharmacist who owned Kerr's chemist shop in Eastbourne, Lower Hutt. Kerr attended Wellington College and in 1947 began medical studies at Otago University. He graduated with a MB ChB in 1952 and three years later completed a Diploma in Obstetrics and then a MD in 1959. In 1957 he married Hazel Kerr (née Dawson, later Robertson), who was a fellow doctor training in Obstetrics and Gynaecology. Alan and Hazel had two children.

== Career ==

=== Early career ===
After graduating from medical school Kerr did his surgical training working as a surgical registrar at Wellington Hospital and then at Middlemore Hospital. During this time, he worked under Auckland cardiac surgeon Douglas Robb. Kerr went to the United Kingdom for three years where he worked at Guy's Hospital in London as a surgical registrar and as a resident surgical officer at The Hospital for Sick Children at Great Ormond Street. On his return to New Zealand, Kerr took up a surgical position at Green Lane in 1969. He worked in the cardio-thoracic surgical team with Brian Barratt-Boyes and was one of the surgeons who performed the first heart-lung bypass operation at Green Lane in 1958. Staff from Green Lane hosted and trained doctors from overseas and visited foreign hospitals In 1981 Kerr visited hospitals in New Delhi and Madras (now Chennai) doing cardiopulmonary bypass operations and delivering training in cardiac surgery. A special supplement of the New Zealand Medical Journal, published in 2001, honoured the work of Kerr and five other cardiology and cardiothoracic consultants: Trevor Agnew, Pat Clarkson, John Mercer, John Neutze, and Toby Whitlock.

== Work in Palestine ==
In 2001 Kerr joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza working in Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem, Palestine Medical Complex in Ramallah and Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza. As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed. In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. The film The Doctor's Wife was released in 2025.

== Honours and awards ==
Kerr was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, for services to cardiothoracic surgery, in the 1997 New Year Honours.

== Selected works ==

I Don't Know How (stylised as I DON'T KNOW HOW) is the debut studio album by Australian singer-songwriter Tate McRae, released on May 16, 2025, through RCA Records. The album, produced primarily by Ryan Tedder, marks a departure from the dance-pop sound of her previous work, exploring themes of heartbreak, self-discovery, and personal growth through a more introspective lens.

== Background ==
Following the commercial success of her 2023 EP Think Later, which spawned the hit single "Greedy", McRae began working on her debut album in late 2023. In interviews, she described the album as a "coming-of-age story" that chronicles her experiences navigating fame, relationships, and her early twenties. The title I Don't Know How reflects the uncertainty and vulnerability that permeates the record.

== Production and writing ==
The album was primarily produced by Ryan Tedder, known for his work with Adele, Beyoncé, and Taylor Swift. Additional production came from Greg Kurstin, Jack Antonoff, and Noah Goldstein. McRae co-wrote all 14 tracks on the album, collaborating with artists and songwriters including Lorde, Amy Allen, and Julia Michaels.

The recording process took place across multiple studios in Los Angeles, New York, and London over a span of 18 months. McRae has stated that the album's sound was influenced by artists like Joni Mitchell, Fleetwood Mac, and Lana Del Rey, as well as contemporary acts like Olivia Rodrigo and Gracie Abrams.

== Music and lyrics ==
I Don't Know How showcases a more mature and sonically diverse sound compared to McRae's earlier work. The album blends elements of indie pop, folk, and alternative rock, with stripped-back production that emphasizes McRae's vocals and lyrical storytelling.

Lyrically, the album explores themes of romantic disillusionment, the pressures of fame, and the search for identity. Opening track "Burning Bridges" sets the tone with its confessional lyrics about ending toxic relationships, while lead single "Ghost of You" is a haunting ballad about lingering feelings for an ex-lover. Other standout tracks include "Twenty-Three", a reflective acoustic piece about the challenges of growing up in the public eye, and "Parallel Lines", an uptempo indie-pop anthem about two people who can never quite connect.

The album's title track, "I Don't Know How", serves as its emotional centerpiece. Featuring just McRae's voice and a piano, the song captures the vulnerability and confusion of not having all the answers—a recurring theme throughout the record.

== Release and promotion ==
The album was announced on February 14, 2025, with the release of lead single "Ghost of You". The music video, directed by Hannah Lux Davis, features McRae wandering through an abandoned mansion, symbolizing her emotional isolation. The single debuted at number 12 on the Billboard Hot 100 and reached the top 10 in several countries.

A second single, "Parallel Lines", was released on March 28, 2025, accompanied by a lyric video. McRae performed the song on Saturday Night Live on April 5, 2025, marking her debut on the show.

To promote the album, McRae embarked on the I Don't Know How Tour, beginning in June 2025. The tour includes dates across North America, Europe, and Australia, with special guests Gracie Abrams and Reneé Rapp on select dates.

== Commercial performance ==
I Don't Know How debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, selling 185,000 album-equivalent units in its first week, marking McRae's first number-one album. It also topped the charts in Canada, Australia, and the United Kingdom. The album was certified Gold by the RIAA within three weeks of its release.

"Ghost of You" became McRae's highest-charting single, peaking at number 4 on the Billboard Hot 100. It also reached number one on the Adult Pop Airplay chart and accumulated over 500 million streams on Spotify within two months.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How received widespread critical acclaim upon release. On Metacritic, the album holds a score of 85 out of 100, based on 25 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim". Critics praised McRae's maturity as a songwriter and her willingness to explore more vulnerable themes.

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Sophie Wilde and Leo Woodall. The film is partially shot on iPhone.

== Plot ==
In the summer of 2004, 21-year-old university students June and John meet in New York City, sparking an immediate connection. Over the course of a single night, they explore the city together, sharing secrets and dreams before they eventually spend the night together. The next morning, June disappears, leaving John with unanswered questions. As the years pass, their paths cross again in unexpected ways: June as a rising pop star and John as a writer in London. They reconnect in France after more than a decade apart, where memories of their fateful first night resurface. Though their lives have taken different directions, their bond endures, forcing them to confront unresolved feelings and decide if they can find a way back to each other.

== Cast ==
* Sophie Wilde as June
* Leo Woodall as John

== Production ==
The film was shot on iPhone 16 Pro, marking one of the first major films to use Apple's latest smartphone. Besson praised the device's cinematic capabilities, stating, "The iPhone 16 Pro gave us a freedom and intimacy we couldn't have achieved with traditional cameras. It allowed us to capture raw emotion in a way that feels fresh and immediate." The film premiered at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival.

== Release ==
The world premiere took place at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on 13 February 2025. The film was acquired by Neon for distribution in North America.

== Reception ==
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 27% of 11 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 4.8/10.

Tim Grierson of Screen International wrote "It's a narrative and stylistic gamble that doesn't quite pay off. Despite solid performances from Sophie Wilde and Leo Woodall, the film's experimental iPhone cinematography often feels more like a gimmick than a genuine artistic choice. The handheld aesthetic, while occasionally lending an intimate rawness to certain scenes, frequently devolves into visual chaos—shaky framing, inconsistent lighting, and a lack of depth that makes the picture feel more like an expensive home video than a festival-worthy feature. Besson's attempt to marry old-school romanticism with modern technological experimentation ends up undermining both. The chemistry between the leads is palpable, but the film's structure—a fragmented, time-jumping narrative—never quite gels. Scenes that should resonate emotionally instead feel rushed or unearned, as if the script was more interested in chasing aesthetic moments than building genuine character depth. By the time we reach the inevitable reunion in France, the emotional stakes feel hollow. It's a love story that wants to be profound but ultimately feels superficial, a technical experiment that prioritises innovation over coherence."

Wendy Ide of Screen Daily wrote "One of the more perplexing entries in this year's Berlinale competition, June & John is a film that seems determined to sabotage its own potential at every turn. Luc Besson, once a master of visually striking cinema, here opts for an iPhone-shot aesthetic that strips away any sense of cinematic grandeur. The result is a film that looks less like a carefully composed work of art and more like a series of Instagram stories stitched together with the thinnest of narrative threads. Sophie Wilde and Leo Woodall do what they can with underwritten roles, but they're fighting a losing battle against a script that mistakes vagueness for depth. The dialogue is often painfully on-the-nose, with characters speaking in the kind of faux-poetic platitudes that might sound profound in a first-year creative writing class but fall flat on screen. The time-jumping structure, rather than adding layers of complexity, only serves to muddy an already thin plot. By the time the film limps to its inevitable, saccharine conclusion, any goodwill generated by the occasional striking image or genuine moment of connection has long evaporated. June & John is a film that wants to say something meaningful about love, time, and connection, but it never figures out what that something is."

Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter wrote "Besson's latest is a curious misfire, a film that feels simultaneously overambitious and undercooked. The decision to shoot on iPhone, while admirable in its democratising spirit, ultimately becomes a distraction. The film's visual language is so inconsistent—veering from dreamy, soft-focus romanticism to jittery, handheld realism—that it's hard to settle into any kind of emotional rhythm. Wilde and Woodall share a few genuinely tender moments, but they're too few and far between to sustain a nearly two-hour runtime. The script, which Besson wrote himself, is frustratingly uneven. It wants to be a sweeping, decades-spanning romance, but it lacks the emotional heft to pull it off. Instead, we get a series of vignettes that feel more like sketches than fully realised scenes. The film's best moments come when it slows down and lets the actors simply exist in a space together, but these are rare. More often, Besson seems intent on dazzling us with technique, cutting frantically between timelines and perspectives in a way that feels more frantic than artful. By the end, June & John feels less like a cohesive film and more like a collection of ideas that never quite coalesced."

Robbie Collin of The Telegraph gave the film 2 stars out of 5, and wrote "There's something admirable about a director of Luc Besson's stature taking a risk—shooting a love story on an iPhone, no less—but admiration is about all June & John earns. This is a film that mistakes visual experimentation for emotional truth, and the result is a hollow, frustrating experience. The iPhone cinematography, rather than lending the film an intimate, verite quality, instead makes it feel cheap and unfocused. Scenes that should shimmer with romantic possibility are undermined by distracting technical limitations—blown-out highlights, murky shadows, and a depth of field so shallow that it's often unclear what we're even supposed to be looking at. The central romance between Sophie Wilde's June and Leo Woodall's John is meant to be the stuff of destiny, but the script never gives us a reason to care. Their initial meeting is a flurry of quirky banter and wistful glances, but it's all surface—there's no sense of who these people really are or why they're drawn to each other beyond the demands of the plot. The time-jumping structure, which sees the couple meeting, parting, and reuniting over the course of more than a decade, is meant to lend the story a sense of romantic inevitability, but it instead just feels repetitive. By the third or fourth reunion, it's hard not to wonder why these two don't just exchange phone numbers. Besson, who once crafted visually sumptuous epics like The Fifth Element, here seems content to coast on empty style. June & John is a film that looks and feels like it was made by someone who has forgotten what it's like to be in love—or, at the very least, has forgotten how to make us feel it."

Clarisse Fabre of Le Monde wrote "What ultimately lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

Lutz van Dijk (born 24 June 1955 in Berlin) is a Dutch-German writer and historian, who since 2001 has lived in South Africa and the Netherlands. He co-founded the projects Stichting Zuidelijk Afrika (Foundation Southern Africa) and HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa). Van Dijk has written books and novels on African and European history, as well as LGBT themes. He is openly gay.

== Life and work ==
Van Dijk studied history, sociology and pedagogy in Berlin, earning a PhD. In 1995, he was appointed the Anne Frank House lecturer at Freie Universität Berlin, and afterwards became a visiting lecturer at the University of Cape Town and University of Oldenburg. In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002.

== Awards and nominations ==
Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize.

== References ==

Lutz van Dijk (born 24 June 1955) is a Dutch-German author and historian who lives in Cape Town, South Africa, and Amsterdam, the Netherlands. He has published numerous books, both fiction and non-fiction, many dealing with oppressed groups. He also founded an organization to help South African children orphaned by AIDS, and is active in LGBTQ+ advocacy.

== Biography ==
Lutz van Dijk was born on 24 June 1955 in West Berlin, where he lived until he was 18. He then moved to the United States to live in New York City for two years. Between 1976 and 1981, he studied history, education sciences, and literary studies at the University of Göttingen in West Germany and at the University of Amsterdam. He completed his teaching degree in history in Amsterdam in 1981.

From 1982 to 1995, Van Dijk worked as a history teacher in Hamburg, Germany. During this time he also authored several books, including a book on oppression of homosexuals in Germany during the Nazi era. Following a stay as a guest researcher in Namibia at the end of the 1990s, he moved to Cape Town and switched to full-time writing and activism. According to a 2017 article in Gay City News, Van Dijk "chose to become a South African" citizen. Van Dijk teaches as honorary professor at the Carl von Ossietzky University of Oldenburg.

In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18.

In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002.

== Awards and nominations ==
Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize.

Volkspark Humboldthain is a public park in Berlin's Wedding district, established in the 1860s and expanded in the 20th century; it now covers about 29 hectares. It features a Nazi-era flak tower (partially demolished and now integrated into an artificial hill), formal gardens, sports facilities, and an outdoor swimming pool, and hosts seasonal events. It is also a notable bat habitat.

== History ==

=== Origins to WWII ===
The park was created between 1866 and 1876 under landscape architect Gustav Meyer, then director of Berlin's public gardens, as one of several "people's parks" (Volksparks) intended to provide recreation for working-class neighborhoods. Like the older Friedrichshain and Treptower Park, Humboldthain was funded by the city government in response to demands by James Hobrecht, chief of Berlin's Building Department. The site sloped down toward the Panke stream; by 1869–1870 the basic terraces and walks were laid out on about 7.5 hectares (18.5 acres).

Meyer's initial design opened onto a large meadow with groves of trees and winding paths; a small man-made pond was also planned. The park was named after explorer and geographer Alexander von Humboldt (its full name means "Humboldt's Grove").

By the 1890s, Humboldthain was extended to the northeast with new play areas and sports fields. In 1906 a formal rose garden was added near the park entrance. In the interwar years the park served as a popular leisure destination for families in Wedding.

On the southeastern side, a St. Paul's church stood; it was destroyed in World War II and never rebuilt.

=== Nazi era and WWII ===
Between 1941 and 1942, two huge reinforced-concrete flak towers (anti-aircraft gun towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits.

From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section.

=== Recent decades ===
Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats.

== Features ==

Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats.

Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure.

Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Operator Constantin Boese launched

Esperanza Fabon-Victorino (born May 4, 1964) is a Filipino lawyer and jurist who currently serves as an Associate Justice of the Court of Tax Appeals of the Philippines. 

== Early life and education ==
Victorino was born on May 4, 1964. She earned her Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from the University of the Philippines Diliman, graduating magna cum laude in 1985. She also graduated with honors in 1990, with a Bachelor of Laws from the Ateneo de Manila University School of Law. 

She was admitted to the Philippine Bar in 1991, and subsequently pursued graduate studies in law at the University of the Philippines College of Law, where she obtained a Master of Laws degree in 1998. She studied further at the Ateneo de Manila University School of Law, under the degree-program Doctor of Juridical Science, and was conferred the degree in 2004.

San Pedro earned her Bachelor of Laws degree from the Ateneo de Manila University School of Law in 1990 and was admitted to the Philippine Bar in 1991.

== Early career ==
San Pedro worked in various legal positions before her appointment to the judiciary. On July 11, 2019, she was appointed Associate Justice of the Court of Tax Appeals.
