response_text:
Eduard Joannides (March 7, 1844 – March 6, 1901), known by the pen name Eduard Johnson, was a German teacher of ancient languages and ancient history in Plauen. He is most famous for two philological works: ''Sprechen Sie Attisch?'' (1889) and ''Sprechen Sie Lateinisch?'' (1890), both of which were modern vernacular conversational phrasebooks in Ancient Greek and Latin, respectively.

==Biography==

Eduard Joannides was born in Burgstein (now known as Pöhl and part of Plauen) in the Vogtland. He graduated from Gymnasium Plauen as ''primus omnium'' (the top of his class) in 1863. He then enrolled at the University of Leipzig, where he studied philology with Friedrich Gottlieb Welcker. From 1870 he worked as a teacher at the Gymnasium in Plauen where he specialized in the classical languages. In 1897 he was forced into early retirement for health reasons.

During this period Eduard Joannides advocated for a humanistic ideal of education (Neuhumanismus), which emphasized classical languages as a fundamental educational principle. In two conversational handbooks, published under the alias of Eduard Johnson, Joannides devised the concept of using Ancient Greek and Latin to discuss modern life and institutions. For example, there were dialogues about such topics as cigars and railroads.

In 1890 Joannides moved to Dresden. He participated in Saxon regional history research, and worked with the Dresden chapter of the Verein für Geschiche Dresdens. He was also active in the Saxon organization ''Vogtländischer Altertumsforschender Verein.''

Joannides' son Ulrich was a painter, who notably illustrated his father's book about Burgstein. Ulrich died as a victim of political persecution in 1952 during the expansion of the inner-German border zone between East and West Germany.

== Works ==
E. Joannides: Sprechen Sie Attisch? Moderne Konversation in altgriechischer Umgangssprache nach den besten attischen Autoren. Koch, Leipzig 1889, Eduard Johnson is available for free viewing and download at the Internet Archive. Second edition [with "many additions" according to the Foreward] Auflage Koch, Dresden und Leipzig 1902. New edition revised, edited and expanded by Helmut Schareika: Ἆρ' ἀττικίζεις; – Sprechen Sie Attisch? Moderne Konversation in altgriechischer Umgangssprache, Buske, Hamburg 2012, ISBN 978-3875486377 Italian translation: Parlare greco oggi: Conversazione moderna in greco antico, a cura di Enrico Renna e Claudio Ferone, Fratelli Ariello editori, Napoli 1998. (No ISBN.)
Georg Capellanus: Sprechen Sie Lateinisch? Moderne Konversation in lateinischer Sprache. Koch, Leipzig 1890. 17. Auflage: Dümmler, Bonn 1999, ISBN 978-3-427-47056-4. PDF at Scribd Famous Book review (in German) of Sprechen Sie Lateinisch by Kurt Tucholsky, first published in Vossische Zeitung on June 23, 1925. Russian translation: Говорите ли Вы на латыни? / Георг Капеллан; пер. И. Р. Гимадеева, И. С. Селиванова; под ред. А. И. Солопова. — М.: Издательство книжной лавки «Листва», 2021. — 164 с. ISBN 978-5-6043461-6-7 English translation: Latin Can Be Fun (Facetiae Latinae): A Modern Conversational Guide (Sermo Hodiernus Antique Redditus). Translated by Peter Needham. London, Souvenir Press Ltd., 1977. ISBN 978-1566199919
Eduard Johnson: Geschichtliches über Burgstein im Vogtland und seine Umgebung. Wieprecht, Plauen 1897. Reprint: Vogtländischer Heimatverlag Neupert, Plauen 1990, ISBN 3-929039-03-6.
Eduard Johnson: Zur Lebensgeschichte des Kabinettsministers Detlev Grafen Einsiedel. In: Neues Archiv für sächsische Geschichte. Band 12, 1891, S.

220 West 98th Street is a historic apartment building located on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, New York City. Built in 1910, it is a seven-story structure designed in the Renaissance Revival architectural style. The building was designated a New York City Landmark in 2000 and is located within the West End–Collegiate Historic District.

== History ==
The building was constructed in 1910 by developer Herman Ascher, who commissioned architect Bernhard Riesenberg to design the structure. Riesenberg, known for his residential designs on the Upper West Side, created a façade featuring ornate terra cotta detailing, Classical columns, and decorative iron balconies. The building originally contained 26 apartments.

220 West 98th Street was part of the early 20th-century development boom on the Upper West Side, when the completion of the IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line subway in 1904 made the neighborhood more accessible. The building represented middle-class housing typical of the era, offering modern amenities such as elevators and steam heat.

In 1982, the building was converted to a housing cooperative, allowing residents to purchase their apartments and collectively own the property. The conversion was part of a broader trend in New York City during the 1980s, when many rental buildings were transformed into co-ops or condominiums.

The building underwent significant restoration work in the 1990s to preserve its architectural features and was officially designated a New York City Landmark by the Landmarks Preservation Commission on November 14, 2000. The designation recognized the building's architectural significance and its contribution to the character of the Upper West Side.

In 2015, the building completed a comprehensive façade restoration project, which included cleaning and repairing the terra cotta ornament, restoring the decorative ironwork, and repointing the brickwork. The $2.3 million project was funded through a combination of building reserves, a bank loan, and a capital assessment on shareholders.

== Architecture ==
The building is seven stories tall and is constructed of red brick with extensive terra cotta ornamentation. The Renaissance Revival style is evident in the symmetrical façade, which features a rusticated base, Classical columns, decorative cornices, and ornamental balconies. The entrance is marked by a projecting portico supported by paired Ionic columns.

The façade is divided into three horizontal sections: a two-story base, a three-story middle section, and a two-story upper section topped by a prominent cornice. Terra cotta panels featuring floral and geometric motifs are interspersed throughout the façade. The windows are arranged in a regular pattern, with those on the upper floors featuring decorative surrounds.

The building's interior retains many original features, including marble staircases, decorative plasterwork, and hardwood floors. The lobby features marble wainscoting, a coffered ceiling, and ornamental light fixtures. Many apartments retain original details such as built-in cabinetry, decorative moldings, and parquet floors.

== Cooperative ownership ==
220 West 98th Street was converted to a housing cooperative in 1982 under the Fink Weinberger Fredberg plan. The building currently has 26 apartments, ranging from studios to three-bedroom units. The cooperative is managed by a board of directors elected by shareholders.

The building's monthly maintenance fees cover property taxes, building insurance, staff salaries, utilities for common areas, and contributions to the reserve fund. The cooperative maintains strict financial policies and has consistently maintained strong reserve funds. As of 2023, the building carries no underlying mortgage and is considered to be debt-free.

=== 1910 census ===
In 1910, the U.S. census recorded primarily immigrant families from Austria, Bohemia, Russia, England, Romania, Germany, Holland, Switzerland, and Armenia. Heads of household included bakers, machinists, hatmakers, merchants, decorators, hotel workers, carpenters, plumbers, policemen, bartenders, dressmakers, and janitors. A total of 82 people lived in the building, averaging 3.15 persons per apartment.

=== 1920 census ===
The 1920 census recorded a higher proportion of U.S.-born residents, alongside immigrants from Bavaria, Germany, Russia, Puerto Rico, Austria, Hungary, Canada, England, Ireland, Holland, Poland, and Slovakia. Occupations included plumbers, cigar makers, librarians, taxi drivers, bakers, clerks, barbers, teachers, druggists, and jewelers. 94 people lived in the building, averaging 3.62 per apartment.

=== 1930 census ===
The 1930 census listed tenants from Sweden, Russia, Norway, Holland, Canada, Germany, England, Italy, the Philippines, and Northern Ireland. Professions included building superintendent, glass glazer, fur cutter, grocery owner, teacher, hotel chef, film director, musician (Mario Braggiotti), and dance instructor (Gloria Braggiotti Etting). 66 people lived in the building, averaging 2.53 per apartment.

=== 1940 census ===
By 1940, the census reflected fewer immigrants, with residents from France, England, Sweden, Wales, Germany, Austria, and Hungary. Occupations included draftsman, advertising publisher, radio writer, teacher, fashion artist, songwriter (Jerry Seelen), and real estate manager. 57 people lived in the building, averaging 2.19 per apartment.

response_text: Eleodoro Aniceto Torres Torres (5 February 1894 – 16 July 1972) was a Chilean politician and physician. == Biography == Torres was born in Vallenar, Atacama Province, the son of Juan de Dios Torres and Mercedes Torres. He studied at the Liceo in Vallenar and at the Internado Nacional Barros Arana in Santiago, then entered the School of Medicine of the University of Chile, graduating in 1917 with a thesis on the vaccination of children under one year. He furthered his medical training in the United States and Europe, traveling through England, France, Germany, Belgium and Italy. On his return to Chile, he worked in hospitals in Valparaíso, Copiapó and Santiago, where he became Director of San Luis Hospital (1934–1941). Torres also taught at the Schools of Social Service and Nursing of the University of Chile. He represented Chile in several international medical and health conferences, including the Sanitary Technique Congress of Milan (1930), the International Hospital Congress in Vienna (1931), and the International Labour Conference in Geneva (1947, 1952). Beyond medicine, he was involved in business as adviser to Radio Minería, president of the Sociedad Abastecedora de la Minería, and founder of the Compañía Minera "Merceditas." == Political career == Torres joined the Radical Party, serving as vice president of the first Congress of the Radical Youth. He was elected Deputy for Chañaral, Copiapó, Freirina and Huasco (1926–1930), joining the Permanent Commission of Public Assistance and Hygiene. Reelected in the controversial "Thermal Congress" of 1930, his mandate was interrupted in 1932 after the Socialist Revolution. He returned to the Chamber of Deputies in 1933, serving until 1941, integrating the Permanent Commissions of Labour and Social Welfare. In 1941 he was elected Senator for Atacama and Coquimbo, serving uninterruptedly until 1965. He participated in the Commissions of Mining and Industrial Development, Foreign Relations and Trade, Government, Hygiene and Public Health. He was also counsellor of the Caja de Crédito Minero (1949–1953). Between 31 May 1961 and 10 October 1962 he was Vice President of the Senate. == Death == He died in Santiago on 16 July 1972, aged 78. == Bibliography == Fernando Castillo Infante, Diccionario Histórico y Biográfico de Chile. Santiago: Editorial Zig-Zag, 1996. Matías

response_text:
Volkspark Humboldthain is a park in the Gesundbrunnen area of Berlin's Wedding district. Opened in 1876, it was Berlin's third "Volkpark" (people's park). Located between Brunnenstraße and Hochstraße at the northern tip of the district, it sits at an elevation of 85 meters (279 ft), forming a hill about half a kilometer east-northeast of Berlin-Gesundbrunnen station.

== History ==
=== Origins and expansion ===
The park's beginnings trace to a 1869 proposal to create green spaces in Berlin's northern districts. Construction started in 1869; designer Gustav Meyer produced a landscape plan centered on a prominent peak, planned walks, and scenic overlooks. The park formally opened May 24, 1876, covering 4.8 hectares in its first phase. The park later expanded and by 1894 reached 29.3 hectares. The Prussian king Frederick William III is honored by a prominent memorial in the park, reflecting the site's historical links. The original design envisioned two main hills. Before World War II, there was an open-air swimming pool (Sommerbad Humboldthain) that opened in 1907, a mini-golf facility, playgrounds, and a small nature museum. A 1941 aerial photograph shows the grounds, including a church (St. Paul-Kirche) at the southern edge of the park. The park and its surroundings were significantly altered starting in 1941 and continue to bear these marks.

=== World War II and aftermath ===
Between 1941 and 1942, two large flak towers (antiaircraft gun towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section.

=== Recent decades ===
Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats.

== Features ==
Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats.
Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure.
Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Operator Constantin Boese launched

The park is also known for the remains of a massive World War II flak tower, now used as a controlled bat-hibernation site and limited-access historical monument. == History == === 19th century === The park lies largely on terrain formerly occupied by vineyards and fields. In 1848, the site hosted revolutionary gatherings; after 1848, the area was leveled. Landscape architect Gustav Meyer drew up plans in 1866 and development began in 1869, opening progressively through the 1870s. The earliest sections—southern, near the brewery site—opened around 1869. Meyer's design emphasized natural-seeming groves, meadows, and curving paths rather than geometric formality. The park was among Berlin's first large public green spaces intended for general recreation. A notable early feature was a restaurant with a lookout terrace, established around 1891 atop the southern ridge. === Early 20th century and interwar period === By the early 1900s, Humboldthain was a well-used local amenity. A small neo-Gothic brick church (Himmelfahrtskirche) stood on its southern edge from 1891. After World War I, the park underwent maintenance and modest expansions. Between 1913 and 1916, an outdoor swimming-pool complex was built on the eastern side, expanding leisure facilities. During the 1920s and 1930s, additional playgrounds, sports fields, and garden sections were added or improved. === World War II === In 1941–42, two enormous reinforced-concrete flak towers (anti-aircraft gun towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats. == Features == Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats. Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure. Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. I Don't Know How to Keep Loving You is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on March 14, 2025, through RCA Records. It was preceded by the singles "Greedy" (2023) and "Exes" (2023), from McRae's second studio album Think Later, "It's ok I'm ok" (2024), and the title track (2025). The album received positive reviews from critics.

== Background and release ==
Following the release of McRae's Think Later in December 2023, McRae worked on "It's ok I'm ok" with songwriter Ryan Tedder. She released the song as a single on September 12, 2024. On December 6, 2024, McRae announced her upcoming album, I Don't Know How to Keep Loving You, was available to pre-order in digital and physical copies with an accompanying album photoshoot.The track "Greedy" was released in September 2023 as the lead single of her 2023 album Think Later. The track "Exes" followed as the second single of Think Later, released in November 2023. On January 24, 2025, she released the title track of the album as a single. On March 10, 2025, the album's track "Sports Car" was released to digital platforms.

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How to Keep Loving You received positive reviews. On Metacritic, which assigns a weighted mean rating out of 100 to reviews, the album has a rating of 80 out of 100 based on eight critic reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews".AllMusic's Neil Yeung rated the album a four stars and stated that "Anchored by McRae's airy, melodic alto and deeply personal lyrics, I Don't Know How to Keep Loving You takes listeners through the ups and downs of early adulthood with a confidence and vulnerability that signals her evolution as an artist." Beth Kirkpatrick of The Line of Best Fit described the album as having "a greater sense of honesty and more expansive sonic experimentation" when compared to McRae's previous albums, and gave it a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How Finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide."

Maria Belen Ringpis-Liban (born January 1, 1965) is an Associate Justice of the Court of Tax Appeals in the Philippines, appointed in 2019. Prior to her appointment, she served as a judge and prosecutor and had an extensive career in tax law and legal education. == Early life and education == Liban attended Centro Escolar University, where she earned her Bachelor of Laws degree in 1987, graduating cum laude. She then held positions as an assistant city prosecutor in Pasig City (1991–1992), Makati City (1992–1998), and again in Pasig City (1998–2001). In 2001, Liban was appointed as an Assistant Regional State Prosecutor in the Department of Justice, a position she held until 2004. From 2004 to 2019, she served as a Presiding Judge of the Regional Trial Court of Muntinlupa City, Branch 256. During this time, she handled a range of cases including both civil and criminal matters, becoming known for her expertise in tax and commercial litigation. == Appointment to Court of Tax Appeals == On July 11, 2019, President Rodrigo Duterte appointed Liban as an Associate Justice of the Court of Tax Appeals, filling one of the vacancies in the court. Her appointment was confirmed by the Commission on Appointments in October 2019. == Academic and professional work == Liban has been active in legal education and tax law professional organizations. Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, January 16, 1847 – July 9, 1894), known as Princess Kazunomiya, was the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate in Japan. She was known posthumously by her Buddhist name Bunkōin (文廣院).

== Early life ==

Mikako was born on January 16, 1847, as the daughter of Ichijō Tadayoshi, a court noble (公卿, kuge). At the age of 7, she married the future shōgun, who was then known as Tokugawa Yoshinobu. Their marriage was held at the daikōsha, a building in the precincts of Kyoto's Imperial Palace. From an early age Mikako lived with her husband and mother-in-law at Hitotsubashi House in Kyoto, however her marriage with Yoshinobu was not a happy one as he spent most of his nights elsewhere. She gave birth to 21 children; a relatively high number of pregnancies per woman at the time, with many of them dying in infancy or all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==

Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==

Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text: Geolycosa subvittata is a species of spider in the family Lycosidae. It is endemic to South Africa and is commonly known as the Cape Geolycosa wolf spider. == Distribution == Geolycosa subvittata is found in the Eastern Cape and Western Cape provinces of South Africa. Notable locations include Grahamstown (now Makhanda), Port Elizabeth, Table Mountain National Park, Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden, and several other sites in the Cape region. == Habitat and ecology == This species is a ground dweller known to live in burrows. It has been sampled from the Fynbos and Thicket biomes at altitudes ranging from 5 to 552 m. == Description == Known from both sexes, Geolycosa subvittata is smaller than the related G. hectoria but has a similar dorsal color pattern. It has two yellow stripes on the abdomen. Ventrally, it bears a median longitudinal black stripe. The tibiae are not distinctly banded. Males measure 11 mm in total length, while females measure 14 mm. == Conservation == The species has a large range and is protected in Table Mountain National Park and Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden. However, most specimens were sampled around 1900, and the species is threatened by loss of habitat. == Taxonomy == The species was originally described by Pocock in 1900 as Lycosa subvittata from Port Elizabeth. It was later revised by Roewer in 1959. == References ==

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson, shot entirely using a smartphone. The film stars Leïla Bekhti, Damien Bonnard, and introduces newcomers Maïa Besson and Kylian Ryckeboer in the lead roles. It follows John, a young Belgian, and June, a young French woman, who meet by chance on the Paris metro. The plot traces their relationship through a series of encounters.

The film marked Besson's first release after a five-year hiatus following Anna (2019). The entire production was conceived, filmed, and edited within six months using an iPhone 16 Pro Max, eschewing traditional film industry structures.

June & John had its world premiere at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on February 13, 2025, in the Berlinale Special Gala section. It was released in French cinemas by ARP Sélection on February 19, 2025, and received generally negative reviews.

== Plot ==
The film begins when John, a Belgian student, meets June, a young Parisian, on a metro platform. Their relationship unfolds in a series of fragmented encounters across Paris—on rooftops, in parks, and empty streets. The narrative structure is non-linear, built around moments rather than a traditional plot arc.

== Cast ==
* Maïa Besson as June
* Kylian Ryckeboer as John
* Leïla Bekhti as June's mother
* Damien Bonnard as John's father

== Production ==

=== Development and writing ===
After completing Anna (2019), Besson stepped away from filmmaking for five years. During this period, he began writing June & John as a personal project, detached from the commercial demands of his previous work. The script was written quickly, reflecting an intuitive approach. Besson stated: "I didn't want to lose time with meetings, financing, and the heavy machinery of film production. I wrote it for myself, then realized I could shoot it immediately."

=== Filming ===
The film was shot entirely on an iPhone 16 Pro Max over a four-week period in Paris in late 2024. Besson worked with a minimal crew consisting primarily of the two lead actors and a small technical team. The choice of smartphone filming was both aesthetic and practical, allowing for greater mobility and intimacy in the framing.

Besson described the process: "With a phone, you're invisible. People don't react the same way as they do in front of a camera crew. There's a freedom in that."

The filming process was characterized by improvisation and spontaneity, with scenes often shot in single takes using natural light and ambient sound.

=== Post-production ===
Post-production was completed within two months. Besson edited the film himself, working closely with composer Éric Serra, a long-time collaborator. The editing style emphasized fragmentation and atmosphere over narrative clarity, with extensive use of voiceover and music to create mood.

== Release ==
The film had its world premiere at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on February 13, 2025, as part of the Berlinale Special Gala section. It was subsequently released theatrically in France on February 19, 2025, distributed by ARP Sélection.

== Reception ==

=== Critical response ===
June & John received predominantly negative reviews from critics. On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds a 21% approval rating based on 24 reviews, with an average rating of 4.1/10.

Boyd van Hoeij of The Hollywood Reporter wrote: "Luc Besson's return to directing after a five-year absence is a wispy, smartphone-shot romantic trifle that feels less like a feature film than an extended demo reel for Apple's latest iPhone model."

Jordan Mintzer of Deadline Hollywood remarked: "There's a certain charm to the project's DIY aesthetic and Besson's willingness to strip down his filmmaking to its bare essentials. But 'June & John' ultimately feels like a rough draft—a director's notebook that was never meant to be seen by an audience."

Wendy Ide of Screen International observed: "The film's experimental approach might have worked as a short, but stretched to feature length, it becomes repetitive and emotionally hollow. The two leads, both newcomers, struggle to convey depth, and the handheld iPhone cinematography, while occasionally striking, often just looks amateurish."

Clarisse Fabre of Le Monde commented: "What holds 'June & John' back is not its technological choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

response_text:
Tokugawa Mikako (徳川美賀子, March 1, 1855 – July 9, 1894) was a Japanese noblewoman of the late Edo period.
Born Ichijo Mikako (一条美賀子), she was an adopted daughter of Prince Ichijō Tadaka of the Ichijō branch of the Fujiwara clan. Her adopted brother was Tadayoshi Ichijo.

== Life ==

=== Marriage ===
In 1862, she married Tokugawa Iemochi's guardian, Tokugawa Yoshinobu (the future shōgun) and moved into his residence in Osaka. Mikako had 7 children by Yoshinobu, two born in Osaka, and five in Tokyo. However, most of them died while young, with one dying at birth, five dying at before the age of one month, and one dying at 21 years old. It was said that the sad life of Yoshinobu's wife had come about because of a curse, reportedly tied to the life of Yoshinobu's father and his mother's servant.

Mikako had a history of gynecological diseases, which caused her to give birth prematurely and all her children all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

== Track listing ==
All songs written by Slapshot

"Leave Me Alone" – 2:33
"Firewalker" – 2:44
"No Friend" – 2:59
"Lookin' for a Fight" – 2:45
"Hang Up My Spurs" – 3:42

== Reception ==

Andre Baumgarten of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the fourth studio album by the Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on June 10, 1996 through Century Media Records. It was the first album to feature guitarist Mike Bowser and drummer Mark Mckay, as founding members Steve Risteen and Mark McKay left the band in 1994. Olde Tyme Hardcore is considered by fans as one of the best Slapshot albums. The music and lyrics explore themes of authenticity, tradition in hardcore punk, and are critical of the commercialization and changing trends in the genre.

== Background and recording ==
Following 16 Valve Hate from 1995, Slapshot had undergone lineup changes, with new members Mike Bowser on guitar and Mark Mckay on drums joining the band. The album was recorded at Normandy Sound and mixed at Normandy Sound in Warren, Rhode Island. The album's title and themes represent the band's commitment to traditional hardcore punk values and their resistance to the evolving trends in the genre during the mid-1990s.

== Critical reception ==
The album received generally positive reviews from punk and hardcore music critics. Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

response_text: Yahia Guidoum (Arabic: يحيى قيدوم) was an Algerian surgeon and politician who served as the Minister of Youth and Sports from 2005 to 2007 and the Minister of Health from 1994 to 1999. == Biography == Guidoum was born in Constantine in 1940 or 1941. He was a doctor trained in orthopedic surgery, and headed the orthopedics department at Constantine University Hospital. He was a doctor at hospitals in Sétif, Constantine, and Algiers from 1965 to 2008. At some point, he was Minister of Labor of Algeria. Guidoum served as the Minister of Health and Population from April 15, 1994 to December 23, 1999. From May 1, 2005 to June 4, 2007, he served as the Minister of Youth and Sports. He was part of the National Democratic Rally (RND) party, where he was a senior member. Guidoum died on March 3, 2020 at the age of 79 in Ibn Badis University Hospital. He was buried in Constantine's Zouargh cemetery. In 2021, a new trauma center was created in Tipaza named after Guidoum. == References ==

response_text: I Don't Know How (stylized in all lowercase) is the third studio album by Canadian singer-songwriter and dancer Tate McRae, released on November 21, 2025, through RCA Records. The album was preceded by the release of five singles: "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", "Sports Car", "Somewhere", and "You're So Easy to Love". I Don't Know How is an expansion of the ideas explored on McRae's previous album Think Later (2023). It encompasses pop, pop rock, and electropop, featuring collaborations with producers Ryan Tedder, Jasper Harris, Grant Boutin, Skyler Stonestreet, and Grant, among others. The album has been described by McRae as "emotional yet fun" and explores "what I've been going through as a younger woman" and "the ways we deal with and come back from the worst moments in our lives". It received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised its emotional vulnerability, catchy choruses, and McRae's exploration of difficult experiences, with some critics describing it as "confessional" and "an artist's third album done right", although there was slight criticism towards some ballads and thematic explorations being considered too generic. == Background == On May 27, 2024, McRae announced via social media that she had begun working on her third studio album. On July 26, 2024, McRae stated that the album was "by far the best work [she has] ever done" and that "these songs mean more to [her] than anything". In a statement, McRae described the album as being about "what I've been going through as a younger woman — my friendships, my relationships, my sense of myself — and the ways we deal with and come back from the worst moments in our lives. I wanted to write something that was emotional yet fun, because that's how I cope with everything." McRae further revealed that the record was inspired by "people who have hurt [her] or who [she has] hurt" and that "[she] wanted to explore those moments and see if [she] could find something beautiful in them." The singer additionally stated that "with this album, [she] wanted to go deeper into the stories [she] was telling, but also make something that [she] could perform live and that people could lose themselves in." == Composition == I Don't Know How encompasses genres of pop, pop rock, and electropop. It includes production from Ryan Tedder, Jasper Harris, Grant Boutin, Skyler Stonestreet, and Grant, among others. Lyrically, the album deals with themes of heartbreak, self-reflection, nostalgia, and complex relationships. The album opens with "It's Ok I'm Ok", an electropop track driven by synth-pop elements and a pulsing beat. It deals with themes of emotional resilience and moving forward after a breakup. "2 Hands" is a pop rock song featuring guitar-driven production and lyrics about the difficulty of letting go of a relationship. "Sports Car" is an uptempo pop track with a nostalgic feel, discussing the excitement and rush of new romance. "Somewhere" is a mid-tempo ballad exploring feelings of being lost and searching for clarity in a relationship. "You're So Easy to Love" is a tender pop song about falling for someone effortlessly. == Critical reception == I Don't Know How received generally positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an average score of 75 based on 12 reviews, indicating "generally favorable reviews". AllMusic's Neil Z. Yeung gave it a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

Alan Robson Kerr (born 1932) is a New Zealand cardiac surgeon who helped establish cardiothoracic services at Green Lane Hospital, Auckland and developed paediatric cardiothoracic surgical services in Palestine.

== Early life and family ==
Kerr was born in Whanganui in 1932. His parents Marjory Robson and Allan Kerr, a physician, moved the family to Auckland in 1937 when Allan took up a position as assistant director of the medical unit at Auckland Hospital.

Kerr boarded at King's College and was dux in his last year. He studied medicine at the University of Otago gaining a Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery in 1956. In 1957 he started work as a house surgeon at Auckland Hospital.

== Medical career ==

=== Cardiac surgery ===
After completing his house surgeon training in 1958 Kerr studied and worked in cardiac surgery at a number of hospitals in America and the United Kingdom from 1959 to 1969. He returned to New Zealand to take up a cardio-thoracic surgical position at Green Lane in 1969. He worked in the cardio-thoracic surgical team with Brian Barratt-Boyes and was one of the surgeons who performed the first heart-lung bypass operation at Green Lane in 1958. Staff from Green Lane hosted and trained doctors from overseas and visited foreign hospitals In 1981 Kerr visited hospitals in New Delhi and Madras (now Chennai) doing cardiopulmonary bypass operations and delivering training in cardiac surgery.

A special supplement of the New Zealand Medical Journal, published in 2001, honoured the work of Kerr and five other cardiology and cardiothoracic consultants: Trevor Agnew, Pat Clarkson, John Mercer, John Neutze, and Toby Whitlock.

== Work in Palestine ==
In 2001 Kerr joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza working in Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem, Palestine Medical Complex in Ramallah and Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza. As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed.

In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. The film The Doctor's Wife was released in 2025.

== Honours and awards ==
Kerr was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, for services to cardiothoracic surgery, in the 1997 New Year Honours.

== Selected works ==

== Background ==
On December 18, 2024, McRae was confirmed to perform as the opening act during the North American leg of The Eras Tour. She also performed and confirmed the release of three singles—"2 Hands", "Sports Car" and "Paper Boat"—during the 2024 MTV Video Music Awards. McRae shared a teaser video for the album on January 15, 2025, along with its pre-order link and release date. On January 22, McRae revealed that I Don't Know How would contain 14 tracks and shared its track list. One week later, the album cover was revealed, featuring the singer sitting on a barstool, dressed in a dark brown jacket and black denim jeans, with her head down, knees drawn to her chest, and arms folded around them.

== Critical reception ==
Upon release, I Don't Know How received generally positive reviews from music critics. Aggregator AnyDecentMusic? reports a score of 6.6 out of 10 based on 10 reviews, indicating "generally favourable reviews". At Metacritic, which assigns a weighted mean score out of 100 to ratings from mainstream publications, the album received a score of 68 based on 14 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews". Editors of Rolling Stone rated it 4 stars out of 5, deeming it "sometimes heartbreaking, sometimes empowering, often very sexy." The album was given a score of 8/10 by NME, with Sarah Jamieson calling it "a coming-of-age record that shows the 21-year-old has only gotten sharper at packaging the messy, aching tumult of the pre-25 brain." Stephen Ackroyd of DIY also gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide."

Linda Godfrey is a South African environmental engineer who works on waste management and the circular economy. She is principal researcher and research group leader at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research. She was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025.

== Early life and education ==
Godfrey studied geology and environmental sciences at the University of Cape Town.

== Research and career ==
Godfrey is principal researcher and research group leader at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research. Her research considers plastic pollution and the circular economy. In particular, she investigates the development and implementation of circular economy infrastructure in the developing world.

=== Circular economy ===
Godfrey works on models that can inform the plastic waste trade, and works to embed circular economy models into the public and private sector. Her research has investigated the economic, environmental and social implications of packaging in South Africa. She advocates for more effective use of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025.

response_text: Camptoceras terebra is a species of freshwater snail with a gill and an operculum, an aquatic gastropod mollusc in the family Viviparidae. == Shell description == The shell of Camptoceras terebra is relatively elongate with a height ranging from 12.5 to 16.0 mm. It is steeply conical and turret-like in shape, with about 4-6 whorls. There are five whorls in the body. The whorls are convex in shape, separated by a deep suture. The surface is relatively smooth except for the presence of axial growth lines and a very thin, greenish brown periostracum. The operculum is thin, amber colored, paucispiral (with 2-3 rapidly expanding whorls), with its nucleus near the inner basal margin. The animal has a relatively short and broad snout. The eyes are located on short stalks which are located between the tentacles. The foot, a muscular organ used for moving, is relatively short. == Distribution and habitat == Camptoceras terebra may be found in India, though its exact distribution is unclear. Specific occurrences have been recorded from Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal. It is considered rare along all parts of its range, though this may be due to underreporting. In West Bengal, it was found in densities of about 4 individuals per square meter. The areas it inhabits are strongly impacted by pollution, agricultural effluents, among other habitat changes. == Ecology == Little is known of the biology and ecology of Camptoceras terebra. It may be found in deep rivers hiding amongst blades of aquatic vegetation. It is slow-moving and sticks well to surfaces. Like others in the superorder Hygrophila, it may be a detritivore, feeding on periphyton such as algae and bacteria. It may be found alongside other gastropods, including Polypylis calathus, Melanoides tuberculata, as well as species of Lymnaea, Planorbis, Pila, and Bithynia. == References ==

Camptoceras terebra is a species of freshwater snail with gills and an operculum, an aquatic gastropod mollusc in the family Viviparidae.

== Shell description ==
The shell of Camptoceras terebra is turriculate, featuring several whorls that extend high into a spire. The shell is of medium thickness and has a distinct, darkish, greenish-yellow periostracum. This periostracum has dark, irregular striations resembling growth lines (these vary based on growth patterns and shell damage). The whorls are quite convex. The sutures that connect the whorls are deeply impressed and well-defined. The apex is sharply pointed and acute. The aperture is circular and angled. The operculum is calcareous. The umbilicus is narrowly open (perforate). The shell height is 19 to 35 mm. The width is 8 to 13 mm.

== Anatomy ==
Camptoceras terebra has a distinct proboscis. It has two antennae, or tentacles, and eyes, which are located between the tentacles. The foot, a muscular organ used for moving, is relatively short.

== Distribution and habitat ==
Camptoceras terebra may be found in India, though its exact distribution is unclear. Specific occurrences have been recorded from Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal. It is considered rare along all parts of its range, though this may be due to underreporting. In West Bengal, it was found in densities of about 4 individuals per square meter. The areas it inhabits are strongly impacted by pollution, agricultural effluents, among other habitat changes.

== Ecology ==
Little is known of the biology and ecology of Camptoceras terebra. It may be found in deep rivers hiding amongst blades of aquatic vegetation. It is slow-moving and sticks well to surfaces. Like others in the superorder Hygrophila, it may be a detritivore, feeding on periphyton such as algae and bacteria. It may be found alongside other gastropods, including Polypylis calathus, Melanoides tuberculata, as well as species of Lymnaea, Planorbis, Pila, and Bithynia.

Théodora (musician)

Théodora, known mononymously as Théodora (born 5 July 1998 in Bayonne), is a French singer and rapper. She became widely recognized in 2025 with the release of her single "Pas de problème" on 26 February and her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory on 4 April. Her music blends influences from zouk, Afropop, R&B, and drum and bass, which critics have interpreted as representing an anti-conformist and emancipatory stance.

== Biography ==

=== Early life and education ===

Théodora was born on 5 July 1998 in Bayonne, Nouvelle-Aquitaine, to parents from the Republic of the Congo and Réunion. She is the eldest of three children; her two younger brothers, Farel and Féréole, form the duo Jeez Suave, with Farel having produced all of Théodora's songs. The family lived in Greece from 2002 to 2005, which Théodora has described as "three years of bliss" when she began listening to music and discovered "girl power" through television programs like W.I.T.C.H. and Winx Club. Her father, a fan of R&B and jazz musicians such as Stevie Wonder and Bobby McFerrin, introduced her to music.

In 2005, the family moved to the Republic of the Congo, where Théodora experienced racism in school. The following year, they settled in Réunion, where she spent the majority of her childhood and adolescence. There, she faced ongoing racism and created an alter ego to cope with the bullying. In 2016, she moved to mainland France to pursue a hypokhâgne program.

=== Career beginnings and early releases ===

Théodora began singing at a young age, initially keeping this interest private. Around 2019, she started recording music with her brother Farel, also known as Jeez Suave, who became her main producer. The pair recorded tracks over instrumentals found on YouTube. In an interview with Libération, she explained that she chose to record in French to set herself apart from other artists. Her artistic name, Théodora, is her real first name, chosen because she believed people would recognize her for her music, not just her name.

Théodora released her debut single "Plus rien" on 14 May 2021, followed by "Vamos" on 11 February 2022 and "Croire en toi" on 6 May 2022. These early releases explored themes of personal insecurity, resilience, and empowerment. In October 2023, she released the single "Tombée du ciel", which attracted modest attention. On 15 March 2024, she released her debut EP 19h08, featuring eight tracks.

=== Rise to fame (2025) ===

In early 2025, Théodora gained widespread attention with the release of "Pas de problème" on 26 February, a track that resonated with audiences, particularly young women. The song's lyrics, which advocate for self-confidence and independence, became popular on social media, with many users posting videos of themselves singing along. By early April, the song had accumulated over 24 million streams on Spotify. The music video, released on 10 March, featured the all-female dancehall group Chtok La Vi and was filmed in the Marais quarter of Paris.

On 4 April 2025, Théodora released her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory via the independent label Yensé Records. The album includes fourteen tracks and features a diverse range of influences, including Afropop, zouk, and drum and bass. Its themes explore self-assertion, independence, and female empowerment, with critics noting its critique of traditional masculinity and advocacy for queer and feminist values. The album received largely positive reviews, with French music magazine Les Inrockuptibles calling it "the best French album of the year" and praising its inclusive vision and musical innovation.

During the summer of 2025, Théodora performed at several major festivals, including Yardland, Les Vieilles Charrues, and Cabaret Vert. In August, Le Monde described her as the "pop phenomenon of the summer" and noted that with the success of her inclusive songs, she had become "the new boss of pop in France." That month, Billboard France reported that Théodora was the second most-streamed female francophone artist of the year in France, behind Aya Nakamura.

On 12 September 2025, Théodora performed on the Angela Davis stage at the Fête de l'Humanité in La Courneuve. The performance, attended by one of the festival's largest crowds, was noted for its political themes and was described as the most significant concert of her 2025 tour by her entourage. Later that month, she and her album Bad Boy Lovestory received the 18–20 prize, organized by the Prix Joséphine des artistes in collaboration with Télérama, Crédit Mutuel, and National Center of Music. The award is decided by a jury of thirteen young music enthusiasts.

== Style and influences ==

Théodora's style has been described as a mix of goth, rap, and R&B influences. Her brother, Jeez Suave, serves as her main producer. Together they have incorporated elements of drum and bass, Creole folk music, Caribbean genres such as bouyon, and influences from her childhood spent in Greece, the Republic of the Congo, and Réunion. In an interview with Vogue France, she credited her father, a music enthusiast, with introducing her to local styles during their travels. She has also cited The Weeknd and Rihanna as influences.

She spent part of her childhood in Brazzaville, Republic of the Congo, where her father worked for the French Institute. In 2009, she moved to Greece for four years before relocating to Réunion, where she lived for another four years. She then moved to Metropolitan France to pursue her baccalaureate and later studied economics at university. 

While enrolled, she worked at McDonald's, but eventually left both her job and her studies to focus on music. Théodora frequently changed schools during her youth and described herself as a solitary, introverted child. Her relationship with her father significantly influenced her songwriting. She has stated that while the two frequently argued, he later became one of her biggest supporters.

In 2019, at age 19, Théodora and her brother released their first song, "Sobri." Initially, Théodora viewed music as a hobby rather than a professional pursuit. However, in 2021, her song "Mami" gained traction on TikTok. The success of "Sobri" followed, which gained 9 million streams on Spotify and went viral on TikTok, with 50,000 videos created using the track. In 2022, she released the EP PLS, though she later stated that she did not fully identify with the project. While promoting her music, she experienced a panic attack before a scheduled concert in Paris but managed to take the stage after receiving encouragement from rapper Aya Nakamura, with whom she had been in contact.

On 3 February 2023, Théodora released "R.A.S." ("rien à signaler," or "nothing to report"), a track that marked a turning point in her career. The single was praised for its introspective lyrics and its blend of chanson française and international sonorities. "R.A.S." also became popular on TikTok, where users shared personal stories of estrangement from family members.

On 21 March 2025, Théodora released her debut studio album Bad Boy Lovestory via Elektra France, a subsidiary of Warner Music France. The album combines alternative R&B with electronic elements. While it explores romantic relationships and the construction of identity, it does not explicitly focus on the father-daughter dynamic central to "R.A.S." Shortly after its release, Bad Boy Lovestory topped the French SNEP album chart and was certified gold within weeks. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002. == Awards and nominations == Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. response_text: Lutz van Dijk (born 3 June 1955) is a Dutch-German writer and historian. In Germany, Van Dijk worked as a high school teacher, first at the Klaus Harms School in Kappeln in Northern Germany and later at the Max Brauer School in Hamburg. == Literary work == Van Dijk describes himself as a "politically engaged writer", so, in many of his non-fiction books, he writes about the history of homosexuality during Nazi Germany's rule. In one of his books, for instance, Van Dijk gives an account of Pierre Seel, a gay man imprisoned in 1941 by the Nazis in Alsace-Lorraine and that was to send to the Schirmeck-Vorbrück concentration camp. As a writer, Van Dijk published articles about social and youth problems in the newspapers Die Tageszeitung, Hamburger Abendblatt, Die Zeit, and Neue Zürcher Zeitung. He also wrote columns in several newspapers, including Noordwest Zeitung, a German-language newspaper based in the city of Oldenburg. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002. == Awards and nominations == Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. response_text: The 2026 Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends (English: Brazilian League of Legends Championship) or 2026 CBLOL is the upcoming thirteenth split season of the Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends (CBLOL), the top Brazilian professional league for the video game League of Legends. The season will mark the inaugural season following the dissolution of the Liga das Américas (LTA) after just one season. == History == === LTA dissolution and return to CBLOL === On October 28, 2024, Riot Games announced their decision to dissolve the LTA after only one season of play for 2025 to be replaced with the CBLOL and the newly-founded Liga Regional Sur (LRS) as part of changes to League of Legends esports for the 2025 competitive season. Later, on November 6, 2024, Riot Games Brazil announced the eight teams that will compete in the 2026 CBLOL season via a 30-second video uploaded to their official YouTube channel. The same day, they announced in a separate article that RED Canids Kalunga, Fluxo, paiN Gaming, LOUD, FURIA Esports, INTZ, and Los Grandes would be the core teams that form the league. Vivo Keyd, a relegated team following the 2024 CBLOL Second Split, was also confirmed to return to the league following their qualification from Circuito Desafiante 2025 Split 2, Brazil's secondary league. On November 7, 2024, Isurus Gaming, another former LTA team representing LTA South from the former LLA, was confirmed to remain as a partner team for the 2026 CBLOL season, marking their first appearance in the league. Furthermore, Isurus would win the LTA South promotion and relegation tournament to advance to its first CBLOL season in 2026. == Format == Following Riot Games' announcement of a new split structure and competitive calendar for League of Legends esports beginning with the 2025 competitive season and the reinstatement of the LCS, it is expected that the league's format will follow a three-split structure. Starting in 2026, the CBLOL will have one guest team similar to the lone LTA season, where the guest team will be subject to promotion and relegation against teams from Tier 2 leagues (Circuito Desafiante and Liga Regional Sur). The CBLOL will also be allocated one team for each international tournament (First Stand Tournament, Mid-Season Invitational, League of Legends World Championship). This was met by criticisms from fans, citing a low number of spots for the region, given the CBLOL teams' performance in the LTA Playoffs and uncertainties surrounding the formats of the international competitions in its current form. == References ==

response_text:
The **2026 CBLOL season** is the 12th season of the Brazilian League of Legends championship, also known as *CBLOL* (Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends). The season will mark the second season since the league's rebranding from the LLA North and return to the original CBLOL name. It also coincides with the reestablishment of the League of Legends Championship Series (LCS) by Riot Games after its replacement in 2023.

== Background ==
The CBLOL returned as a regional league after spending three seasons as part of the Americas league (LLA) North conference. The original CBLOL, established in 2015, was replaced in 2024 as part of a broader shift in competitive League of Legends leagues. In late 2024, Riot Games announced the reinstatement of the LCS, and the LLA was discontinued. The CBLOL, which had been operating as the LLA North regional league from 2023 to 2024, returned to its traditional format starting in 2025, while Mexico and LATAM formed a separate regional league known as LTA South.

The league confirmed that all teams from the former LLA North conference will remain in the league for its return in 2025 under the rebranded CBLOL name. For the 2026 season, paiN Gaming, which joined LTA South from the former LLA, was confirmed to remain as a partner team for the 2026 CBLOL season, marking their first appearance in the league. Furthermore, Isurus would win the LTA South promotion and relegation tournament to advance to its first CBLOL season in 2026.

== Format ==
Following Riot Games' announcement of a new split structure and competitive calendar for League of Legends esports beginning with the 2025 competitive season and the reinstatement of the LCS, it is expected that the league's format will follow a three-split structure.

Starting in 2026, the CBLOL will have one guest team similar to the lone LTA season, where the guest team will be subject to promotion and relegation against teams from Tier 2 leagues (Circuito Desafiante and Liga Regional Sur). The CBLOL will also be allocated one team for each international tournament (First Stand Tournament, Mid-Season Invitational, League of Legends World Championship). This was met by criticisms from fans, citing a low number of spots for the region, given the CBLOL teams' performance in the LTA Playoffs and uncertainties surrounding the formats of the international competitions in its current form.

== References ==

response_text: Dogman is a 2023 drama film written, directed, and produced by Luc Besson. The film tells the story of Doug, a man who has suffered abuse since childhood and finds refuge in the company of dogs. == Plot == In the prologue, viewers see young Doug as he is violently beaten by his father, saved only by the intervention of his dog. In the present day, Doug has developed deep empathy with canines, being able to think, act, and perceive the world like a dog. He can even have premonitions. Doug lives with three dogs and earns a living by stealing, with his animal companions' help. He is later joined by his fourth dog, Mysterious Lady. One day, Doug comes to the aid of a woman named Evelyn, who is about to commit suicide. The two begin a romantic relationship, which then leads them to marry. Evelyn is a stage actress who, during an audition, is rejected due to her limited acting skills. Doug's dog Shadow, who was pregnant, gives birth to four puppies. When Evelyn discovers this, she threatens to leave Doug if he doesn't get rid of the animals. Doug, who has become emotionally dependent on Evelyn, abandons Shadow and the puppies in a forest during a heavy snowfall. One day, Doug and Evelyn are invited to dinner by their neighbor, who explains that he kills any animal that dares to enter his garden. Upon returning home, Doug discovers that his four dogs have been fatally poisoned by the neighbor. Grief-stricken, he decides to seek revenge and storms into the neighbor's house, starting a violent fight. Evelyn calls the police. Doug is arrested and sentenced to five years in prison. There, Doug experiences various hardships: he is repeatedly raped by his cellmate and beaten by the guards. When he is released, he discovers that Evelyn has left him. Overcome with despair, Doug purchases a revolver and attempts suicide; however, he accidentally shoots himself in the leg, severing his spinal cord. As a result, Doug becomes paraplegic and must use a wheelchair for the rest of his life. Some time later, he is reunited with his dog Shadow and three of the now-grown puppies. When Doug was away, Shadow had become a stray dog. A journalist named Sam interviews Doug, who confesses to having participated in illegal dogfights and suffering the violent consequences of those matches. At one point, Doug tells the journalist that he has become a "dogman" himself, and his transformation also involved the consumption of dog food. One evening, Doug and his dogs are invited to a nightclub belonging to Étienne, an old childhood friend involved in petty crime. Étienne proposes that Doug participate in an illegal dogfight in which the stakes are very high. However, Doug declines the offer. Étienne, a ruthless man, kidnaps Shadow and the puppies to coerce Doug into fighting. Doug reluctantly agrees, but during the fight, he sics his dogs on the other dogs and the spectators who came to watch the bloody show. After freeing his animals and escaping with them, Doug begins plotting revenge against his old friend. Meanwhile, Doug attempts to find honest employment: he tries to enlist in the police, but he is rejected. One night, Doug sneaks onto the set of Hamlet, where an actress is performing. He uses a speaker to humiliate her mid-show. It is revealed that the actress is Evelyn. Back at Doug's apartment, the police arrive along with two orderlies from a psychiatric hospital to take Doug into custody. Doug tries to flee but is eventually captured and placed in an ambulance, which he then manages to escape. Sam realizes that Doug's true target is the psychiatric hospital where he was confined during his childhood; this is the place where he was abused. In the hospital, Doug holds several people hostage and tortures Dr. Feldman, who oversaw the facility during Doug's childhood and allowed the abuses. Later, Doug sets the building on fire. "It's a story of a dog and a man, and both of their struggles to survive. Something I've never done before—I learned a lot," Besson explained on social media. Caleb Landry Jones was cast in the role of Doug. Principal photography began in March 2021 in New Jersey during the COVID-19 pandemic. Besson, acting as cinematographer, shot most of the film on an iPhone. In other scenes, he employed GoPro cameras, Steadicams, and Arri Alexa cameras. Editing was handled by Julien Rey at Soho in London. The filming of Dogman marked the second collaboration between Besson and Jones; the two had previously worked together on the set of Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets. Besson dedicated two weeks to rehearsals with Jones. == Music == The film's musical score was composed by Besson's wife, Virginie Besson-Silla, known by the stage name VJ. This was her first time composing a musical score. According to Besson, the original choice for the score was American musician Devonté Hynes. Named after the Star Wars character Chewbacca due to its long, flexible, "hairy" branches that evoke the Wookiee's fur, the species was formally described in 2025. It inhabits rocky seafloors in the tropical western Pacific Ocean at depths exceeding 400 meters, where it forms solitary colonies up to 1.2 meters tall. == Description == Iridogorgia chewbacca features a monopodial, spiral axis typical of its genus, with a brilliant iridescence that gives it a shimmering appearance under light. The colony grows upright and solitary, reaching heights of ~1.2 meters (4 feet) in specimens from near Molokaʻi, Hawaii, while those near the Mariana Trench measure around 50 cm (20 inches). Its branches are long and flexible, stretching up to 38 cm (15 inches), hanging downward in a "shaggy" manner that resembles hair, distinguishing it from stiffer-branched relatives. The polyps, numbering thousands per colony, extend tentacles for filter-feeding and give the branches a fuzzy texture when active. Unlike many corals that form dense reefs, I. chewbacca occurs scattered and alone on hard substrates, with its shiny, iridescent surface reflecting light in patterns akin to "fireworks exploding from the seafloor". Genetic markers, including mtMutS-cox1 and 28S rDNA, confirm its distinction from congeners, though mtMutS showed limited utility for delimitation within the genus. Spiral growth direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) does not serve as a reliable taxonomic trait. == Taxonomy == Iridogorgia chewbacca belongs to the genus Iridogorgia, in the family Chrysogorgiidae, order Malacalcyonacea, class Octocorallia, phylum Cnidaria. response_text:
Olde Tyme Hardcore is the tenth studio album by American hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on April 10, 2018, through Demons Run Amok Entertainment. It is their first album in nine years, since 2009's Make America Hate Again, and first with guitarist Chris Lauria, who replaced original member Jordan Curtis.

== Background ==
In 2017 Slapshot released a cover of Sham 69's "Hurry Up Harry" on a 7" vinyl through Demons Run Amok Entertainment, marking the bands first release with new guitarist Chris Lauria. Though it was reported the Slapshot was working on new material. Lauria debuted with the band on the song "Borstal Breakout" from the Demons Run Amok compilation Demons 'n' Friends Vol. 2 released on July 13, 2013. By 2018 the group only consisted of lead vocalist Jack "Choke" Kelly, the only founding member. Around this period the band released a video for the song "Another Day" a track that appeared on the album.

== Reception ==
Reviewing the album, laut.de stated " What Slapshot offer on their tenth studio album 'Olde Tyme Hardcore' is mainly uncompromising and therefore anything but popular. The Bostonians' concept can also be read as stubborn, which is by no means meant in a negative way. Because as far as their sound is concerned, the followers of the purist HC craft can and do not want to be persuaded."

Rolling-Stone.de gave the album a positive review and praised the group for not trying to add unnecessary musical elements. " With relentless rasp, the 56-year-old barks his lyrics into the distortion offensive. There is no frills, no melody for melody's sake, not even a hint of an attempt to win over anyone to the cause with sophistication and spirited differentiation."

Max Lüdemann of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

== Background and recording ==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was recorded during early 2013 and originally scheduled to be released on April 16, 2013. However, due to manufacturing problems, the album was not released until June 10. Frontman Jack "Choke" Kelly expressed his frustration in an official statement via Facebook and later stated "I think the delay sucks and I am sorry for it and it kills me because our fans had to wait. response_text: Sara Ellen Wilson is an American biomechanical engineer whose publication topics include ergonomics, applications of control theory in understanding the coordination of the human musculoskeletal system, the effects of occupational disorders on the spine and lower back, and engineering education. She is an associate professor of mechanical engineering at the University of Kansas, the former chair of the Bioengineering Division of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, and vice-chair of the National Institute for Engineering Ethics. == Education and career == Wilson was an undergraduate at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, where she received a bachelor's degree in biomedical engineering in 1992. Continuing her studies at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, she received a master's degree in mechanical engineering in 1994, and completed her Ph.D. in medical engineering in 1999. Her doctoral dissertation, Analysis of the forces on the spine during a fall with applications towards predicting vertebral fracture risk, was supervised by Elizabeth R. (Betsy) Myers of the Harvard Medical School. Wilson was a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Virginia, working there with Kevin Granata. Next, she joined the University of Kansas in 2001, and was tenured there in 2007. She directed the Bioengineering Graduate Program from 2010 until 2018, and chaired the ASME Bioengineering Division for the 2015–2016 term. == Recognition == The University of Kansas named Wilson as a 2006 W. T. Kemper Fellow for Teaching Excellence. She was elected as an ASME Fellow in 2017. == References == == External links == Human Motion Control Laboratory Sara E. Wilson publications indexed by

By the early 19th century the holding encompassed portions of today's East 50s near the East River and the old Post Road; the site was gradually absorbed by the Manhattan street grid during the 19th century. == History == The acreage that later formed the Pearsall farm originated in colonial grants near Turtle Bay. A 1676 patent from Governor Edmund Andros to John Danielson described roughly thirty acres northeast of "Deutel" (Turtle) Bay, bounded by the commons and lands of Jacobus Fabricius and David De Voor. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall.
