response_text: Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, January 10, 1835 – July 9, 1894), born Ichijō Mikako (一条 美賀子), was a member of the aristocratic Ichijō Kaneyoshi family and the official wife of shōgun Tokugawa Yoshinobu. == Biography == Born as the daughter of Ichijō Tadayoshi, she became Yoshinobu's wife in 1862, with the name of Goshu. However, from 1853–1867 Yoshinobu had 2 concubines and over 30 children, yet none of Mikako's children survived, all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the seventh studio album by the hardcore punk band Slapshot. It was released on February 22, 2008, through Taang! Records. It was the band's first studio album in over nine years. It received positive reviews. It is also the first album to feature Mike Bowser on guitar instead of Jamie Sciarappa after he left the band.

== Recording and reception ==
For the first time since their inception Slapshot decided to hire a producer. Louie "Mercury" Bellazo who worked for the bands Unearth and Godsmack. During an interview Jack Kelly said "So far we're really happy with Louie. He's a great guy to work with and he's really into the band. Also, it's very refreshing for us 'cause he's coming at it from a producer's stand point, and bringing a lot of stuff to the table as far as what he wants to do with the sound that we, being musicians, would never even think of. We've been doing a lot of experimentation and it's exciting."

Olde Tyme Hardcore received positive reviews from music critics. Pete Crigler of Alternative Press wrote "The seven-song 10 Years Late EP, was basically a big thank-you to the hardcore fans that stuck by them. On Olde Tyme, they're back on the attack, and their assault sounds fresher than any of their supposed peers." Gaz Green of Metal-rules.com gave the album a rating of 3.5 out of 5. stating "Even with the new guitarist onboard the Slapshot sound is there for all to hear, and let's face it, this is basically what most fans would have expected from them." Stefan Franke of Sonic-Seducer wrote "After a nine-year hiatus, the American hardcore punk steamroller Slapshot from Boston is back with their new album "Olde Tyme Hardcore". A breath of fresh air in a scene otherwise dominated by young guns pushing to the fore!" Frank Engelhardt of Musikreviews gave the album 8 out of 10 stars writing "Eleven years after their last album "Tear It Down" the band is back with another thrashing, hard-hitting hardcore package in the tradition of bands like Agnostic Front or Warzone. Comeback of the year." Jan Müller of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them." == Track listing == == Personnel == Slapshot Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals Mike Bowser – guitar Chris Lauria – bass Mark Mckay – drums Technical personnel Arthur Johnston — composer Rudy De Doncker — photography == References ==

response_text:
Olde Tyme Hardcore is an album by the American hardcore punk band Slapshot. It was released on May 6, 2009, on Bridge 9 Records.

== Production ==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was recorded in the Rat's Ass Studio (RAS) in Seabrook, New Hampshire in January 2009. The 10 songs for the album were produced by Arthur Johnston and Slapshot. According to vocalist Jack "Choke" Kelly, they "pushed the 'record' button, and fifteen hours later we had a record." Olde Tyme Hardcore would be the final Slapshot album to feature Mike Bowser on guitar and longtime drummer Chris Lauria on bass. Mark Mckay played drums.

== Reception ==
The album received generally favorable reviews. Hendrik Lukas of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

Sara E. Wilson is an American biomedical engineer whose research concerns biomechanics, neuromechanics, motor control, and fall injury prevention in older people. She is a professor at the University of Kansas, in the Department of Mechanical Engineering, and a Fellow of ASME.

== Education and career ==
Wilson graduated from Wake Forest University in 1990. She went to Harvard University for her graduate studies, earning a master's degree in applied physics in 1994 and a Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in 1999. Her doctoral dissertation, Analysis of the forces on the spine during a fall with applications towards predicting vertebral fracture risk, was supervised by Elizabeth R. (Betsy) Myers of the Harvard Medical School.

Wilson was a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Virginia, working there with Kevin Granata. Next, she joined the University of Kansas in 2001, and was tenured there in 2007. She directed the Bioengineering Graduate Program from 2010 until 2018, and chaired the ASME Bioengineering Division for the 2015–2016 term.

== Recognition ==
The University of Kansas named Wilson as a 2006 W. T. Kemper Fellow for Teaching Excellence. She was elected as an ASME Fellow in 2017.

== References ==

== External links ==

response_text: Sara E. Wilson is an American biomedical engineer and professor at the University of Kansas. In her research, she studies human motor control, musculoskeletal biomechanics, and orthopedic biomechanics. == Education and career == Wilson majored in mechanical engineering at Rice University, where she earned two bachelor's degrees, in 1993 and 1994, with the second on a dual-degree program with Hendrix College. (Betsy) Myers of the Harvard Medical School. Wilson was a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Virginia, working there with Kevin Granata. A brick school was built in 1886 on the north side of King Street near the end of West Street. It was ultimately known as the West Building. An elementary school was built to the east of it, and the high school was built to the north of the elementary on the west side of Hall Street in 1923. The West Building was condemned by the state fire marshal in 1939, but the high school continued to hold classes in it due to overcrowding. It was torn down when the new high school opened. As of 1962, high school classes were held in three other buildings, including the 1923 high school, which was converted to a junior high when the current high school opened. Northwestern Elementary was built in 1959 and closed in 2011. Union Street Elementary was built in 1962. The architect was Guido A. Binda. Currently it is known as Union Street Center and houses the Early Learning Center and other programs for the community. The current high school opened in fall 1963. Warren Holmes Co. was the architect. The opening of the high school was marred by vandalism. A few days

response_text:
June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson.

== Plot ==
Set in June 1995, the story centers on June, a wild and free-spirited girl, and John, a shy and reserved young man. After a chance meeting at a French nightclub, they embark on a whirlwind romance.

== Cast ==
Thylane Blondeau as June
Benjamin Voisin as John
Suzanne Clément as the narrator

== Production ==
The film was announced on 12 December 2024. Filming took place in Paris and the French Riviera. The film was shot entirely with the iPhone 16 Pro. Besson has described the film as "homemade cinema" and said: "Shooting with a phone changes everything. Not just the weight of the equipment but the way you see, the way you feel. It's the power of the film in your pocket. It's pure adrenaline."

== Release ==
The film was released in France on 16 April 2025. The American premiere took place at the Tribeca Film Festival on 6 June 2025.

== Reception ==
The critical reception was very mixed. Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian rated the film 2 out of 5 stars and wrote: "Maybe the most frustrating thing about 'June & John' is not its cinematographic modesty – which in fact could be justified as a deliberate aesthetic of youthful intimacy – but the emotional thinness and the almost parodic mannerism with which it treats the theme of love at first sight. Luc Besson, who has never been a subtle director but has always been a visual one, this time abandons the visual bravura of his science fiction films and action thrillers, but does not replace it with psychological depth or authentic romantic sincerity. What we are left with is an aestheticized postcard, shot on an iPhone as if that alone were a artistic statement."

Bradshaw also wrote: "Thylane Blondeau and Benjamin Voisin are talented young actors, but they are trapped in a script that gives them only poses, not characters. She is the 'free spirit,' he is the 'shy soul,' and that's all they will be allowed to be for the entire 90 minutes. There is no room for complexity, doubt, or even real joy. The narration – which wants to sound poetic – sounds instead like a collection of inspirational phrases from a teenager's diary. And the much-vaunted choice of filming with an iPhone, which might have given the film a documentary spontaneity or a subversive energy, ends up looking like a stylistic gimmick: the image is clean, but anonymous; intimate, but empty."

He concluded: "What really lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

June and John is a 2025 romantic drama film directed and written by Luc Besson. It stars Madelynn Stuenkel and Ethan Rouse. The film was released in France on 12 February 2025.

== Plot ==
An idealistic and almost utopian vision of love and relationships, embodied by two young people, June and John, who meet during summer and fall madly in love with each other.

== Cast ==
Madelynn Stuenkel as June
Ethan Rouse as John
Emily Chang as Woman in nightclub

== Production ==
The film was shot in Los Angeles in June and July 2024. It was filmed with the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

== Release ==
The world premiere of the film took place at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival in the Berlinale Special Gala section on 13 February 2025. The film was released in France on 12 February 2025 by EuropaCorp Distribution.

== Reception ==

=== Critical response ===
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 30% of 10 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 4.7/10.

Jordan Mintzer of The Hollywood Reporter wrote, "It's a sign of these fast-paced times when even Luc Besson is making movies with an iPhone. Filmed in about a month during the summer of 2024, the French filmmaker's June & John is more of a test pattern than anything else, a chance for the helmer to go back to basics and rediscover a youthful spirit he probably lost somewhere between Nikita and The Fifth Element. But while this simple romance between two twentysomethings has its share of free-spirited innocence, it also plays like a calling card for aspiring directors who want to make their own movies without much money or backing. As something to screen in festivals and maybe put out as a streaming item for viewers who like their love stories light and airy, it does the job. But if you're hoping to be deeply affected by a couple of pretty people saying pretty things to one another under the Los Angeles sun, you may want to look elsewhere." Peter Bradshaw of The Guardian wrote, "Luc Besson has come up with a new film: shot on an iPhone, a meandering improvised romance set in Los Angeles, highly influenced by Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise and Before Sunset films, and a little like Leos Carax's Bad Blood. Two beautiful young people, June (Madelynn Stuenkel) and John (Ethan Rouse) are separately heading at night for a party at a house up in the Hollywood Hills, that traditional locus for vapid LA wealth. They get talking in a sweet and unassuming way, and their conversation continues at the party and elsewhere until finally they wonder if this is the night they will finally have sex. It is likable and there are some nice moments, but it feels a bit contrived and the Before Sunrise template is perhaps a bit too obvious. There's something missing: perhaps a sense of risk or a sense of humor or genuine bisexual tension or a greater feeling for the city of Los Angeles itself. But there's an appealing sweetness to it."

Lovia Gyarkye of The New York Times wrote, "Besson's approach is admirably bare-bones. But it's hard to shake the feeling that this wisp of a movie is just a lark." Carole Quintaine of Première wrote, "Behind a deceptively simple device – two young people, a city, a chance encounter – Luc Besson constructs a romantic antithesis that is more interesting in its intentions than its execution. 'June & John', shot with an iPhone, seems to want to return to a cinema of spontaneity and sincerity, but it is trapped by the shackles of its own self-awareness. The script, improvised or nearly so, oscillates between grace and clumsiness, giving the viewer the sense of attending a filmed rehearsal. The two leads are committed, but their characters remain frozen in a dramatic no man's land where we never know if we should take them seriously or see them as allegories of contemporary youth. The real problem is not there: the visual bias chosen by Besson (natural light, mobile camera, minimal staging) gives the film a modern texture but also highlights its dramatic weaknesses. In trying to get closer to the truth, the film brushes shoulders with the inconsequential. What holds 'June & John' back is less the smallness of the means than the vagueness of the subject. We come out with a feeling of sympathy, but also of waste." Aurélien Allin of Télérama wrote, "We would have liked to praise the modesty of the approach, the return to artisanal sources, this desire to capture something fleeting. But 'June & John' looks more like a pitch for an iPhone ad than a real cinematographic story. What Linklater did with genius in 'Before Sunrise' – making time palpable, doubt sensitive, conversation the material of the film – Besson only reproduces its shell. There remains a form of candor, a desire to believe in lightness. It's not nothing. But it's not enough."

Fionnuala Halligan of Screen International wrote, "What lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the tenth studio album from the Boston, Massachusetts hardcore punk band, Slapshot. The album was released on July 5, 2011 on Taang! Records.

== Background ==
The last Slapshot release 16 Valve Hate was in 2006. In 2009, the band began working on the album with Arthur Johnston at Rocking Horse Studio in Pittsfield, New Hampshire. After recording the drum tracks in 2009, it took 18 months to complete vocals and guitar with mixing and mastering. The 18-month-long process of Olde Tyme Hardcore delayed the release of Slapshot's Best of album.

== Touring and promotion ==
In 2009, Taang! Records announced "Summer '10" as a release for Olde Tyme Hardcore. Prior to the release of the album, Slapshot did tour dates with Agnostic Front in the United States. The band promoted Olde Tyme Hardcore with three music videos, "Digital Warfare", "Might Makes Right" and "Superhero". The band did European tour dates in late 2011 with the Cro-Mags and released split 7-inch single with the Cro-Mags called Boston to New York with the non-album tracks "Firewater" and "Choke's Army". Slapshot and Dropkick Murphys did short tour in late 2012.

== Reception ==

response_text:
Mercury(II) perchlorate

Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids.

== Preparation and reactions ==
Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid:
HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O
Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide.

Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex.

Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate:
Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2

== Structure ==
The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions.

== Applications ==
Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines.

== References ==

June & John is a 2025 romantic drama film written, directed and co-produced by Luc Besson. It stars Noée Abita and Gabriel Guevara. It was released in France by ARP Sélection on 16 April 2025.

June and John cross paths in Los Angeles and instantly connect. Deciding to seize the moment, they set off on a spontaneous road trip, exploring California in a thrilling adventure that brings them closer as they face life's unexpected turns.

* Noée Abita as June
* Gabriel Guevara as John

A film festival in France had denied a request by Besson, seeking €50,000 in public funds for a new film, citing sexual assault and rape accusations he faced in 2018. The decision sparked outrage in the film industry at the time. A local cinema accused the Angoulême film festival of a "shocking refusal" to provide public support for a "film by a director who has not been charged, prosecuted or convicted". Besson has also received support from industry heavyweights such as producer Marc Shmuger, costume designer Olivier Bériot and directors Jean-Jacques Annaud and Martin Scorsese.

On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 20% of 5 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 3.8/10.

Writing for Le Figaro, reviewer Julien Lecler gave the film a rating of 1 out of 5 stars, writing, "June and John, the new film by Luc Besson that nobody asked for, is a curious object. Filmed entirely with an iPhone (did we mention that the director prides himself on this twenty-six times during the film's press kit?), this whimsical wandering plunges us into the chaotic love affair between two young people who speak vaguely about life, love and the lightness of being. Well, except that in reality, they just mumble inconsistencies with empty eyes and frozen smiles, a little like humanoid influencers programmed for a badly dubbed advertising campaign. Let's be clear: this is the aesthetic and emotional equivalent of a commercial for California tourism gone wrong... Because no, Luc, filming with an iPhone doesn't make a project 'modern' or 'daring'. It just makes it look like a high school student's final year project, except the high school student would have had more ideas." The review concluded, "At the end of the day, June and John feels like a last-ditch attempt by a once-great director to stay relevant—or at least look busy. Except that by releasing this film in theaters, we feel like we're attending the chaotic meeting of a man who no longer knows where he's going… but who is convinced that his GPS still works. Avoid, unless you like to suffer in silence." Reviewer Aurélien Allin of Libération wrote, "Caught in the fever of a deceptively light romance, the story goes nowhere, literally and figuratively, on roads where nothing happens, other than a succession of clichés about love and youth, shot with a trembling hand and an inconsistent framing… as if Luc Besson had also been infected by the Covid epidemic. How can we imagine, in fact, that its director wasn't himself feverish, at the end of his rope and out of ideas, to dream up such a dud?" Reviewer Christos Bakatselos of the website flix.gr gave the film a rating of 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "Luc Besson, always a lover of images and dreamy romance, decides this time to cross over to the other side of formalism, shooting the film entirely on a mobile phone. A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. Charles Carshon (1920 – October 28, 2011) was an American actor, director, and teacher active in New York theatre and academia from the 1940s through the early 2000s. He is best known for his long association with Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught acting and directed for over three decades.

== Early life and education ==
Carshon was born in 1920. He trained at the Neighborhood Playhouse in New York City, studying with Sanford Meisner.

== Career ==

=== Acting ===
Carshon's Broadway credits include The Tower Beyond Tragedy (1950), in which he played The Queen's Slave, and Billy Budd (1951). He also appeared in Off-Broadway productions, including Beethoven/Karl (1975).

=== Directing ===
Throughout the 1960s and 1970s, Carshon directed numerous Off-Broadway productions. His directing credits include The Lesson, Summertree (winner of the 1968 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director—off-Broadway for Summertree), The Collection, The Dumbwaiter, and The Lover. He served as artistic director at Tapestry Theatre and directed The Tempest at the Berkshire Theatre Festival in Stockbridge, Massachusetts.

=== Teaching ===
Carshon joined the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College in 1965. As head of the college's theatre program and director of the Sarah Lawrence Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction.

== Teaching ==
Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes."

== Stage credits (selected) ==

Broadway

The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast).
Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement).

Off-Broadway

Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer.

== Personal life ==
Carshon married actress and producer Gloria Barret. They frequently collaborated on productions connected to Sarah Lawrence College, including projects with the Green Gate Theatre company. In 1948, Carshon resided at 444 East 58th Street, Manhattan (Sutton Place).

== Death ==
Carshon died on October 28, 2011, at the age of 91. He was survived by his wife, Gloria Barret.

== Legacy ==
Carshon's blended career—as a working actor/director and a long-tenured teacher/mentor—made him a fixture of New York's mid-century theatre training ecosystem and a contributor to the growth of Off-Broadway ensembles such as Tapestry Theatre and Green Gate Theatre.

== References ==

== External links ==

Charles Carshon at the Internet Broadway Database
Charles Carshon at BroadwayWorld

response_text: Tokugawa Mikako (徳川美賀子, February 7, 1835 – July 9, 1894), (Mika-gimi (美賀君)), was the official wife of the final shōgun of the Tokugawa shōgunate of Japan, Tokugawa Yoshinobu. She came from a top ranked noble family and was the only official wife (midaidokoro) in the Tokugawa family who came from the kuge. She later became a Buddhist nun under the name Shinshōin (心静院). She was the final Midaidokoro of Japan and ended an era of woman known by this title. == Biography == Mikako was born as the first daughter of Ichijō Tadaka, a high-ranking court noble, by his wife, Hanako. However, she was brought up by Tadaka's mother, Eiko. Mikako had six brothers and five sisters; although, five of her brothers and three of her sisters died young. In 1849, when Mikako was still a young girl, Lord Nariaki the daimyō of Mito wished for an imperial consort to marry his son, Yoshinobu. Mikako's elder sister, Nobuko, was chosen for this role; however, her mother objected to her marrying Yoshinobu, and as such Mikako was sent in her place. Mikako was officially engaged to Yoshinobu by the end of July 1850, and married him in December 1851. == Marriage and Children == During the marriage, although she held the titles, the relationship between Yoshinobu and Mikako were distant as the couple never produced any children with each other (although this could be explained by her three previous miscarriages) and in Mikako's and Yoshinobu's marriage, three boys were all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, February 12, 1835 – July 9, 1894) was the principal consort of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the fifteenth shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate. She was the daughter of Tadaka Konoe.

== Life ==

=== Early life ===
She was born in the seventh year of the Tenpō era, on January 3, 1835, as the eldest daughter of Tadaka Konoe, the Imperial Steward.
When she was 18 years old, her marriage with Yoshinobu, the oldest son of Tokugawa Nariaki (who was living in retirement at Hitotsubashi Nariyuki's estate in Kyoto) was arranged. The couple married on November 15, 1853.

=== As shōgun's wife ===
Mikako and Yoshinobu had 4 children together, 2 sons and 2 daughters. Although little of their relationship is recorded, the couple were said to be of a similar temperament and close to one another, so the death of their children, three of whom died in childhood, was felt hard by the couple. Another daughter, Katako, was born later and survived. 
After Yoshinobu's marriage to Yoshiko Ichijo, Mikako was said to be upset by his marriage to another wife. The two wives did not have much of a relationship however, they were both sad over their children all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the seventh studio album by the American hardcore punk band Slapshot. It was released on March 3, 2009, through Century Media Records.

== Background ==
On December 5, 2008, Century Media Records announced the signing of Slapshot to the label and that the label would be reissuing the band's back catalog. The announcement also came with news that the band was recording their next album, their first in eight years. Entitled, Olde Tyme Hardcore, the album was released on March 3, 2009, through Century Media Records. 

The album was recorded by Arthur Johnston at Brick Hithouse in Boston, Massachusetts and Guitarist Mike Bowser said in an interview  "We knew what we wanted and got it done pretty quickly. This is a Slapshot record that has it all: speed, power, melody and attitude. After all, we're not teenagers fooling around in a basement." He went on to add that "Olde Tyme Hardcore was the obvious album title. Even though our sound does evolve with age, we're not drastically changing our style or approach. We're keeping things simple and in the tradition of what hardcore punk rock used to represent."

== Critical reception ==
Jan Schwarzmeier of Metal.de described the album as having "Biting guitars and vocals from the throat-cutting fraction set the scene, coupled with a merciless rhythm section—that's all there is, that's all there needs to be." Rob of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the ninth studio album from hardcore punk band Slapshot. Described as "old school hardcore at it's finest" the band released the 27 minute album in 2010. The album title and title song were inspired by people claiming the bands best days were behind them.

== Background ==
Slapshot had released their eighth studio album Tear It Down in 2004 and their first live album "Live At SO36" in 2005. The band resumed touring and in 2009 released a split with Close Call titled "East Vs. West". The band then toured Japan before beginning work on their ninth album "Olde Tyme Hardcore" which was released in 2010.

== Album ==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was recorded in nine days and featured 9 tracks. The albums theme and title song was inspired by people who claimed Slapshot's best days were behind them. Jack "Choke" Kelly explained "I heard some punk behind a bar say something along those lines and that was it," adding that "for us, we wanted to create music that will stand the test of time." The title song was described as a "stomping mid-tempo reaffirmation of Slapshot's commitment to the old school." Musical described the album as "straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core" while another review described it as "a "no-frills" reminder of how much fun a "well-played, pissed-off hardcore record" can be." The album was released on Taang! Records on October 5, 2010, and was initially released with a bonus 7" titled "The Early Years" which included three demo tracks from the band's 1986 demo tape. The vinyl pressing of the album also included the song "Chip On My Shoulder" from the band's 1987 split with Negative FX. An "Olde Tyme Hardcore Tour followed.

== Reception ==
Kerrang magazine called the album "old school hardcore at it's finest," adding that the band was "still sounding sharp as a shiv." Another review noted that "at 27 minutes, this record is a "no-frills" reminder of how much fun a "well-played, pissed-off hardcore record" can be." Christian Rother of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Slapshot had released their eighth studio album Tear It Down in 2004 and their first live album "Live At SO36" in 2005. The band resumed touring and in 2009 released a split with Close Call titled "East Vs. West". The band then toured Japan before beginning work on their ninth album "Olde Tyme Hardcore" which was released in 2010.

== Album ==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was recorded in nine days and featured 9 tracks. The albums theme and title song was inspired by people who claimed Slapshot's best days were behind them. Jack "Choke" Kelly explained "I heard some punk behind a bar say something along those lines and that was it," adding that "for us, we wanted to create music that will stand the test of time." The title song was described as a "stomping mid-tempo reaffirmation of Slapshot's commitment to the old school." Musical described the album as "straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core" while another review described it as "a "no-frills" reminder of how much fun a "well-played, pissed-off hardcore record" can be." The album was released on Taang! Records on October 5, 2010, and was initially released with a bonus 7" titled "The Early Years" which included three demo tracks from the band's 1986 demo tape. The vinyl pressing of the album also included the song "Chip On My Shoulder" from the band's 1987 split with Negative FX. 

The band launched a dedicated tour to support their provocative album, showcasing their enduring hardcore spirit. Critics praised the record's raw energy and authentic approach, highlighting Slapshot's continued relevance in the punk scene.

Reviewers emphasized the album's concise 27-minute runtime and uncompromising musical style. The band's lyrics and performance directly challenged perceptions about their longevity, demonstrating their ongoing commitment to hardcore punk's aggressive roots.

The album lineup featured the core band members: Jack "Choke" Kelly on vocals, Mike Bowser on guitar, Chris Lauria on bass, and Mark Mckay on drums, with technical support from Arthur Johnston and photography by Rudy De Doncker.

Eaton Rapids Public Schools is a school district in Eaton County in the U.S. state of Michigan. Its six schools serve most of Eaton Rapids and Eaton Rapids Township and portions of Benton Township, Hamlin Township, Brookfield Township, Walton Township, and Oneida Charter Township. The schools enroll more than 2,300 students.

== History ==

Prior to the first football game of the year, a match with Charlotte High School, students from Charlotte spray painted "CHS" on the school and smashed school bus windows. The guilty boys agreed to pay for the clean-up and did not face prosecution. Eaton Rapids won the football game against Charlotte 21-6.

The middle school and intermediate school share a building that opened in 1971. The name "Intermediate" was chosen instead of "Junior High" because, as then superintendent Carl Holbrook said, "The word 'junior' gives connotations of secondary importance. We don't want our new school to be junior anything."

Parts of the former high school have been converted into apartments.

== Schools ==

The district's schools share a campus on State Street/Plains Road at Greyhound Drive.

== References ==

== External links ==

George and Willie Muse, also known as Eko and Iko, were African-American albino brothers who were popular in circus sideshows in the first half of the 20th century. It is estimated that the brothers were born in 1893 (George) and 1902 (Willie) to Cabell and Harriet Muse in Truevine, Virginia. Both of them had albinism. In 1899, their father Cabell died and their mother Harriet was left to take care of both George and Willie and their seven other siblings by herself. Harriet was the daughter of a former slave and worked for tobacco farms in order to support her family.

== Abduction ==

At some point in 1914, while working at the local tobacco farm, the brothers were stopped by a bounty hunter James Herman "Candy" Shelton whilst walking home from their jobs. Shelton would convince the brothers to have a checkup under the guise that there was something wrong with them. The brothers would agree, expecting to return later that day. The brothers never returned and it was later discovered that the checkup was simply a ruse in order to abduct them. The brothers were also both underage at the time, with George being 21 and Willie being 12 years old, however since they had lived their lives as farmhands they were not able to verify their ages.

== Circus life ==

Shelton would shortly after abducting them take on the role of their manager. He managed the brothers as they toured across the United States as part of various circuses, including the Al G. Barnes Circus and Ringling Brothers Circus. Some of the funds raised from this were used to pay for the brothers lodging and clothing, however the brothers were not paid wages. The brothers were cruelly exploited and portrayed often as savages and cannibals. They were also often dehumanized such as being said to be aliens from Mars and even portrayed to have been descended from monkeys from the dark contintinent. Shelton also lied to both George and Willie, telling them that their mother had died in order to prevent them from trying to contact her. The brothers were also used as case studies for the US eugenics movement where a picture of them was displayed within the book titled "You and Heredity". The author of the book Amram Scheinfeld would go on to point out the brothers albinism, nystagmus and teeth defects.

== Later life ==

In 1927, the Ringling Brothers Circus passed through Roanoke. Their mother, Harriet Muse, interrupted a performance and confronted circus proprietors and city cops. During this interruption she was reunited with her sons, who had been missing and working without pay for 18 years. Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, July 23, 1835 – July 9, 1894), also known as Sumiko, was the official wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate. == Early life == Born in Kyoto, the daughter of Imperial Prince Fushimi Kuniie and his consort, Arisugawa Nagako, Mikako married Yoshinobu in October 1853.

== Marriage ==
During the marriage, she gave birth to five daughters, all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;

On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

Mikako Ichijō (一条 美賀子, Ichijō Mikako, June 24, 1835 – July 9, 1894), formally known as Seikanin-no-miya Mikako Naishinnō, was a member of the Japanese nobility. She was the first consort of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the fifteenth and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Early life ==

Ichijō Mikako was born as the third daughter to Ichijō Tadayoshi and his wife Tomiko, née Shimazu, at the Ichijō family mansion in Kyoto. As a daughter of sekke, her title was Himenomiya (姫宮). Konoe Tadafusa and Takatsukasa Masamichi were her maternal uncles, and Nijō Nariyuki was her first cousin. Takatsukasa Sukehiro was also her paternal uncle. On September 10, 1853, she married Tokugawa Yoshinobu (then known as Tokugawa Keiki) who had recently become the head of the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family, at the Ichijō family mansion. Upon her marriage, she was titled Himenomiya (姫宮) by the Emperor. In 1858, she moved from the Ichijō household into the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family's mansion in Tokyo.

== Consort to shogun ==

Mikako and Yoshinobu produced six children together, 3 sons and 3 daughters, however only the eldest daughter survived to adulthood, with the rest all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==

Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==

Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text:
June and John is a 2025 French romantic drama film written, produced, and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Pierre Lottin and Juliet Charvet. It was selected to be screened in the Orizzonti section at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival, where it premiered on 31 August 2025. It was released in France and Belgium on 3 September 2025.

== Plot ==
In contemporary France, June and John are two inseparable friends aged between 18 and 20 who grew up together in the city of Alençon. The film follows them during a summer where their complicity turns into a love story against the backdrop of music and youthful impulses.

== Cast ==

* Pierre Lottin as John
* Juliet Charvet as June

== Production ==
The project is presented as a contemporary update of the spirit of Luc Besson's first film, The Big Blue.

=== Filming ===
Principal photography of the film began in August 2024.
The film was shot with the Alpha 9 III camera lent by Sony France, which allows the use of artificial intelligence to track faces in motion. The film was thus shot with AI that kept the faces of the main actors constantly in focus.

== Release ==
The film was shown on 31 August 2025 in official competition at the 82nd Venice International Film Festival. The film was released in France and Belgium on 3 September 2025.

== Reception ==

=== Critical response ===
Upon its release, June and John received mixed-to-negative reviews from critics. On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 25% of 8 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 3.5/10.

Jonathan Romney of Screen Daily gave the film 2 out of 5 stars, writing, "To say that June and John feels like a film made by a sophisticated artificial intelligence is not to endorse its use. However, the film feels like the computer has been fed all of Luc Besson's filmography and his obsessions – big blue skies, loving shots of female faces, an unapologetic view of romance – and has been asked to create an 'authentic' modern love story. The result is a curiously flat experience." Boyd van Hoeij of The Hollywood Reporter wrote, "While tech-wise everything is at the service of supposedly spontaneous-looking images, what ultimately lets down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==

June & John (French: June & John) is an upcoming romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Mélanie Laurent, Simon Royer, and Louis Garrel. It is scheduled to be released in France by ARP Sélection on 4 June 2025.

== Synopsis ==
The movie follows the romantic journey of June and John, a young couple who meet by chance and embark on a passionate relationship. As their love story unfolds, they navigate through the complexities of modern romance, personal growth, and the challenges that test their connection. The film explores themes of love, destiny, and the transformative power of human connection.

== Cast ==
* Mélanie Laurent
* Simon Royer
* Louis Garrel

== Production ==
In an interview with Le Parisien, Besson revealed that he wrote the screenplay for June & John in just two and a half days. The film was shot entirely using the new iPhone 16 Pro Max, making it one of the first major feature films to be captured entirely on a smartphone. Besson expressed his fascination with the technological possibilities offered by modern smartphones, stating that the device allowed for unprecedented creative freedom and intimacy in capturing performances.

== Release ==
June & John is scheduled to premiere in France on 4 June 2025, distributed by ARP Sélection.

== Reception ==
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 21% of 14 critics' reviews are positive.

Catherine Bray of Sight and Sound wrote, "Luc Besson's June & John tries to charm with iPhone-shot intimacy, but ends up feeling more like an expensive screensaver than cinema. The handheld aesthetic, while technically impressive, can't disguise a script that mistakes whimsy for depth—these aren't characters, they're mood boards. Laurent and Royer are photogenic, certainly, but they're stranded in a film that confuses the idea of spontaneity with actual emotional stakes. It's all vibes, no substance—a love story that never bothers to make you believe in love."

Clarisse Fabre of Le Monde gave the film 1 out of 5 stars and wrote, "The main thing that brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

June and John (French: June & John) is a 2025 romantic drama film written and directed by Luc Besson, and starring Isabela Merced and Finn Cole. Set in 1970s Paris, the film follows the relationship between June (Merced), an American student, and John (Cole), a British fellow traveler.

This is Besson's first film to be directed entirely with real-time image-synthesis generative AI. Besson cited the difficulty of simulating 1970s Paris as the reason for using AI for the visuals.

The film premiered at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on 13 February 2025 in the Berlinale Special Gala section, and was released in theaters in France on 12 March 2025 by ARP Sélection. It received mostly negative reviews.

== Premise ==
In the summer of 1970s Paris, June, an American student, and John, a British drifter, meet and fall in love.

== Cast ==
* Isabela Merced as June
* Finn Cole as John

== Production ==
June and John was directed entirely using real-time image-synthesis generative AI. Besson cited the difficulty of simulating 1970s Paris, a specific time and place with very specific visuals, as the reason for using AI for the film's visuals. Besson worked with a number of AI systems, including Kling, Luma and Runway, but found them lacking. He then worked with visual effects company BUF, which developed the AI system used in the film. A small team was assembled at BUF, and they trained the AI using footage from Besson's previous films.

The AI initially produced psychedelic visuals; the team worked to make the AI produce the specific visuals Besson wanted, a process which he likened to "taming a horse." The AI technology allowed the film to be made on a comparatively small budget, with the system replacing special effects, set construction, production design and location shooting.

== Release ==
June and John premiered at the 75th Berlin International Film Festival on 13 February 2025, and was released in theaters in France on 12 March 2025.

== Reception ==
=== Critical response ===
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 13% of 15 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 3.5/10.

Sheri Linden of The Hollywood Reporter wrote, "Besson seems more interested in the tech itself than in the human story he tells with it." Louis Guichard of Télérama wrote, "If one can recognize the merit of this technological feat, however, we observe the impoverishment of the story, which is caught in a labyrinth of long, ethereal sequences, barely rhythmed by syrupy songs and texts full of sentimentality. As pretty as a postcard as it may be, this visually saturated film tires rather than captivates. And the few ellipses made in the narrative end up not really allowing us to become attached to the couple." 

Aurélien Allin of Première wrote, "The real disappointment in 'June & John', beyond the technical choices, is that Besson appears to have abdicated his role as director in favor of that of an operator of algorithms. Each sequence, although neat, is drained of its emotional substance. The excessive use of traveling shots and dreamy dissolves creates a mechanical aesthetic, where poetry gives way to demonstrative artifice. The summer light bathing the film lacks the organic warmth of cinematography worked by hand, and the actors seem to float in a setting that does not retain them, as if prisoners of an interactive museum rather than inhabitants of a living Paris. Besson's desire to film the 1970s through a filter of nostalgia is certainly not reprehensible, but here it turns into a distorting prism which sacrifices narrative coherence for the benefit of technological prowess. June and John follow one another without us ever feeling the intimate or conflictual depth of their relationship. The rare moments of tension are immediately diluted in a visual magma where each shot seems thought of as a future GIF for social networks rather than as a necessary piece of a story. The director's inexperience with these new tools is felt: where a Gondry or a Jonze would have hijacked technology to serve a sensitive vision, Besson allows himself to be seduced by it, forgetting that the tool must remain in the service of emotion." 

Mathieu Macheret of Les Cahiers du cinéma wrote, "What really brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

According to film critic Alexei Gusev, the film should obligatorily be shown in the very first class at film schools as teaching units "watch films" and "love cinema". From 2004 to 2015, Dmitry Sidorov was a professor at the Saint Petersburg State Institute of Film and Television. Following the master class principle, he guided two generations of documentary film directing students for five years each, from entrance examination to diploma. response_text: Dmitry Sidorov (Russian: Дмитрий Сидоров; born 1959 in Novosibirsk, Soviet Union) is a Russian experimental documentary film director, producer, animator and pedagogue, associate professor at the Saint Petersburg State Institute of Film and Television. His works have been shown at many film festivals and won several prizes. Dmitry Sidorov studied physics at Novosibirsk State University (1976–1981) and cinema direction at the Gerasimov Institute of Cinematography (VGIK) in Moscow (1990–1992). After his studies at the physics faculty, he entered the All-Union State Institute of Cinematography, enrolling in Vladimir Kobrin's experimental animation masterclass at the Higher Courses for Scriptwriters and Film Directors, from which he graduated in 1992. His graduation work was the film collage The Biological History (Биологическая история), a reflection on totalitarian propaganda and Soviet environmental policy. From 1999 to 2002, Sidorov held a scholarship at the Karlsruhe University of Arts and Design and completed postgraduate studies in film and media art with Professor Hans Beller. Michael Muñoz (racing crew chief)

Michael Muñoz is an American professional stock car racing crew chief who currently works for Central Coast Racing as the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the ARCA Menards Series West. He was previously the crew chief for Jesse Love in the ARCA Menards Series and ARCA Menards Series West.

== Career ==

=== David Gilliland Racing (2021–2022) ===

Muñoz began his crew chief career in 2021 at David Gilliland Racing serving as the crew chief for Jesse Love. During his tenure as Love's crew chief the duo won 2 races during the 2021 ARCA Menards Series West at Irwindale and Phoenix Raceway. In 2022, Muñoz would get to crew chief for Love again in the ARCA Menards Series. During the 2022 season, Love won at both Phoenix Raceway and Toledo Speedway.

=== Central Coast Racing (2023–Present) ===

In 2023, Muñoz would make the move to Central Coast Racing, becoming the crew chief for the No. 13 in the ARCA Menards Series West. In 2024, he was the crew chief for Jesse Love for 5 races. Love would gain a victory at Irwindale Speedway on March 2nd, giving Muñoz his 5th career win. On April 27th, following Irwindale, NASCAR would give CCR a penalty consisting of "an L1-level penalty to the No. 13 team: loss of 25 driver and owner points, along with a $1,000 fine and a one-race suspension for the crew chief, Michael Muñoz. The penalty is for attaching decals on the vehicle that aren't from the awarded OEM, per Section 12.5.2.2.b of the NASCAR Member Conduct guidelines. That section deals with a "decal violation / unapproved modifications or missing / wrong decals on the vehicle". This penalty was regarding the No. 13, which was racing a Ford Mustang body but had Toyota manufacturer stickers on the car on top of the Ford ones. Muñoz would help bring home the team's first Owners' Championship in the 2024 ARCA Menards Series West. In 2025, Muñoz would remain full time at CCR, being the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the No. 13 car. On April 5th, he would gain another win at Tucson Speedway after Tanner Reif would bring home his first win for Central Coast Racing.

== Personal life ==

Muñoz was born into a Latino family in California. He credits NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series champion Matt Crafton as the reason he got into motorsports professionally. He met Crafton while growing up as a kid in second grade at school. In an interview, he says, "Crafton gave me a platform as a child to dream, his dad, watching him be a mechanic during the day and a race mechanic at night. Grew up around Jerry Baxter and Junior Joiner, they kind of groomed me as a child to dream."

== References ==

Michael Muñoz (born August 21, 1993) is an American NASCAR crew chief. He currently serves as the crew chief for Tanner Reif and the No. 13 Ford Mustang in the ARCA Menards Series West for Central Coast Racing.

== Racing career ==

=== Early career ===
Muñoz started racing go-karts at the age of six. He would then move on to compete in Bandoleros and Legends cars. While attending College of the Canyons and California State University, Northridge, he worked on a Super Late Model team for drivers P.J. Pedroncelli and Derek Thorn. He would later join the Bill McAnally Racing team working on the ARCA Menards Series West and K&N Pro Series East teams.

=== Bill McAnally Racing (2017-2023) ===
Muñoz joined Bill McAnally Racing in the ARCA Menards Series West (then the K&N Pro Series West) as a crew chief for Derek Kraus, who drove the team's No. 16 NAPA Auto Parts Toyota Camry. He would get his first win when Kraus won at Irwindale Speedway. The duo would ultimately get four wins in 2017, which then led Kraus to win the series championship. Muñoz would add another win to his resume when Kraus won at Tucson Speedway in 2018. He would continue being the crew chief for Kraus in 2019, getting two wins at Irwindale Speedway and Las Vegas Motor Speedway, he would help Kraus finish 2nd in the points standings behind his teammate Jesse Love in the No. 19 NAPA Auto Parts Toyota Camry. Muñoz would also crew chief for the part time effort of the No. 99 Toyota Camry, which ran two races that season, being piloted by Connor Mosack at Sonoma Raceway and Roseville, CA native Stafford Smith at the All-Star Showdown.

In 2020, Muñoz would return as the crew chief for Derek Kraus in the No. 16 car, this time moving to the ARCA Menards Series. He would get four wins with Kraus that season at Toledo Speedway, Kansas Speedway, Lucas Oil Indianapolis Raceway Park, and the DuQuoin State Fairgrounds. This would help Kraus get 2nd in the ARCA Menards Series points standings behind Bret Holmes. He would also crew chief for Takuma Koga at both Phoenix Raceway and Kansas Speedway in the No. 19 Toyota Camry.

In 2021, Muñoz would crew chief for Jesse Love in the ARCA Menards Series West and the ARCA Menards Series. Love, who was competing full time in the ARCA Menards Series West, would get 8 wins in the West series, winning at The Bullring, Irwindale Speedway, Phoenix Raceway, and Sonoma Raceway to claim the championship. Love would also compete in 9 races in the main series, which Muñoz also crew chiefed for. Love would get one win that season in the main series at Berlin Raceway. Love would also finish 9th in the main series points standings.

In 2022, Muñoz would crew chief for Jesse Love in the ARCA Menards Series and continue to crew chief in some ARCA Menards Series West races. Love would compete full time in the main series, getting 5 wins at Phoenix Raceway, Dover Motor Speedway, the DuQuoin State Fairgrounds, Salem Speedway, and Bristol Motor Speedway. Love would go on to finish 2nd in points that season. Muñoz would also be crew chief for the part time efforts of the No. 12 for Andres Perez de Lara at Sonoma Raceway, and Takuma Koga at both Phoenix Raceway and Sonoma Raceway.

In 2023, Muñoz would remain as the crew chief for Jesse Love, this time competing part time in the main series and full time in the ARCA Menards Series West. While competing in the ARCA Menards Series West, Love would have 8 wins at The Bullring, Irwindale Speedway, Phoenix Raceway, Sonoma Raceway, and Portland International Raceway while winning the championship. In the main series, Love would compete in 13 races while getting 3 wins at Phoenix Raceway and Kansas Speedway. He would eventually finish 6th in points in the main series. Muñoz would also crew chief for the part time efforts of the No. 12 with Takuma Koga at both Phoenix Raceway and Sonoma Raceway, and the No. 20 with Ayumu Iwasa at Portland International Raceway. Love and Muñoz would part ways at the end of the season, with Love moving to Richard Childress Racing to compete full time in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series, leaving Muñoz remaining at Bill McAnally Racing.

=== Central Coast Racing (2024-present) ===
In 2024, BMR announced that Muñoz would be joining Central Coast Racing as the crew chief for the team's first ever full season effort in the ARCA Menards Series West. Muñoz would crew chief Takuma Koga (who also moved from BMR) in the team's No. 13 Ford Mustang. Koga would get a career best finish for the team at Phoenix Raceway, where Koga would finish 2nd. Muñoz would also get a $1,000 fine from ARCA on April 9th for a P3 penalty, which was for a "Manufacturer Decal incorrectly placed on the vehicle". This penalty was regarding the No. 13, which was racing a Ford Mustang body but had Toyota manufacturer stickers on the car on top of the Ford ones. Muñoz would help bring home the team's first Owners' Championship in the 2024 ARCA Menards Series West. In 2025, Muñoz would remain full time at CCR, being the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the No. 13 car. On April 5th, he would gain another win at Tucson Speedway after Tanner Reif would bring home his first win for Central Coast Racing.

== Personal life ==
Muñoz was born into a Latino family in California. He credits NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series champion Matt Crafton as the reason he got into motorsports professionally. He met Crafton while growing up as a kid in second grade at school. In an interview, he says, "Crafton gave me a platform as a child to dream, his dad, watching him be a mechanic during the day and a race mechanic at night. Grew up around Jerry Baxter and Junior Joiner, they kind of groomed me as a child to dream."

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the tenth studio album by the Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on September 5, 2011, through I Scream Records (Europe) and Taang! Records (USA). "Olde Tyme Hardcore" is the first Slapshot studio album released since "Tear It Down" from 1997.

Ox-fanzine, Visions and Rock Hard magazine all gave "Olde Tyme Hardcore" positive reviews. I Don't Know How But They Found Me is the third studio album by Canadian singer and songwriter Tate McRae, released on February 7, 2025, through RCA Records. It was preceded by the singles "It's Ok I'm Ok", "2 Hands", and "Sports Car". The album features guest appearances from Dasha and Jeremy Zucker.

== Background ==
McRae's previous album, Think Later (2023), marked a shift toward pop music, becoming her highest-charting album in several countries and earning platinum certifications. On August 28, 2024, she announced the lead single "It's Ok I'm Ok," saying, "I needed to write it. I felt like the last album I loved so much and it was so fun, but I needed to do something darker and more emotional, and I felt like this song really set the tone for that." She confirmed that a new album was coming soon while announcing a North American and European tour, titled the "Miss Possessive" Tour. Regarding the inspiration, McRae stated, "I was the type of kid who couldn't show my emotions and couldn't talk about them. I was always this bottled person who just moved on from things and pretended nothing happened. I don't know if that's the Canadian in me or my personality, but I've never been one to talk about my feelings. As an artist, you're made to feel like you have to be perfect all the time, and I had this desire to just break that."

== Critical reception ==
I Don't Know How But They Found Me received positive reviews from music critics. At Metacritic, which assigns a normalized rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream publications, the album received an average score of 77, based on 5 reviews. Aggregator AnyDecentMusic? gave it 7.1 out of 10, based on their assessment of the critical consensus. AllMusic's Fred Thomas rated the album 4/5 stars, highlighting, "Every track is a bop that communicates very real feelings of being young and a little lost, and the album is both McRae's most emotionally open work and her most fun." The Guardian gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

Tokugawa Mikako (徳川 美賀子, 28 February 1835 – 9 July 1894), born Ichijō Mikako (一条 美賀子), was a Japanese noblewoman from the Ichijō family, and the formal wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born on 28 February 1835 to Ichijō Tadaka of the Fujiwara clan, and was given the childhood name of Toshiko (敏子) and later Asuko (鐙子). Her mother was Naruko, the eldest daughter of Prince Arisugawa Orihito. 
Mikako married Yoshinobu on 10 December 1853, a then Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family member. She became his formal wife, but the couple had no children. Mikako was called Goshoryu-san from the days of Yoshinobu's residence at Hitotsubashi, and it is said that the two had a good relationship with each other.

== Married life ==
Yoshinobu had many concubines at a young age. Prior to marrying Mikako, the couple had a child, however it died young. During their marriage, Yoshinobu and his concubines had many children born to them, however, shortly after their birth many of them also died. Of the children born between their marriage and August 1858, all died, with Yoshinobu Iesato being the eldest surviving child, however he spent much of his childhood sick. Mikako was very fond of Kamenosuke (later Tokugawa Iemasa), and Morichiyo (later Tokugawa Yoshihisa) however the pair of them began to dislike her for supposedly causing many of Yoshinobu's children to die early. Following the death of so many children, a rumor emerged that anyone born whilst Mikako was main wife would die an early death. This turned out to be true, as 30 of Yoshinobu's children were born whilst she was his main wife, with 21 of them all dying young.
After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

Mikako Ichijō (一条美賀子, Ichijō Mikako) (May 11, 1835 – July 9, 1894) was a Japanese noblewoman of the late Edo period and the mid-Meiji period. She was the official wife of the 15th (and last) shōgun, Tokugawa Yoshinobu.

== Early life ==

Mikako was born in Kyoto, to the court noble Tadaka Ichijō and his wife Motoko. She was referred to as Suemiya when she was young, and later called Mikako. During her younger years, she was taught how to write waka and received a thorough education.

== Marriage ==

In January 1853 she became the formal wife (midaidokoro) to Hitotsubashi Yoshinobu (later Tokugawa Yoshinobu), the son of Tokugawa Nariaki, on the orders of Emperor Ninkō. The reason for the marriage was to give Tokugawa Yoshinobu a social standing acceptable to allow him to be the successor to the Shogun, Tokugawa Ieyoshi. However, Yoshinobu was unsuccessful and the position of the 13th shōgun was occupied by Tokugawa Iesada. Although she formally married into the Hitotsubashi-Tokugawa family, she did not move in with Yoshinobu. Instead, Mikako remained in Kyoto with her parents whilst her husband lived in Edo. The couple were on good terms, and Mikako began travelling between the capital and Edo when she was 22 years old in 1857. Mikako received from Yoshinobu a number of passionate love letters, which included waka poems. This was considered unusual for a wife and concubine relationship, as Yoshinobu was known to have several mistresses. Mikako fell pregnant five times, but with all of them ending in either miscarriage or the children all dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==

Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==

Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".
