Olde Tyme Hardcore is the eighth studio album by the Boston, Massachusetts hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on March 6, 2009 through I Scream Records. This was Slapshot's second release since reuniting in 2008. A music video was released for the title track "Olde Tyme Hardcore" by singer Jack Kelly. The album was generally well received by critics who felt the album remained true to what the band was about while the band's performance was strong as well.

== Recording and release ==
Following the release of Make America Hate Again, Slapshot entered sessions to begin working on their next album. Once sessions wrapped up, Slapshot announced that their eighth studio album would be titled Olde Tyme Hardcore and released on March 6, 2009 through I Scream Records. In addition, a music video for the title track "Olde Tyme Hardcore" was released. Issued, partially as a response to critics who felt Slapshot was out of touch with the changing times. Kelly felt that the band had remained relevant and true to themselves despite the changes surrounding them over the years. Following the announcement of the album, Slapshot partnered with RevolverMag.com to stream the song "Firewalker" as part of promotion for the upcoming album. This marked the second song available to the public from Olde Tyme Hardcore along with the title track.

== Critical reception ==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was met with generally positive reviews from music critics upon its release. Ox-fanzine.de felt the album was straightforward and brutal. They felt the band changed very little in terms of their musical approach but they appreciated that fact. They noted that the title track demonstrated what the band thought of people who felt Slapshot's best days were behind them. AllMusic called Olde Tyme Hardcore a non-surprising release that represented a strong and time-tested performance from Slapshot. Visions.de called the album "nothing really new", but commended the band's simple and honest approach to presenting their brand of hardcore. Punktastic felt the band remained true to themselves while managing to deliver an album that matched the "uncompromising and brutal" nature of their previous work. They singled out songs like the title track and "Firewalker" as highlights of the album.

Thomas Rieser of AllMusic wrote "Slapshot fans shouldn't be surprised by anything Olde Tyme Hardcore has to offer. But that's what's great about it, since the Boston act hasn't lost any of its initial power over the years, despite the many personnel changes the group has undergone. The album consists of nine straightforward, intense, and time-tested hardcore tracks led by Jack "Choke" Kelly's shouting. Added "The uncompromising and pointed punk rock that Slapshot plays here has lost none of its initial excitement or authenticity." Paul Muttley of Punktastic gave the album a positive review stating "Olde Tyme Hardcore sees them doing what they have done previously, delivering uncompromising and brutal East Coast hardcore." adding "There's nothing groundbreaking or original, but this is Slapshot being Slapshot and there's something to be admired about that. Stand out tracks come in the form of 'Olde Time Hardcore' and 'Firewalker'. If you are looking for hardcore punk in its purest form then Slapshot are certainly worth checking out."

Christian Heinemann of Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

Michael Muñoz (racing)

Michael Muñoz is an American professional stock car racing crew chief who works in the ARCA Menards Series West. He is the crew chief of the No. 13 Ford Mustang for Central Coast Racing, driven by Tanner Reif.

== Career ==
=== Stock car racing ===
==== 2024 ====
Muñoz joined Central Coast Racing in 2024 to be the crew chief for their No. 13 entry. He would bring their team to victory lane for their first win at Phoenix Raceway when driver Jesse Love picked up his only win of the season with CCR, going on to finish second in the Owners Standings. However, also at that same race, Michael Muñoz would be fined $250 and face "loss of Owners points earned from the event that will not affect the Drivers Championship earned by the vehicle". This penalty was regarding the No. 13, which was racing a Ford Mustang body but had Toyota manufacturer stickers on the car on top of the Ford ones. Muñoz would help bring home the team's first Owners' Championship in the 2024 ARCA Menards Series West. In 2025, Muñoz would remain full time at CCR, being the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the No. 13 car. On April 5th, he would gain another win at Tucson Speedway after Tanner Reif would bring home his first win for Central Coast Racing.

== Personal life ==
Muñoz was born into a Latino family in California. He credits NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series champion Matt Crafton as the reason he got into motorsports professionally. He met Crafton while growing up as a kid in second grade at school. In an interview, he says, "Crafton gave me a platform as a child to dream, his dad, watching him be a mechanic during the day and a race mechanic at night. Grew up around Jerry Baxter and Junior Joiner, they kind of groomed me as a child to dream."

== References ==

== External links ==
Michael Muñoz crew chief statistics at Racing-Reference

Michael Muñoz is an American crew chief and car chief in the NASCAR ARCA Menards Series West and ARCA Menards Series. He currently works for Central Coast Racing as the crew chief for the No. 13 in the West Series.

== Career ==

=== Early career ===
Muñoz would enter the racing industry as a car chief for ThorSport Racing driver Matt Crafton in the NASCAR Camping World Truck Series starting in 2016, working his first race at the season opening race at Daytona International Speedway. He would also work additional races with Ben Rhodes and Rico Abreu. He would see his first win at Canadian Tire Motorsport Park with Crafton. In 2017, he would remain with ThorSport Racing, working a majority of races with Crafton. He would also work part time with Ben Rhodes, Grant Enfinger, and Robby Lyons.

=== 2018-2022 ===
In 2018, Muñoz would continue with ThorSport Racing, as the car chief for Crafton. He would work additional races with Ben Rhodes and Myatt Snider that season. He would see seven wins in his time as the car chief for Crafton, which includes two wins in 2018. In 2019, Muñoz would move to BMI Racing as a crew chief for races in the CARS Tour with Connor Mosack. In 2020, Muñoz would be announced as the crew chief for Ryan Repko in the ARCA Menards Series with Fast Track Racing. He would see his debut win as a crew chief at Berlin Raceway. This year was also the year where Muñoz would debut as a crew chief in the ARCA Menards Series West at Irwindale Speedway. In 2021, Muñoz would work with Lessard Motorsports as the crew chief for Ryan Repko in the ARCA Menards Series East. That same year, he worked one race with Ryan Repko in the CARS Tour.

=== Central Coast Racing (2022–present) ===
In 2022, Muñoz would become the crew chief for Central Coast Racing in the ARCA Menards Series West with Jake Drew. He would see his first win with the team at Irwindale Speedway. In 2023, Muñoz would continue at Central Coast Racing but in the ARCA Menards Series East, where he would be the crew chief for Jesse Love. He would see three wins with the team at Five Flags Speedway, Bristol Motor Speedway, and again at Five Flags Speedway in the season finale. He would also additionally work in the West Series where he saw a win at Irwindale Speedway again with Jake Drew. In the Five Flags Speedway finale, he and Jesse Love were both penalized for "Violating Articles 3.5.C.4.b and 3.5.C.4.c: Nose positioning and placement of the required manufacturer's decals on the vehicle". This penalty was regarding the No. 13, which was racing a Ford Mustang body but had Toyota manufacturer stickers on the car on top of the Ford ones. Muñoz would help bring home the team's first Owners' Championship in the 2024 ARCA Menards Series West. In 2025, Muñoz would remain full time at CCR, being the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the No. 13 car. On April 5th, he would gain another win at Tucson Speedway after Tanner Reif would bring home his first win for Central Coast Racing.

== Personal life ==
Muñoz was born into a Latino family in California. He credits NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series champion Matt Crafton as the reason he got into motorsports professionally. He met Crafton while growing up as a kid in second grade at school. In an interview, he says, "Crafton gave me a platform as a child to dream, his dad, watching him be a mechanic during the day and a race mechanic at night. '''Laura Toenjes''' is the superintendent of the [[Kyrene School District]] serving the [[Ahwatukee, Phoenix, Arizona|Ahwatukee]], south [[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], and west [[Chandler, Arizona|Chandler]] communities in the state of [[Arizona]]. She is responsible for the education of approximately 12,000 students located at 25 elementary and middle schools, and employs over 2,000 staff, teachers, and administrators. Toenjes has a three year contract until June 30, 2027 with a base annual salary of $220,000. She has been with the Kyrene school district since 2016 joining when Dr. Jan Vesely became superintendent. After Vesely announced retirement in October 2020, the school board immediately promoted Toenjes to the superintendent role. Her career has also included positions at Sunnyside Unified School District and Arizona Department of Education.

== Notable decisions ==
In February 2025, the Kyrene Governing Board created the Long Range Planning Committee. Toenjes was involved, and vetted 58 members of the committee. As of October 1, 2025, the planning committee is recommending closing 9 out of 25 schools, with final school board decision scheduled for December 2025.

In April 2025, Toenjes re-affirmed that the school district's "policies around equity, inclusion and social-emotional wellness—are fully compliant with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964." Arizona Superintendent of Public Instruction Tom Horne threatened to withhold $1.5 million of federal funding per guidance from the United States Department of Education. The guidance was subsequently revoked, and district was properly funded.

== References ==

response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

Olde Tyme Hardcore is the tenth studio album by the American hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on December 6, 2011 through Taang! Records. This was the first full-length album released by Slapshot since 2000's Tear It Down.

== Background ==
In the four years following 2004's Call to Arms, Slapshot went through a series of lineup changes. Then, in January 2009, they announced that Mike Bowser and Chris Lauria had rejoined the group. That summer, the band headed into the studio with producer Steve Rizin to record new songs. The album was mixed and mastered at Zippah Recording in 2011. Discussing the lengthy process involved with the record, vocalist Jack Kelly remarked "It took about two and a half years to complete," adding "When you're dealing with four different people with full-time jobs and families, it's quite a challenge. But, we're all very happy with the results."

==Release==
Olde Tyme Hardcore was released by Taang! Records on December 6, 2011. The album was distributed through MVD Entertainment Group. In a press release announcing the album, Kelly stated "We're bringing back that olde tyme hardcore sound. That's what we do best. That's what we've been doing since 1985."

==Critical reception==
Olde Tyme Hardcore has received generally positive reviews from music critics. In his review for Ox-fanzine, Joachim Hiller praised the band's consistency, noting that the album "proves once again that SLAPSHOT haven't lost any of their original charm." Jens Nepper from Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

A 1676 patent from Governor Edmund Andros to John Danielson described roughly thirty acres northeast of "Deutel" (Turtle) Bay, bounded by the commons and lands of Jacobus Fabricius and David De Voor. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall. response_text:
Tesco Boy (テスコボーイ, Tesuko Bōi, 16 April 1963 – 25 October 1987) was a British-bred Japanese-trained Thoroughbred racehorse. As a racehorse, he won the Sankei Osaka Hai and was a five-time grade 2 winner. He was even more successful as a sire, topping the Japanese sire list a record eight times between 1976 and 1986. In 1987, he was inducted into the Japan Racing Association Hall of Fame.

== Background ==
Tesco Boy was a bay horse bred in the United Kingdom by his owner, Lord Rosebery. Lord Rosebery's silks of pink, primrose hooped sleeves, and cap, are among the most recognizable in British horse racing. His sire, Princely Gift, won the July Cup and the Nunthorpe Stakes and was the Leading sire in Great Britain & Ireland in 1951. Tesco Boy's dam, Suncourt, a daughter of Nasrullah, was a full-sister to the Irish Derby and St. Leger Stakes winner, Chamossaire.
Tesco Boy was trained during his racing career by Jack Jarvis at Newmarket, Suffolk. He was sold to Zenya Yoshida, and sent to race in Japan.

== Racing career ==
Tesco Boy made eleven starts in Japan, winning eight times. His most important win was the 1966 Sankei Osaka Hai. He also won five grade 2 races, including the Mainichi Okan twice and the Nakayama Kinen. He was the Japanese Horse of the Year runner-up in 1967.

== Stud record ==
Tesco Boy was retired to stud at Shadai Stallion Station in Hokkaido. He topped the sire list for the first time in 1976, when his son Tesco Derby won the Tokyo Yūshun (Japanese Derby), and won the title again every year from 1978 to 1984. Tesco Boy topped the sire list for a record eighth and final time in 1986. In total, Tesco Boy sired 36 graded stakes winners, including eleven grade 1 stakes winners.
His success as a sire made him very popular both in Japan and abroad. His stud fee rose to ¥10 million in 1984, making him one of the most expensive stallions in the world at the time. The most successful of his sons as a sire was Mairzy Doates, who sired Symboli Rudolf, winner of the Japanese Triple Crown and four-time Horse of the Year. Mairzy Doates also sired Symboli Rudolf's younger full brother Dyna Gulliver. Tesco Boy's son Nishino Flower was also a successful sire after his racing career.
As a broodmare sire, Tesco Boy was also highly successful, with his daughters producing such successful race horses as Ines Fujin, the 1990 Tōkyō Yūshun winner, Trot Thunder, the 1996 Yasuda Kinen and Mile Championship winner, and Nehai Caesar, the 1994 Autumn Tenno Sho winner. He is also the grandsire of Mr. C. B., who won the Japanese Triple Crown in 1983. Another of Tesco Boy's grandsons, Sakura Bakushin O, became a successful sire in his own right, and Tesco Boy's bloodline continues in the 21st century mainly through descendants of Sakura Bakushin O. This includes Kitasan Black, of whom Sakura Bakushin O is the damsire of.
Tesco Boy died on 25 October 1987, aged 24.

response_text:
Olde Tyme Hardcore is the ninth studio album from the Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. The album was released on May 5, 2009, through Taang! Records. The album was produced and mixed by Arthur Johnston and contains nine tracks. The bands previous albums featured lyrical themes about drinking, partying and having a good time. The album Olde Tyme Hardcore is a concept album about the Boston Hardcore scene, the band itself, loyalty and friendship. The release was first advertised in 2008 in a interview with Jack Kelly and Arthur Johnston for the Taang! Records 25th anniversary book. The album artwork was done by Rudy De Doncker, who had previously worked with Slapshot on the 2004 album Tear It Down and the 2007 album Make America Hate Again.

== Background ==
In 2008, Taang! Records released an oral history of the record label, titled Taang! The Legends of Punk: An Oral History written by Jake Austen. The book gave fans of the Boston label a insight into the history of the label and its bands. During this time, Jack Kelly and Arthur Johnston participated in a interview, where they discussed upcoming plans. Kelly gave fans hope for a new album, stating "I thought we were retired too, but Arthur had a bunch of songs he wanted to work on with me, and we got the itch to do an album. We are working on some new Slapshot material now."
Slapshot spent the Spring of 2009 recording the album with Arthur Johnston at Mad Oak Studios in Boston. The album features nine songs and was limited to 27 minutes, giving it a classic hardcore punk style. Unlike the bands previous albums, which mainly focused on drinking and having a good time, Olde Tyme Hardcore featured a more conceptual direction. The album was about the bands past, its loyalty and the Boston Hardcore scene. Kelly stated in an interview with Trust fanzine that "These are the first songs I've ever recorded and released that tell a story about someone in particular."

== Musical style ==
Slapshot's style on the previous album had been compared to New York Hardcore bands such as Agnostic Front and Warzone, and had also been compared to the classic 1980's hardcore sound. Olde Tyme Hardcore continues in this same musical direction with heavy guitars and mid tempo drumming. The band avoids fast skate punk and opts for a powerful sound meant for the pit.

== Composition ==
The songs on the album are more melodic when compared to previous Slapshot albums, but still maintain the bands classic sound. "Olde Tyme Hardcore" is about staying true to the origins of the hardcore scene, in reference to the origins, the song lyrics reference Eddie Sutton the vocalist of Leeway. "We've Got The Crew" deals with friendship and loyalty to those within the hardcore community.

== Critical reception ==
"Olde Tyme Hardcore" received positive reviews from critics. Sebastian Koll from Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them."

== Track listing ==

== Personnel ==
Slapshot
Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals
Mike Bowser – guitar
Chris Lauria – bass
Mark Mckay – drums

Technical personnel
Arthur Johnston — composer
Rudy De Doncker — photography

== References ==

response_text:
The **Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends** (abbreviated **CBLOL**; Portuguese for **Brazilian League of Legends Championship**) is the top level of professional League of Legends in Brazil. It is one of thirteen regional leagues in the League of Legends esports scene. Founded in 2012, the league was organized by publisher Riot Games and was part of the Championship Series in Brazil (also abbreviated CBLOL) until 2021, when it became the top-tier division. It served as a qualifying circuit for the Mid-Season Invitational and the World Championship until the 2024 season.

In 2025, the CBLOL was merged with the LCS (with the North Conference known as the LCS and the South Conference known as the CBLOL) to create the League of the Americas (LTA). Following the 2025 season, Riot Games announced that the CBLOL would be reinstated as an independent league beginning with the 2026 competitive season, featuring eight partner teams and one guest team subject to promotion and relegation against teams in the second-tier Circuito Desafiante.

==History==
===Founding and early years===
The Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends (CBLOL) was founded in 2012 as an LCS-style league for Brazil, which was part of the Latin America North (LAN) and Latin America South (LAS) region alongside South America until 2014 when it became its own regional league, splitting from the LAN and LAS region and the North and South American circuit to become its own league circuit.

===Merger with the LCS and LTA era===
On October 21, 2024, the CBLOL and the LCS merged to form the League of the Americas (LTA). The LTA debuted in 2025, featuring teams from both the United States, Canada, and Latin America, and was split into two conferences, North and South, made up of 6 and 10 teams respectively. The conference winners advance directly to the playoffs, while the remaining six teams- the next best three teams from each conference- play in best-of-three series. The semifinals and finals are played- all in best-of-five series. During the maiden LTA Championship Finals between FlyQuest of the North Conference (now LCS) and Vivo Keyd Stars of the South Conference (now CBLOL), Riot Games announced that the LCS and CBLOL would return as independent leagues beginning with the 2026 competitive season.

== League changes ==
=== Teams ===
Before the lone LTA season in 2025, it was announced that INTZ, KaBuM! Esports, Liberty, and Los Grandes, four teams from the most recent CBLOL season, would leave the league following the 2024 season. KabuM! Esports and Los Grandes would be invited to compete in the second-tier Circuito Desafiante beginning in 2025. Two team changes occurred heading into the 2026 season. Leviatán, who was selected as a partner team in the former LTA South from the former LLA, was confirmed to remain as a partner team for the 2026 CBLOL season, marking their first appearance in the league. Furthermore, Isurus would win the LTA South promotion and relegation tournament to advance to its first CBLOL season in 2026.

== Format ==
Following Riot Games' announcement of a new split structure and competitive calendar for League of Legends esports beginning with the 2025 competitive season and the reinstatement of the LCS, it is expected that the league's format will follow a three-split structure. Starting in 2026, the CBLOL will have one guest team similar to the lone LTA season, where the guest team will be subject to promotion and relegation against teams from Tier 2 leagues (Circuito Desafiante and Liga Regional Sur).

The **Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends** (**CBLOL**) is the top level of professional League of Legends competition in Brazil. The CBLOL is run by Riot Games and has eight teams. Each annual season of competition is divided into three splits. At the end of each split, the top-seeded teams compete in the playoffs. The winner and the runner-up of the playoffs qualify for the Mid-Season Invitational and the World Championship, respectively, depending on which split was just completed. The league was established in 2012 and was considered a part of the Latin America North Conference, and later the Latin America Conference, of the League of Legends Championship Series. In September 2024, Riot Games announced that the league would merge with the LCS into a single pan-Americas league called League of the Americas for the 2025 season; however, following the end of that season, Riot reversed the merger and the CBLOL resumed independent operations starting from the 2026 season.

== History ==
In January 2012, Riot Games launched a competitive gaming league in Brazil, similar to other regional leagues created by Riot in other parts of the world. The inaugural season took place from January to August of that year with ten competing teams. The circuit was initially called "1st RIOT League of Legends Tournament" and later rebranded to "Campeonato Brasileiro de League of Legends" for the 2013 season.

The CBLOL originally used a promotion and relegation system for determining which teams could compete in the league. In October 2022, however, Riot Brasil and representatives from the eight teams in CBLOL agreed to abandon this system in favor of a franchising system beginning with the 2023 season. Although the CBLOL was recognized as a distinct league, during the 2023 season it was part of the Latin America North Conference, which also included the Liga Latinoamérica (LLA) and the North American League of Legends Championship Series (LCS). Then, starting with the 2024 season, Brazil and the LLA would form a new Latin America Conference.

At the end of the 2024 season, as a part of a larger restructuring of League of Legends esports leagues across the world, Riot Games announced that the CBLOL and LCS would merge with one another to form the League of the Americas for the 2025 season. The teams from the North Conference (LCS) and the South Conference (CBLOL) would face-off three times throughout the season- all in best-of-five series. During the maiden LTA Championship Finals between FlyQuest of the North Conference (now LCS) and Vivo Keyd Stars of the South Conference (now CBLOL), Riot Games announced that the LCS and CBLOL would return as independent leagues beginning with the 2026 competitive season.

== League changes ==

=== Teams ===
Before the lone LTA season in 2025, it was announced that INTZ, KaBuM! Esports, Liberty, and Los Grandes, four teams from the most recent CBLOL season, would leave the league following the 2024 season. KabuM! Esports and Los Grandes would be invited to compete in the second-tier Circuito Desafiante beginning in 2025.

Two team changes occurred heading into the 2026 season. Leviatán, who was selected as a partner team in the former LTA South from the former LLA, was confirmed to remain as a partner team for the 2026 CBLOL season, marking their first appearance in the league. Furthermore, Isurus would win the LTA South promotion and relegation tournament to advance to its first CBLOL season in 2026.

== Format ==
Following Riot Games' announcement of a new split structure and competitive calendar for League of Legends esports beginning with the 2025 competitive season and the reinstatement of the LCS, it is expected that the league's format will follow a three-split structure. Starting in 2026, the CBLOL will have one guest team similar to the lone LTA season, where the guest team will be subject to promotion and relegation against teams from Tier 2 leagues (Circuito Desafiante and Liga Regional Sur).

response_text: Humboldthain is a public park and memorial in Berlin's Gesundbrunnen district on the border with Wedding. It was constructed from 1869 to 1876 on the site of the "Windmühlenberg" (Windmill Hill) with a distinctive landscape architecture; the park included an observation tower and a monument to King Friedrich Wilhelm III. It later became the site of one of the largest anti-aircraft artillery structures in Germany, a Flak tower that was destroyed in 1948. Following its rebuilding after the Second World War, the park was officially designated a protected Berlin landmark in 1980. == History == === Origins === The park was built on a hill site opposite the "Scharnhorstplatz" (Scharnhorst Square) between 1869 and 1876. The city government had purchased around 5 ha of land on the former Windmühlenberg. and commissioned the Berlin garden architect Gustav Meyer to plan a municipal park. The park was officially opened on August 24, 1876. As was Meyer's custom, the park was laid out in the rolling style of Peter Joseph Lenné, with generous meadows and meandering footpaths. A monument to King Friedrich Wilhelm III of Prussia was erected on the northeast corner of the site, a 21 m (69 ft) high observation tower was built atop the hill. === 20th-century alterations === In 1906, the tower was replaced with a restaurant, and the size of the park was substantially increased as nearby housing was demolished; the additions included a large lawn in the northwest and the playing fields to the south of the old Windmühlenberg. Monumental gates designed by Friedrich Gerlach were erected at three entrances to the park. Around 1911, a formal rose garden was laid out in the southwest. Between 1937 and 1940, the Wehrmacht built the Humboldthain Flak tower in the northwest of the park. It stood 42 meters (138 ft) tall and included a hospital as well as housing for both soldiers and civilians during air raids. At the end of the war, the tower was captured by the Soviet Army and occupied. === Post-war reconstruction === Under Soviet command, the flak tower was partially destroyed in 1948. Following plans by architects Hans Albert Schlemm and Reinhold Lingner, Humboldthain was rebuilt with considerable modifications during the 1950s to compensate for the loss of space to the flak tower and wartime damage. A new observation tower was built from the tower ruins in 1952 to 1955. New paths and embankments were added to the southern perimeter, providing a setting for open-air film screenings. The southwestern rubble heap, now the terraced "Rosenhöhe" (Rose Hill), received a formal rose garden. Remains of the former "Westring" (West Ring), one of the planned tangential roads, were covered up with an avenue of linden trees. The road's overpasses, the "Hochstraße" (elevated road) now span the space as a pedestrian promenade. Residential developments were built around the park in 1956 to 1959 by several architects. The Humboldthain swimming pool complex was built by Hans Szyszkowiz on the park's southwestern boundary between 1969 and 1971. === Recent history === From 2009 to 2010, the park was refurbished, with the Rosengarten receiving improvements to paths, benches and flowerbeds and new information panels. In 2011 and 2012, the city built a climbing facility at the southeastern tower remains of the bunker in partnership with the German Alpine Club. Between 2016 and 2018, the roof, terraces and balcony of the Rosengarten pavilion were extensively repaired and modernized to improve accessibility. == Attributes == Humboldthain combines a variety of built and landscape elements: Monument for King Friedrich Wilhelm III of Prussia (1854): Includes a monumental pillar by Albert Dietrich Schadow. The King's Monument viewpoint: from the top of the former northern flak tower, accessible only in summer. Humboldthain memorial and educational center: Inside the former northern flak tower, documenting the tower's history. The climbing wall center and its café occupy the top level of the tower. "Unter Tage" (underground): The former air raid shelter, accessible only by guided tour. Lessinghöhe: A landscaped hill used for summer open-air film screenings since 2022; there was once a cinema in the nearby Lessing neighborhood. A new event venue called "Kesselhaus" was added in the park on the Lessinghöhe in April 2024; it opened the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

Volkspark Humboldthain is a public park in the Gesundbrunnen district of the Berlin borough of Mitte. The 29.2-hectare (72-acre) site is maintained by the city authorities and is used by residents for recreation. The park is also important for preserving urban biodiversity and providing linkages in the citywide network of green space.
Named after the Prussian naturalist and polymath Alexander von Humboldt, the park was designed by the Berlin city gardening director Gustav Meyer and initially opened in 1876. Subsequently, the site was extended and modified in the interwar period, and then radically altered by the construction of flak towers, warfare, and post-war demolition. Reconstruction works made use of wartime rubble to build an artificial 85-metre hill. A rose garden, climbing walls, pool complex and other modern facilities were added in the 1950s. After German reunification the park was restored as far as possible to Meyer's original design and its historic status was acknowledged in an addition to the inventory of protected garden monuments.
The park is a good example of the nineteenth-century German "people's park" (Volkspark) philosophy, and is also significant for its Second World War flak tower remnants. As a result of its history and varied topography, the park today provides a range of recreation facilities including playgrounds, a rose garden, swimming pool, sports facilities and open-air theatre. Humboldthain is also valued as a green corridor and wildlife resource in the densely developed area of northern Berlin.

== Geography ==
The park covers a level area in the north, with an embankment and two hills with valleys in the southern part of the site. There is a 78-metre difference in altitude (from a high point at 85 meters above sea level). The site was once part of the floodplain of the Panke river; a stream called the Humboldthainer Weiherwiesengraben flowed through the park until the 1950s. The park is separated from the Berlin–Szczecin railway line by a wall. From the upper levels of the park there are views over the city.

== Features ==
The park contains a number of distinct spaces and facilities:
Rosenhügel: Hill with a Soviet memorial, Märchenbrunnen, playground and views
Olympus bunker: A World War II flak tower that is partly above ground and used for storage; it stands 42 meters high and covers 4,600 square meters
Bunkerberg: A wartime rubble heap that has been laid out with paths and woodland planting. The summit is at 85 meters above sea level and provides extensive views.
Hochbunker: The park includes a high bunker which has been converted to a venue for concerts and events. It recently reopened in 2022 after extensive renovations, with the venue hosting a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May.
Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition.
Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV).
Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas.
Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns.

== Conservation ==
The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte.

== Access ==
The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes.

== Gallery ==

== References ==

response_text: Humboldthain is a park in the Gesundbrunnen area of Berlin, located at 13355 Berlin in the borough of Mitte. Spanning a total area of about 29.5 hectares (73 acres), it was commissioned by King Frederick William IV of Prussia and laid out by landscape architect Gustav Meyer between 1866 and 1876 on a former parade ground for Prussia's Life Guards. When the park opened in 1876, it represented the first people's park in Berlin; during World War II, the grounds suffered significant damage as the site of the northern flak tower. After 1945, the remains of the tower were buried under a rubble hill and the area was redeveloped into a postwar park. == History == === 1848 Revolutions === Violent street fighting broke out in Berlin in March 1848 during the German Revolution. Police and military forces held back from armed conflict with the revolutionaries; instead, a citizens' militia was formed to maintain order, and the Life Guard's parade ground at Gesundbrunnen was relinquished as a meeting place for the Berlin Bürgerwehr. After the revolution was suppressed, Frederick William IV granted the site to the people of Berlin in perpetuity as a gesture of civic reconciliation. === Meyer's Park === The future site of Humboldthain had terrain levels varying as much as eighteen metres (59 feet). In planning the park for this steep topography, landscape architect Gustav Meyer proposed a route network designed to be comfortably negotiated by the elderly and physically impaired. Meyer's design also included a monumental double staircase at what is now Hochstrasse; at the foot of the stairs on the lower end of the park, he planned a fountain, flanked by a pair of pubs. Before his death, Meyer had completed a public park in the style of an urban forest, with curving pathways bordered by copses of trees and generous sight lines. === World War II and rebuilding === During the Second World War, the Nazis built one of three large anti-aircraft flak towers, the Flakturm Humboldthain, in the center of the park. One of the two main buildings, originally 42 metres (138 feet) high with walls three metres (almost 10 feet) thick, was blown up by French occupation troops after the war ended, leaving behind a 60-foot (18 metres) tall pile of rubble. Today it is covered with soil and embedded in the park as a hill. After the war, the park was redesigned by landscape architect Reinhold Lingner; a new design followed in 1976. Over several decades, the park developed from Meyer's urban forest into a multi-purpose leisure and recreation area. Since reunification, Humboldthain has undergone further redesign to recapture some of its former character and historical elements. == Features == Monuments and memorials: Memorial in the centre of the park created by Heinrich Splieth to commemorate those who fell during the Franco-Prussian War (1870); relief bronze plaques created by Hans Dammann and placed in 1936 near the Hochstrasse entrance to commemorate victims of the First World War. Alte Kantine: A venue for cultural events and recreation originally built as a canteen circa 1949, and reopened in May 2011 after renovations by the club collective Mitte und Freunde. The group celebrated its return to the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text: Humboldthain (German for "Humboldt Grove") is a locality in the borough of Mitte in Berlin, Germany. It was part of the former district of Wedding, which was merged into Mitte in the 2001 administrative reform. It has a population of 17,889 people (as of 2008). == History == The area was not settled until the 19th century. In 1869, with rapid industrialisation that saw the area housing increasing numbers of workers and poorer migrants, Prussian urban planner James Hobrecht designed the Humboldthain park, the first modern inner-city park to be built within working-class districts. The park was named after explorer and naturalist Alexander von Humboldt. Over the succeeding decades, the district remained poor and working class. During the Second World War, two large flak towers were built in Humboldthain park, followed by a high bunker to serve as shelter during air attacks. In the last days of fighting, the towers were briefly held by a group of French SS-men. After the war and the division of Berlin, Wedding and Humboldthain became part of the French sector. The towers were partially demolished in the early 1950s in a series of controlled explosions; however, due to its construction their complete removal was not attempted, and the ruins (one almost 1500 m2 in size) were left standing and later incorporated into the park. Humboldthain also houses three of Berlin's cemeteries: The Catholic St. Hedwigs-Friedhof II (established in 1834), the French Reformed Church Cemetery (1835), and the Urnen-Friedhof (cremation cemetery; 1912). A fourth, the Reformed Church Cemetery (1835), was closed in 1948 and incorporated into Humboldthain Park. During the 1990s the area was home to Kunst-Werke Berlin's precursor, Kunst-Werke e.V., which operated a temporary art space at Auguststraße 69 that was an important focal point for artists moving into the area following the fall of the Berlin Wall, and a project centre for students of the Berlin School of the Arts. This played a major role in opening the now-famous gallery scene in and around Auguststraße. == Humboldthain Park == The main feature of the locality is the 29-hectare Humboldthain park, one of the larger parks in Berlin. === Park development === Construction of the first section of the park was completed in 1876 to a design by Gustav Meyer, a pupil of Peter Joseph Lenné. A second section was added in 1896 to a design by Hermann Mächtig. The pre-World War II park had an area of about 7.5 hectares, a large share of which was occupied by a Prussian Jahn-Turnplatz (sports ground), where the sport of Völkerball was invented in 1906. In the immediate postwar years, the park was used to dispose of an estimated 1.5 million cubic metres of rubble. Two large flak towers were partially demolished and then covered with landfill to form Humboldthöhe (Humboldt Heights); the remaining sections of the towers were incorporated into the new park, which took on its present form in 1950/51 and received additional areas from adjacent cemetery land. === Park features === Today's park features include: Ice-skating rink: A natural ice-skating rink on a pond at the northern end of the park. Sports facilities: Football grounds and tennis courts were installed in 1980. Beer garden: The Café am Rosengarten was renovated in 2006, and a beer garden added. Playground: An extensive playground complex offering a wide variety of games and playground equipment in the central park area was the 2005 winner of the international playground award "Goldene Schaukel". Bunker: A former high bunker was renovated and converted into a Berlin venue for underground techno parties since 1992, the same year that it opened. The bunker was titled the Bunker and reopened on May 11, 2018 after the venue was renovated. This new venue is expected to attract a lot of attention as it will be one of the more luxurious underground parties within the Berlin scene and would open up capacity for up to 2,000 people at the peak of it. A multitude of artists helped make the venue possible including Boris Tells, Oio, Carsten Nicolai, Madeleine Berkhemer, Norman Pfaff, and MUDA. To raise the hype for the venue it was announced that Berlin DJs and labels Berghain, Marcel Dettmann and Ostgut Ton would christen the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

Humboldthain (German for "Humboldt Grove") is a locality in the borough of Mitte in Berlin, Germany. It was part of the former district of Wedding, which was merged into Mitte in the 2001 administrative reform. It has a population of 17,889 people (as of 2008). == History == The area was not settled until the 19th century. In 1869, with rapid industrialisation that saw the area housing increasing numbers of workers and poorer migrants, Prussian urban planner James Hobrecht designed the Humboldthain park, the first modern inner-city park to be built within working-class districts. The park was named after explorer and naturalist Alexander von Humboldt. Over the succeeding decades, the district remained poor and working class. During the Second World War, two large flak towers were built in Humboldthain park, followed by a high bunker to serve as shelter during air attacks. In the last days of fighting, the towers were briefly held by a group of French SS-men. After the war and the division of Berlin, Wedding and Humboldthain became part of the French sector. The towers were partially demolished in the early 1950s in a series of controlled explosions; however, due to its construction their complete removal was not attempted, and the ruins (one almost 1500 m2 in size) were left standing and later incorporated into the park. Humboldthain also houses three of Berlin's cemeteries: The Catholic St. Hedwigs-Friedhof II (established in 1834), the French Reformed Church Cemetery (1835), and the Urnen-Friedhof (cremation cemetery; 1912). 

I'll continue the thought about the cemeteries. Another cemetery, the Reformed Church Cemetery from 1835, was shut down in 1948 and integrated into Humboldthain Park. In the 1990s, the area became significant for art, hosting Kunst-Werke Berlin's precursor and an important temporary art space that helped launch the gallery scene around Auguststraße after the Berlin Wall fell.

The park itself spans 29 hectares, making it one of Berlin's larger green spaces. Initially designed by Gustav Meyer, a student of landscape architect Peter Joseph Lenné, the first section was completed in 1876. Hermann Mächtig added a second section in 1896, expanding the park's footprint. Before World War II, the park covered approximately 7.5 hectares, with a substantial portion dedicated to a Prussian sports ground where Völkerball was invented in 1906.

Post-war reconstruction transformed the landscape, with approximately 1.5 million cubic metres of rubble disposed of in the area. Two massive flak towers were partially demolished and covered with landfill, creating Humboldthöhe. By 1950/51, the park took its current form, incorporating additional land from nearby cemetery grounds.

Today, the park offers diverse recreational amenities. A natural ice-skating pond anchors the northern section, while sports enthusiasts can enjoy football grounds and tennis courts installed in 1980. A renovated beer garden near the Café am Rosengarten provides a social gathering space. The central playground, awarded the international "Goldene Schaukel" prize in 2005, features extensive play equipment. A former high-rise bunker has been repurposed as a unique venue for underground techno events since 1992.

The bunker's 2018 renovation aims to host luxurious underground parties, potentially accommodating up to 2,000 attendees. Prominent artists like Boris Tells and Carsten Nicolai contributed to its transformation. Berlin's renowned Berghain and Ostgut Ton labels planned a four-day inaugural event to generate excitement about the new space.

The site now features climbing walls operated by the German Alpine Club, with a rose garden hosting approximately 15,000 roses. An outdoor pool complex offers recreational facilities including a 50-meter pool and sunbathing areas. Recognized as a historic garden monument, the park is maintained by Berlin's Mitte district and conveniently located near Gesundbrunnen station.

response_text: Olde Tyme Hardcore is the fourth full-length studio album from the Boston, Massachusetts hardcore punk band, Slapshot. It was released in April 1996 via Victory Records on CD and LP. The title track features a darker, more metallic sound and features a cover of the SSD track Get It Away. The album starts with a clip from the '70s hockey movie that gave Slapshot their band name. The album title is a reference to multiple things: it nods to hockey, Boston's Revolutionary War–themed tourist culture, and to the idea that their hardcore sound was already considered old-fashioned at the time. At the time of the albums release various reports stated lead singer disbanded the group the day after the albums release citing "the idiocy of a scene that is increasingly predominated by college frat boys who will mosh to anything that even closely resembles punk." However the group still went on tours and eventually released a compilation album in 2001. == Reception == German music review Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them." == Track listing == == Personnel == Slapshot Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals Mike Bowser – guitar Chris Lauria – bass Mark Mckay – drums
